PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Kernot (from 964 citizens) and Senator Tierney (from 840 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Mifepristone
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned showeth:

(1) That the trials of the abortifacient drug Mifepristone (RU486) are against the public interest in that they use women as guinea pigs for trials of a drug which causes death to the unborn future citizens and adds undue risk to the health of women.
(2) That when RU486 is used with a prostaglandin it exposes women to a disproportionate risk of pain, bleeding and more serious complications.
(3) That when RU486 is used as a `morning after pill' its effect is abortifacient in that it stops implantation of a human embryo, a future citizen, in the womb.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will legislate to ban the importation and use of RU486 in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Cyclodiene Termiticides
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned petitioners respectfully request that the Australian Government place an immediate ban on all uses of the cyclodiene termiticides Aldrin, Dieldrin, Heptachlor, Chlordane. Cyclodiene termiticides have been banned in many countries due to their persistence and damaging effects in the environment. We also request that the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia be implemented as quickly as possible.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

PETITION.PARA: that we are strongly opposed to the Government's proposed Plant Breeders Rights Bill 1994 in its entirety.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament, should oppose the Plant Breeders Rights Bill (1994) in its entirety.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and Senators assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate:

PETITION.PARA: The ANZACS at the Gallipoli landing on 25 April 1915 were instrumental in forging a new identity for Australia. That landing was a lifetime ago but the deeds of those ANZACS of 1915-18 still speak a message of selfless service and sacrifice that will last forever.

ANZAC Day is a day to remember those who left their homes with a strong desire to return but did not, as well as those who did return. The survivors carried for the remainder of their lives the scars of these experiences.

ANZAC Day is a day to contemplate the spirit that moves men and women to serve, to suffer discomforts, dangers and fears and to risk their lives in defence of their country and in the pursuit of peace, justice and freedom.

On ANZAC Day, we salute not only the spirit of the ANZACS but, in paying tribute to them, we take the opportunity to dedicate ourselves to striving for our country as they did and to upholding their finest qualities of courage, commitment, endurance and mateship.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate draw to the attention of the Government the desirability of declaring ANZAC Day an Australian National Day of Commemoration and that it be held on 25 April each year regardless of the day of the week on which it shall fall.

PETITION.TITLE: Desertification
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We, the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the proposed signing of the UN Convention on Desertification has the potential to adversely affect the rights of farmers to manage their farms, and of local authorities to govern their shires as well as infringing the constitutional responsibility of the states on land management issues.
We therefore request that the treaty not be signed without first receiving the scrutiny and approval of the Senate and subject to such reservations as the Senate might recommend.
As your petitioners in duty bound shall ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia asks that the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993 be amended with the application of common principles. To ensure that all parents with dependent children are treated equally, allowing maximum freedom of choice in child rearing.
These Acts need to be amended to take account of:

PETITION.PARA: 1.the fact that 60% of married women in the workforce who have children, would prefer to stay at home and mind their children, but for economic reasons can't afford to (Institute of Family Studies Survey).
2.the failure to provide for equitable choice for women and families in allowing parents the maximum right to choose the most appropriate form of care for their children.
3.that there be recognition of a parent at home as a formal occupation reflecting its economic value and worth to society.
4.the need for equal payment of any subsidies and allowances for the care of children, paid directly to the parent.
5.the recognition that a family with more than one child incurs extra expenses.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners request that the Senate amend the Childcare Rebate Act 1993 and the Social Security (Home Child Care and Partner Allowances) Legislation Amendment Act 1993.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Sales Tax: Soy Milk and Rice Milk

TALK.START.PARA: I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)deplores inconsistencies in sales tax legislation;
(b)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)milk and soy milk, which is a substitute for milk for lactose intolerant people or people wishing to reduce saturated fat intake in their diets, is sales tax free,
(ii)rice milk, also consumed by lactose intolerant people, attracts sales tax, and
(iii)the soy raw material is essentially imported whereas the rice material is grown locally;

PARA.TAB: (c)is of the belief that it is unfair that soy milk is exempt from sales tax but rice milk is not; and

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 1182, standing in my name and relating to Thailand and the Khmer Rouge, be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in the name of Senator Margetts, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Margetts moving a motion relating to the conduct of business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1182 standing in her name for this day, relating to Australian export of weapons to Thailand.

SPEECH.PARA: Can I just check—do a sort of straw vote—to see whether there is support to have five minutes or a little longer to debate this motion? Is the government likely to support a suspension?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—No.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to take much time—obviously, I have not been given much time on such an important issue. The motion references recent comments by both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) regarding support in Thailand for the Khmer Rouge. I am aware that there are some in the government who feel that these comments are not in conflict with any proposal to export small arms to Thailand, but I am afraid that I will need to be convinced of that point.

PARA.TAB: On the Sunday program on 6 November 1994, Senator Evans, while clearly stating that he did not believe that senior levels of the Thai government were involved directly in supporting the Khmer Rouge, did make reference to the failure of the Thai government to prevent `freelance military personnel and business spivs' from doing so. This sentiment is consistent with comments made in May this year by Mr Morton Abramowitz, a former US ambassador to Thailand, who stated in the Washington Post:

SPEECH.PARA: Some Thais want to keep a hand in Cambodian affairs and create a sort of permanent buffer zone against a renascent Vietnam. A senior Thai official told me in 1992 that protecting the Khmer Rouge was an important element of Thai security. The Thai publicly proclaim the opposite and provide economic assistance to the Phnom Penh government, but even if it doesn't condone the military's complicity with the Khmer Rouge in violation of Cambodia's sovereignty, it has not controlled the practice.

In the context of these admissions about the problems faced by the Thai government in controlling forces in Thailand which are committed to assisting the Khmer Rouge, I cannot see any sense in sending any small arms to that nation because of the potential for those arms to find their way into the hands of the Khmer Rouge forces. Personally, I could not live with myself if it was discovered that Australian weapons were used in the sort of genocide that took place under the Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot.

PARA.TAB: It is for this reason that I feel it important to place on the record my concerns about the potential sale of Australian arms to Thailand and to highlight some concerns raised by me and five other members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, including Senator Bourne, in an additional report that was incorporated in a recently released report on the implications of Australian defence exports.

In that report, the six committee members highlighted some shortcomings in the approval processes for Australian defence exports, particularly in relation to the dominant role of the Department of Defence.

The Steyr rifle sale is a case in point: here we have a proposal for a major sale of weapons to a country where serious questions have been raised both internationally and by the Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs in this country. These are questions of the implication of the sale to a nation in which at least some elements of the military have been implicated in transfers to an insurgent force of extreme brutality. There are implications that this may be a deliberate strategy of destabilisation of a neighbouring country by elements of the Thai military. The arms proposed for sale are small arms, the sort that the Khmer Rouge would use. Even should those arms not be directly on-sold to the Khmer Rouge, we admit it is likely that the arms they replace may be.

In the current guidelines the criteria include consistency with Australia's broad national interests. They include implications for Australia's international obligations to our friends and allies and to the United Nations, including arms control and human rights considerations. They also include implications for regional stability, and whether the proposed export is likely to be used in conflict, either internal or external, or could further militarise such a situation.

I would like to question what in this motion is so terrible to the government, because there are only a couple of things that we have asked. Firstly, we have asked that the proposal be referred to the standing interdepartmental committee for defence exports. The problem with the current system is that it is left to the Department of Defence, and it is left too late; and that was pointed out by the inquiry. Secondly, we have asked that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade do an inquiry into the potential for anything to go wrong.

Considering the statements by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs, I wonder why the heck we have a committee available to look at potential problems with defence exports if this kind of situation is not considered sensitive enough to refer to the committee at this stage. How can the government stand up—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Margetts, your time has expired.
—I seek leave to extend just a little. Is that possible?

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —In opposing this motion I will explain why we will not extend time. Urgency, not substance, is the key factor in calling for suspension of standing orders. Senator Margetts has spent five minutes on the substance, so I guess I will have to do the same, even if it is infringing the standing orders.

PARA.TAB: This is a very poorly framed motion in the way it has been designed. It is poorly framed because it calls on the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to do things which are, in fact, the responsibility of the Department of Defence. It also tends to send the major request to the wrong committee. In any event, it would not matter what the issues were in current debate, Senator Margetts would not support the export of Steyr rifles to any country around the globe because, fundamentally, she does not support any defence exports. So she takes this current issue and dresses it up to disguise her fundamental opposition, which I respect but do not endorse, to the export of arms.

I will just put a few facts on the record. Firstly, there is no application from ADI or any other Australian company to export rifles to Thailand. The Thai government has not made a decision as to which country or even which type of rifle it will source and it will probably not make such a decision for another 12 months. We have in place procedures and guidelines that will adequately cover all Senator Margetts's concerns; that is, guidelines that are constantly revised—the last revision was in March 1994—in which the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Attorney-General's and all these other departments have a say on the committee and an equal vote with Defence as to whether export approval will be given. A whole range of activities are taken into account in any decision made.

I have absolute confidence that if an Australian firm were to win an export order none of those arms would be on-sold to the Khmer Rouge because the Thai government is putting in place procedures where that cannot occur. The allegation has been extended from Senator Margetts as to what the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, and by implication the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, said about Thai assistance to the Khmer Rouge. There has been no allegation from this government that the Thai government has given any material assistance to the Khmer Rouge. There has also been an acknowledgment by this government that the Thai government has tried to cut off any Thai assistance to the Khmer Rouge.

Our fundamental point is that we would like the Thai government to redouble its efforts to prevent any individuals in Thailand giving aid to the Khmer Rouge. We recognise that, because the Thai-Cambodian border is as rugged as it is and also because there are traditional trading routes across it, this is a fundamentally difficult task. There is a sensitivity from Australia's point of view. I think the horror that all Australians would feel if that general who was responsible for the brutal execution of an Australian citizen were able to find refuge across the border from pursuit by the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces would be something we could not live with. I want to make it very explicit where we stand on this particular issue. We are not in any way accusing the Thai government of giving aid and succour to the Khmer Rouge. We are asking it, wherever it can, to redouble its efforts to prevent any individuals getting any particular assistance.

I have multiple reasons for not supporting the suspension of standing orders. We have available time in general business to discuss these matters. I am not going to run the argument that we are busy doing other things because we can always fit things in. But this is an appallingly drafted motion. It is one that is, in fact, a little duplicitous on the part of Senator Margetts because the implication is that if we fixed everything else up and these other problems did not exist she would support the export of Steyr rifles. We all know that Senator Margetts will not support defence exports to any area whatsoever. So I think at this stage this matter will have to take its chances with all the other competing priorities in general business.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the question of the suspension of standing orders, I do not think that a case for urgency has been made out in the circumstances of what seems to be a relatively preliminary stage of development of the possible sale of rifles from Australia to Thailand, and also the fact that procedures are in place that would require assessment of and a contribution to the process by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, which is what Senator Margetts is seeking in any event. But the debate has ranged a little more widely than that, if I am correctly assessing the matter. I will make a few general comments as well.

PARA.TAB: There is a very worrying situation occurring in Cambodia and it is ongoing. We were told by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) that he was confident that, after the change of policy by the Chinese government, the sources of supply and maintenance of the Khmer Rouge would quickly dry up and their capacity to wage an ongoing civil war would be severely impeded. In effect, he was arguing that after the elections in Cambodia the Khmer Rouge could be no more than a nuisance factor and within a relatively short period their cause would be lost and the future for Cambodia would be much brighter.

We always believed his assessment of the Khmer Rouge was naive. We believed he was naive when he embraced the Khmer Rouge within the peace process. Looking at the history and record of the KR, we could not understand how he ever believed that they would genuinely participate in a democratic process or how they might ever genuinely participate in a democratic government. We thought he was naive in his assessment that they would not continue their armed conflict after that election process. Their whole approach to politics in Cambodia has been to take power and influence through the barrel of a gun. There had been no indication upon which he could have reasonably relied that should have led him to the view that they had fundamentally changed.

I think it is fair to say that what we have is a Cambodian government that is in a shocking state of repair. The assessment of the previous Australian Ambassador to Cambodia is that of a government that would appear to be severely corrupt, a military that seems to be largely out of control—some would also say corrupt—and a civil war that is continuing. All the signs are that the Khmer Rouge is as dangerous and as influential as it was before that process. They are being sustained and armed by someone. We thought we might get a hint yesterday because apparently the Minister for Foreign Affairs had a document prepared by his department which was going to give the parliament an up-to-date assessment of the strength and capacity of the Khmer Rouge, the government's view as to their ongoing war-waging potential and the government's current assessment of safety issues regarding Australians in Cambodia.

But the Minister for Foreign Affairs pulled that yesterday. You would have heard, Madam Acting Deputy President, that he decided not to put down that statement on the basis that it did not introduce sufficient new matters. We can only be gravely concerned about that. We are puzzled as to whether the Australian government is confused as to what is going on in Cambodia, whether it is giving sound and adequate advice to Australian citizens in Cambodia, many of whom are doing very worthwhile work in aid projects, apart from those who may be visiting as tourists or for other reasons.

We are deeply disturbed that that assessment by the department was not put on the record yesterday so that Australians would be better informed. There is no doubt that the Khmer Rouge are continuing their conflict. They are as ruthless and shocking as ever. It has perhaps become more apparent to Australians because of the sad death of an Australian recently at their hands, but that does not change the fundamental issues. There are a lot of important issues relating to this matter that ought to be debated at an appropriate time. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats believe this is an urgent motion. Things have changed. I did not notice Senator Margetts saying that anybody believed that the Thai government was selling Steyr rifles to the Khmer Rouge, the SLORC or anybody else, and certainly we do not believe that. I do not think anybody believes that. I think the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, is exactly right when he says there is a real problem with some of the Thai military—not all of them—particularly the ones on the border with Cambodia and on the border with Burma. Senator Evans called them business spivs, and I would have to agree with that as well. There are some people who are totally out of control in Thailand, and those people can get a hold of Steyr rifles from Australia.

PARA.TAB: If they are out of control they are likely, in my view and in the view of many people—including those in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and, I would imagine, Senator Margetts—to sell those Steyr rifles where they can get the most money. And they are likely to get the most money—or gemstones, or timber or anything that they can then sell to make money for themselves—from the Khmer Rouge and the SLORC.

This is an urgent motion. The reason it has been put up, I believe, and I agree with it, is the recent inquiry into the defence export guidelines. We found that the guidelines were a lot better than they had been, but there were bits around the edges which could be significantly improved. One of those bits around the edges was that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade ought to have a far more significant input into where our defence exports go and why they go there.

At the moment the most significant input by far is with the Department of Defence. The Department of Defence does not necessarily look at Australia's strategic interests around the world and particularly in this region when it decides what it will recommend and what it will do in the end on defence exports. Senator Margetts and I, and the others who signed the additional report into this, believe the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade should have a far more significant role in this whole area of defence exports. This is one of the parts of Senator Margetts's motion and I absolutely agree with it. They should have a far more significant role. They should be the ones looking at the strategic interests of Australia.

Part of that process is looking at whether it is in our best interests that our Australian Steyr rifles end up in the hands of the Khmer Rouge. As the foreign minister has said, the Khmer Rouge are getting aid and ammunition and goodness knows what from certain people in Thailand who are not necessarily—in fact, they are probably not—under the control of the Thai government, and that is the problem. That is why the department of foreign affairs ought to be looking at this, that is why the standing interdepartmental committee ought to be looking at this and that is why we ought to be looking at this. That is why we ought to be supporting this motion right now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it perfectly clear that in respect of the sale of arms to foreign countries for their legitimate defence purposes it would be better for that sale to be made by a country like Australia which has far more stringent guidelines than a number of other countries that I could think of. That having been said, however, this is an issue which concerns all of us here and I do not think anyone in the chamber would be other than appalled at the prospect of Australian arms being channelled through certain sources in Thailand to the Khmer Rouge.

PARA.TAB: The question then arises of the appropriateness, or at least the urgency, of Senator Margetts's motion. It has been suggested that the matter is not all that urgent because these matters are in their formative stages, the questions are being considered and presumably the options are being offered to the Thai authorities. I would have thought that that means it is rather urgent that the issue be settled prior to the matter proceeding too far along the road. Under those circumstances, I would have thought that it would be desirable to at least debate the motion.

Whether the Senate ultimately adopts the motion in the terms in which it is presented is another question. The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) has suggested that the committee mentioned in the motion is not the appropriate committee to which to refer this matter. Let him tell us which is the appropriate committee. During the debate, let him put forward an amendment. What is wrong with the examination that is being sought in this motion? I would have thought it is pretty non-controversial even for those people, including myself, who believe that there is a role for Australia to play in the supply of defence material for legitimate defence purposes for specific governments. I support the motion by Senator Margetts to suspend standing orders to enable debate to take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I obviously support my colleague Senator Margetts in moving this motion as a matter of urgency. I can only reiterate what Senator Harradine and Senator Bourne have said: if this is not urgent, what is? It is a very relevant, appropriate point in time for this chamber to be looking at this matter, and five minutes in a half hour contingency debate is not adequate for people who feel that it is important to put content into the debate.

PARA.TAB: On its face, it is an extremely urgent and important matter. It is all the more relevant because of the comments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 7 November, and by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) on 5 and 6 November.

Deferral of this matter would make a mockery of their words of concern over the tragic events that we have just heard about and seen and a mockery of any attempt by the parliament to look at that issue and address it. So I believe it is urgent, and if we do not deal with it today and if it is fobbed off, it puts the credibility of any sentiments of willingness to do their utmost in doubt.

Unless this parliament can be informed of better ways to phrase the motion, of more appropriate ways in which the government can deal with this matter, it is being left in the air in a way that is quite damaging to the government. I cannot believe that the government would not be sensible enough to think of that.

The best way to deal with the situation is to present fairly and squarely what the government feels is the most strategic, positive and useful approach. It also allows those in the chamber who do not agree with those views to express those views of dissent and have them addressed properly and thoroughly on the public record, rather than adjourning to a media debate, to take it to other avenues hoping for a voice there.

I think it is utterly inappropriate that contingency motions and the urgency motions that are put up are used in order to put in content and, on that basis, I add my words of support. This matter is too important to be raised as a matter of urgency and then dismissed.
It is a slight on the parliament and on the government if they do not consider it urgent enough for discussion today.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Margetts's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: (The Acting Deputy President—Senator S. M. West)

PARA.EMPHASIS: * denotes teller

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—I present the 21st report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing.
Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the second report of 1994 of the Procedure Committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.
Ordered that consideration of the report be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion to postpone consideration of certain legislation introduced in the current sittings till the first day of sitting in 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: I have moved to suspend the standing orders in order to request the Senate to give due consideration to the fact that on 18 August 1993 Senator Gareth Evans announced to the Senate a practice that, thereafter, the government would introduce legislation on an `introduce one session, debate the next' basis.

PARA.TAB: In a motion that I moved in the Senate on Thursday, 25 August, I suggested that the government needed to table detailed reasons why, if the bill was not unseen, steps were not taken quickly or effectively enough to maintain the practice and avoid a collapse into confusion and abandonment.
Currently we have more than 50 bills on the Senate program and we have approximately 12 sitting days left. We have also to take the most optimistic view of our efficient rate of debating.

A large number of those 50 bills have been introduced into the Senate in this session. The bills mentioned in my motion are the bills listed for today, two of which are listed for the lunch time non-controversial period.
It is urgent that the Senate gives consideration to the way in which the government has abandoned the agreed practice. The motion should be debated to see what the government intends to do.

Unless the Senate agrees that there is good reason for each of these bills being on the program for the remaining 12 sitting days, they should be adjourned to the first day of the next sitting. This is obviously an urgent matter.

I seek the support of fellow senators to do this commonsense thing which will aid the government in dealing with its program. The Senate will have consensus on the bills that are considered to be worthy of inclusion for the remaining days of this session, despite the fact that they have only been introduced this session.

Senators will then be able to address the difficult task of preparing for the large number of bills that remain before the Senate even if every newly introduced bill is adjourned to the first day of the next sitting. This is a very important motion that needs to be debated to allow every all sides of the chamber to express a view on the practice.

I believe this is a very important matter, and I would like to have the time to explain why I think it is in the interests of democracy and community scrutiny that we adjourn any bill that has been introduced this session for debate and completion in the next session.

I hope that I have persuaded the chamber that it is urgent to debate this matter and to reorganise the program to suit the Senate, and not to suit the government at the expense of the Senate and the public of Australia. The community wants us to approach the legislation that we have before us in a reasoned way.

I think it is quite legitimate for priority to be set by the people who will be debating the bills; otherwise, we will revert to the unfortunate practice that we had over two years ago and in the last 12 days of the session we will have so many bills to consider that we will not be able to do our job properly and debate the bills properly. The reason for that is that the priority for debating those bills has not been determined by content, importance or urgency, but simply because of the order on the government program. I believe that this is a matter that all honourable senators need to consider and that is why we should give it urgent consideration this morning.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, we discussed this matter in our party room this morning. Rather than seek to hijack the proceedings at this stage, I cannot see why we do not revert to the usual cooperative practice where the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the leaders and whips of each party—including the Greens—sit down together and say, `This is what we need to get through.

PARA.TAB: This is what we are designating as important for the end of this session.' We have not tried to do that yet. This is just a little bit of hijacking, a taking over of the proceedings today. We have not tried an alternative, and that is what I object to.

We had the cut-off motion before, which Senator Chamarette did not proceed with. We now have an opportunity to be a bit sensible about this and we should at least try to do that before we adopt this practice. It is possible for us, based on past experience, to say to the government, `We're not prepared to go through this unbelievably exhaustive list, but we are prepared to be reasonable and we're prepared to consider this, this, this and this.'

I propose we do that and not vote in favour of this motion at the moment. We wait for the government to give us some indication that it is prepared to pursue the practice of the past and leave it at that for the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We on this side of the chamber do have concerns about the way in which government business has been managed this year and in previous years. It is an almost inevitable fact of political life at the moment that, every time we get to November, there is a huge number of bills introduced into the parliament which the government wants dealt with before the end of the year. Many of them, as far as primary industry is concerned, are introduced very late into this session. That places enormous pressure on honourable senators who wish to speak on primary industry bills to pull off the bills so that the legislation can get through. That causes enormous concern and angst on this side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: It is fair to say that the late introduction of bills is done to make it difficult to scrutinise the bills, to make it difficult to understand the consequences of the legislation and to make it difficult for the public and the media to comment on the legislation that the government is introducing. There are also a few unforeseen consequences of the legislation.

I only have to go to the last sitting day we had before the last federal election. We were here at 2.30 in the morning debating a bill to set AQIS inspection charges for the export of primary produce. Former senator Archer quite rightly pointed out that the per tonne inspection charge for onions was 40 times the per tonne inspection charge for potatoes. It was quite obviously a typographical error.

There was a very nasty debate in the chamber—I remember it distinctly—in which the government said it was not going to amend the legislation and was not going to enter into any discussion with the opposition because it was 2.30 in the morning. Eventually the Democrats relented and voted with the government. What happened? One of the first bills we had when we came back after the federal election was a bill to amend the amendment act that we had put through on the last day of sitting, altering the per tonne inspection charge for onions because, yes, there had been a typographical error. When that sort of thing happens, we have to have some concern about the quality of the management being exercised in relation to government business and the way legislation is brought forward.

Having said that, we need to have a close look at the motion and understand the consequences of it. Those of us on this side of the chamber do not want to be contributing to a situation where legislation which ought to go through is needlessly put off. I understand that Senator Chamarette has said that the motion can in some way be amended. We are not quite sure exactly how.

TALK.START.PARA: —We haven't seen the motion yet.

—That is one of the other problems we have. I was not aware of it until Senator Harradine came across and told me that he had not been told of it either. So it makes it a little difficult for us to make these decisions on the run. We do not want to needlessly interrupt the legislative program but we want to ensure proper scrutiny and proper debate of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: In the next couple of minutes we will have to look at the motion which is before the chamber very carefully and get a thorough understanding of what the suggestion is and what the implications are. I note that some of the legislation which has been identified to me may be legislation which would require passage before the end of the calender year. If that is the case, obviously it will have to be amended. But we will give it decent consideration. We think the matter is certainly worthy of attention and that is the basis on which the opposition will be dealing with it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather difficult to debate a motion that we have not seen. Yet the complaint from the Greens, in particular, is that they do not want to debate legislation they have not been given enough notice of. So there is an irony there first of all.

PARA.TAB: I guess the real question in this part of the debate is whether it is necessary to deal with this at this moment, for indeed we had an opportunity 24 hours ago for Senator Chamarette to give a notice of motion so that today this matter could be either declared formal or, by using a contingent notice of motion, be discussed. I am debating today a motion I have not seen; and that is difficult. Where is the written version of this? Why the ambush right now? Why the ambush at 25 minutes to 11 on this Thursday?

If this Senate were to follow any decent and proper procedures, it would defeat this motion, and Senator Chamarette would give notice of motion of it today and seek to have it debated, through a similar means, on Monday. It would also be more appropriate, of course, for the motion to be debated when the Manager of Government Business (Senator Faulkner) is here and not away on government business—he will not return till midday. I would oppose Senator Chamarette's motion at this stage on this basis: I have not read it; I do not know what discussions have taken place; and the Manager of Government Business is not here.

There has been ample opportunity to put a notice of motion down, even this morning, to have it debated on Monday. If we have to get into the substance of the debate, I would argue that many of those bills are urgent—some are budget related and some are necessary to go through. I would also adduce arguments that this government has not had ample opportunity to debate legislation in the spring session and that the Senate has gone off on many romps, as it often does, on disallowance motions and many other things. The percentage of time so far devoted to the legislative program as compared with the totality of Senate time spent is quite low—but normal; I stress, it is normal.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's because you haven't had your program ready.

—No. We have had legislation ready every day. This is the normal process. I am not alleging filibustering or anything else. I am saying that this is the normal process in the Senate as weeks go by and more time is spent on legislation, rather than less, as we get further into the session.

PARA.TAB: I return to the central point: it is rather hard to debate a motion I have not got in front of me and of which I do not know the conditions. It was absolutely unnecessary to do it this way, unless the Greens were looking for a thrill kill. Was that the reason? Do they want the excitement of moving their contingent notice of motion by way of ambush? They can have their thrill; they have had their thrill. But that is not really a position they can argue in a principled way, having had ample opportunity yesterday and today to give a notice of motion so it could be considered at whips' meetings and knocked around.

Maybe they will get support, I do not know; I am not involved in that process, and I have not been involved in that process. Maybe they will; but they have not sought to go down that particular path, which is the normal path. They have sought, by way of ambush, to have a motion we do not have in front of us debated now, on Thursday morning. What is urgent? Why do we not move on to the legislative program today? The Greens can then give a notice of motion if this motion gets defeated and then they might have an opportunity to debate it on Monday. I really think this is an unwarranted ambush. It is a very difficult motion to debate in principle or anything else when it is not before us in a written form.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not support the suspension because the principal motion is not before us. I think it is in the terms that all bills that were not introduced in the last session of parliament cannot be dealt with in this session. An undertaking was given by the government that under normal circumstances that was how it intended to do business in this session, and it has not done that. It is not as if it is simply matters of urgency which the government has sought to bring on without their having been introduced in the previous session. It is simply a matter of convenience for the government to basically deal with the program as it has evolved according to its timetable—with a total disregard of the undertakings that were previously given to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: So I can understand the sentiment and the annoyance of the Greens that has led them to move this suspension, but that does not mean that this is the right way to deal with the matter. However, on a matter of principle, we will agree to deal in this session with bills which were not introduced in the last only if the government can make out a real and genuine case of urgency.

The sorts of circumstances we are talking about may relate to grants for the needy or whatever and the government's attempt to deal with the mass unemployment in this country. Obviously, if there are bills coming out in the government's program to address such matters, we will look sympathetically at a request to deal with them in this session. But where the government is just continuing in total disregard of the undertakings that were formerly given, we will not.

The opposition suggests that the parties sit down on Monday morning and look at the program. If agreement cannot be reached as to which bills will be and which bills will not be dealt with in this session, then we can debate this in a sensible way on Monday and we will see where the numbers lie in relation to any particular bill. I told you, Mr Acting Deputy President, where the opposition stands in principle on the substantive issue. That is the way we would approach discussions on Monday or in the debate that would subsequently ensue in this place.

However, I have to repeat what I said yesterday. The program in this session is a shambles. The government did not have its legislation ready, despite all the promises to the contrary. During the first half of the session the opposition was being requested to raise matters to fill in the day for the government. Now those opposite come here and say that they have insufficient time. The minority parties have been joining with the government to allow extensions of this sitting to enable the government's incompetent planning to, in effect, be implemented, which we say is a totally unsatisfactory way of doing business.

So we will be interested to see on Monday morning how the minority parties approach these bills that the government is introducing or seeking to debate in breach of its earlier agreement. Obviously, the Greens have said on the record today that they are prepared to vote against the debate of those matters and hold the government to its agreement. If that is so, I commend them for that. We have never had such an undertaking from the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—My experience with the Australian Democrats is that when the government says, `Jump,' the Democrats say, `How high?' That happens every time. The Democrats always jump to the government's request, and I have no doubt that it will happen again on Monday morning. We will see. The precedent is there. The Democrats agreed with the government to curtail the sittings of this session. The Democrats said there would be no more night sittings because it was unnecessary with proper planning, yet already in the last two weeks we have had to sit nights.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has given up its general business time. The opposition has given up its time to facilitate the government's program. The government abuses that facility and the Australian Democrats come in and support it. That is where things lie at the moment. So we will be interested in the debate that takes place on Monday morning and whether, in fact, for the first time this session the Australian Democrats will even attempt to keep this government honest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —A suggestion has been made here today that this particular motion is so difficult to understand that people cannot focus their minds on it. In fact, the motion is a very simple one and that is—
—It is when you read it; when you get given a copy!

—No. I listened. All it is doing is postponing those particular bills. That is all it is doing. It is true that I was not consulted about this before. I am not a member of the Greens Party. I actually heard about it five or 10 minutes before it was going to be moved—
—Why the ambush? Why not a notice of motion?

—It is not an ambush. That is the problem. Senator Ray owes it to this chamber to prove to us why these bills should be dealt with in a manner contrary to the undertaking given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans—I suppose `undertaking' is too strong a word. Why is it being done in a way not desired by the Leader of the Government? I quote what Senator Evans said on page 183 of the Senate Hansard of 18 August:

SPEECH.PARA: That process will always have exceptions built into it.
He was talking about the processes. He continued:

Finally, looking to the future and moving beyond this budget session, we are conscious of the need, if we possibly can, to do even better than this. We have decided in principle that in future we will introduce legislation—to the extent it proves possible; I have to add that qualification—on the basis of introduction in one sittings for debate in the next. I guess that that is the optimal position for everyone in this chamber.
Again, I repeat that that probably was not an undertaking; it was a desire. He continued:
It will give everyone . . . the opportunity in the parliamentary break to fully consider their position and take such advice as they want, research it, produce sensible responses and deal with it.

PARA.TAB: That process will always have some exceptions built into it.

SPEECH.PARA: He then states the exceptions:

Under the present budgetary process, obviously budget bills will always be an exception. However, that may not need to be the case under our proposed new system for dealing with budgets before the end of June. The precise implications of that for session times and sitting times have yet to be fully considered, so I cannot give any detailed description of what the process will be in that respect now. Obviously, it will make it potentially possible for that category of exceptions to be removed or modified.
Removed or modified—listen to that. He continued:
Equally, there will always have to be exceptions for urgent bills on unforeseen subjects.

So we are dealing with, as he says, what is potentially possible for the categories of exceptions to be removed or modified. We are dealing with a motion to suspend standing orders, but as I understand the substantive motion, it would be up to the government to bring us into its confidence as to which of those bills which have been introduced in this session, contrary to the optimal desire of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, fall into those categories of urgent bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —But we have knocked another 20 or 30 out already.

—The government should bring us into its confidence; that is all I am saying. This gives the government an opportunity to do so. Whether it does it now or at some other time, it ought to be done on a regular basis so that it openly gives us its reasons for doing that and, through us, the public can be given the reasons. The legislation that we pass affects the public. Surely, they have got a right to chew over the ramifications of the legislation.

—It is quite clear what the reasons are for the urgency of this motion. The reasons are very clear from today's Notice Paper—seven new bills which were introduced in this session and not in the previous session. The reason for the urgency is that if we do not speak now, the roller-coaster goes along and we basically get bulldozed. To say that this can be done through the normal system obviously does not indicate any understanding of the way things work at a five-minute whips' meeting. If one is given a list of bills at a whips' meeting, the ability to argue in depth as to why a bill is urgent is not available. It is not an accountable method under which governments can operate or deal with the parliamentary and Senate process.

PARA.TAB: In fact, this has not come out of the blue. The Greens have been expressing these concerns to the government for months. We were not given reasons for the bills being introduced. We asked for reasons and they were not given to us until we asked. Therefore, even the process which was foreshadowed, promised or mentioned by Senator Evans did not happen until it was forced. Therefore, without this kind of debate today, how could we have thought that there would be any action at all to deal with the real concerns about proper notice, proper consultation and proper consideration of important matters that get lumped into the process at this time of the year?

Once the reasons were given, there was no effort by the government to then go to the various parties, let alone in the Senate chamber, to find out whether those reasons were acceptable reasons for the urgency. Senator Chamarette's motion mentions the seven new bills for today. Under this Senate process, if this motion were to go through, it would be perfectly possible for the government to bring its reasoned arguments to the Senate as to why any particular bill on that list should not be recommitted to this session. That gives the proper scrutiny process.

If there is a general method of operating that the urgency of that particular bill has to be proven and argued to the Senate, at least it is out in the open and at least all parties have the opportunity to participate. That is the urgency of it. The urgency is that in the morning or at the whips' meeting we get a list of bills and the ability to properly scrutinise the reasons for dealing with that at the time is not there, and that is not the correct way in which parliamentary scrutiny should be taking place, considering the undertakings that were given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). The decision to take some action in relation to this was perhaps brought on by the very fact that today's Notice Paper has seven bills on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you decide to move this?

—When did the government decide to put seven new bills on this paper, and when did it decide not to tell the people in this place that it was putting them on? When did it ask anybody whether this was acceptable?

—by leave—I simply want to answer the questions that Senator Ray put and, I believe, quite appropriately. I acknowledge that there may have been better ways to have raised this matter. Nevertheless, I regret that it is not being supported by the Senate because it will not give adequate time to debate the actual motion. But I do not believe that making arrangements on a party basis on a Monday morning and on a numbers basis, as Senator Hill said, is an adequate way to determine the program.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ray asked why there was an ambush and not a notice of motion. I will tell him. He should ask himself what has happened to the program this morning. First of all, we were told we were to debate the Higher Education Funding Legislation Amendment Bill. We have no objections to that bill being debated today. The next thing we were told is that we were doing the ATSIC land fund bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you object to that?

—No, I do not have any objection to that; that was introduced last session. The other thing was that I did not know in what order these bills were planned to be debated. The only definite order I knew was that the lunchtime bills were all set in their order. That was fine, except that they included two bills that had been introduced in the last session. So I had a choice between entering the time that has been set aside for so-called non-controversial legislation and calling a division on whether that was an appropriate time for new bills that had not been introduced in the last session to be done, thereby interrupting lunchtime, or bringing it on before any of the bills came on.

PARA.TAB: The reason why it was not able to be put in a notice form is that I consider that every bill has a validity of its own and that the government has a legitimate and accepted right to say to the Senate why the bill is urgent enough to be debated without conforming to the commitment given to the Senate by Senator Gareth Evans about bills being introduced one session and debated the next session. I think it is an appropriate right of government to say that, but I also think it is a right of the Senate to hear that in the chamber and to decide in the chamber whether it is acceptable to it or not and to vote bill by bill.

Putting a motion of a general nature did not serve the purpose. I believe that negotiations behind the scenes are done on the basis of numbers rather than on the content of the bills. The validity of the government's reasons for departing from procedure is worthy of consideration in the chamber and should not be done behind the scenes. That is why I sought to do this. There is no other way of challenging bills as they come up without even further disruption to the process of the Senate.

I assure Senator Ray that the Greens have no desire to debate any bills that have been introduced only in this session, with the government giving the Senate no opportunity to consider them. In a notice of motion I requested that the reasons for the practice be tabled. They were tabled, and I appreciate that, but there was no opportunity given for the Senate to decide whether those reasons were legitimate. I believe that the Senate has a legitimate decision making power. It should not be having to deal with bills on a day-by-day basis.

As Senator Ray knows, I had to do a fair bit of research to find out when each of these bills was introduced and whether we had been given any reasons for their introduction. If we do not debate the motion today and we deal with bills that have been introduced only in this session, that makes it very difficult for the Greens to argue, as we strongly believe, that this should not be happening. We will raise this matter time and time again if the government does not face its responsibility to organise the program in such a way that only urgent bills—if the reasons for them are publicly available and agreed to—go through the Senate in the last 12 sitting days that we have left in parliament this year. I thank the Senate and Senator Ray for giving me leave to reply to some of the concerns that were raised in this debate.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 9 November.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—The committee is considering the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994 and amendment M9 moved by Senator Chamarette on behalf of the Greens WA to clause 3. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on the public record that at the time we adjourned this debate last night I was very distressed by the comments that were coming from the government and the Australian Democrats imparting personal characteristics to this motion. I want to reiterate that the Greens moved this amendment on the basis of principle. It was quite rightly pointed out by the opposition that to have an amendment that says that all the commissioners be elected commissioners is a statement of principle. It does not prevent anyone who has been an appointed commissioner from becoming a member of the board. It simply ensures that the principle of election is maintained in the legislation on an ongoing basis.

PARA.TAB: I ask those people who made those comments on the basis of some kind of friendship with the only appointed commissioner, David Ross, whether they were really acting in his best interests by making those comments on the public record. There is nothing personal in this amendment and I distance myself from any of the aspersions and allegations that were made either by Senator Evans or Senator Kernot when they implied that this was somehow—

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not make any comment about Commissioner Ross in person.

—If Senator Kernot did not, I apologise. I will consult the Hansard, because I know it was said as an interjection. That is why I have remembered it. I want it to be quite clearly put on the public record that the Greens (WA) support David Ross's right to be on that board. This amendment is in no way designed to exclude him or anybody else. It is designed to maintain the principle of election. As the amendment will not be supported, I think it is utterly regrettable that those people whom I have mentioned—and if Senator Kernot is not one, I take it back—have claimed that this amendment is designed to attack any single person. They are not acting in the best interests of that person, and they are certainly not acting in the spirit and principle—
—Senator Evans did.

—I know Senator Evans did. People who made this claim are not acting in the principle of what I believe the debate should be in the Senate, and they are certainly acting against the spirit of the amendment that the Greens are placing before the Senate. I think the comments would have been far better left unsaid. All I can say before I finally put my amendment is that I distance myself totally from those comments.

—I, too, was concerned at the reference made last night by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). I will leave it at that. He is not here to defend his statement. No doubt he might wish to do so at some stage. I thought his statement was uncalled for.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, I am not convinced of the merits of this amendment. I have listened carefully to what was said. An opposition senator commented last night that it does not matter whether or not this amendment goes through; it will not affect the personalities appointed to the ILC. I am not convinced by the arguments that have been put forward that the legislation needs to specify `elected commissioners' rather than just `commissioners'. People are commissioners; if they are commissioners, they are commissioners. As has been said, each person who is a commissioner will be elected anyhow at the next election, which I think is in 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, July.
—So this amendment will have no force one way or the other at that time. I am not convinced to the extent of voting for this amendment.

—I wish to respond briefly to Senator Harradine. It may be the case that the commissioners will be elected in 1996 but, when this bill becomes law, it will talk about the establishment of the board. Therefore, the sensible principle that Senator Chamarette's amendment encapsulates is that it is better that people are elected and, to that effect, responsive to their fellows.

PARA.TAB: The argument that the commissioners will be elected in 1996—just as President Clinton will try to get re-elected in 1996 as well—is important now. It will be less important in 1996. The fact is that we are establishing a board that will hold office for four or five years. So the principle is important now. It will be less important in the future. It is an important distinction, and the coalition will support it. It is not a life and death amendment, but I think it is a sensible and important principle.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (36)Clause 3, page 16, lines 15 to 19, omit proposed subsection (5), substitute the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: " `(5) In making appointments to the Indigenous Land Corporation Board, the Minister must have regard to the need to ensure the broadest possible representation of those Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to whom this Part is directed.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is the second part of the plank that seeks to ensure that the board is well structured. It seeks to ensure that in the appointments to the Indigenous Land Corporation Board `the Minister must have regard to the need to ensure the broadest possible representation of those Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders' that this bill would affect.

PARA.TAB: I think it is a sensible principle that envisages a broad representation across the regions and states, and from the various Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. It gives a broad direction to the minister. We do not think it is an onerous requirement that he have regard to ensuring there is broad representation. It simply seeks to ensure that the board is not representative of a small set of interests and that it does reflect the hopes, aspirations and needs of people from across Australia. For that reason it is worthy of support. I commend it to the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Campbell has provided the precise reason why the government will not be supporting this amendment. Senator Campbell's reference to the board not being representative of small sets of interests is a fascinating point to make in support of this amendment. ATSIC is the primary source of policy advice to the government on Aboriginal affairs and ATSIC is the primary deliverer of the implementation of that policy advice in the administration of programs for the benefit of Aboriginal people. Therefore, it is appropriate for ATSIC to be appropriately represented on this board. The effect of the opposition amendment is to decrease that representation. I reiterate that ATSIC is not only the government's primary source of policy advice but also the primary administrator of the delivery of that policy and the implementation of programs. We are absolutely opposed to this attempt by the opposition to dilute its representation.

—I think Senator Collins has said it all. The government would like to see the ILC operate as a mirror to ATSIC. What this Indigenous Land Corporation would end up being is an alter ego of ATSIC. That is a recipe for disaster because we have seen in recent times how the Aboriginal community has had varied opinions. I recall the evidence of Aden Ridgeway, who appeared before the Senate finance and public administration committee, when he said, `Of course there are going to be differences in views within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. It is only natural.' It is the same in the wider community. Therefore, we should not just accept the bureaucratic body which supposedly represents that community as being the be all and end all. All wisdom does not reside in ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: So what we are saying is that there are mechanisms in the appointment of the board to have an ATSIC commissioner on the board. That is mandatory. It is in the bill. But there should be other areas of the community from which the government can draw for appointments to this board. There is absolutely nothing wrong in stating that the minister needs to ensure the broadest possible representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people on this board. I would have thought that it stood to reason—and that any objective viewer would agree—that we should try to get the broadest possible representation.

We would not just go to ATSIC and say, `You're our chief implementer of policy. You're it. You're on the board, and that's it.' One would rue the day that such an approach was taken because ATSIC would not be totally representative of the Aboriginal community. The government, although elected—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's democratically elected.
—The government is democratically elected, but that does not necessarily mean the whole country voted for it.
—It's the best system we've got.

—What we have in this system—in the committees, in the various functions of parliament and in the Senate—is a reflection of that because we have participation by opposition members. What we are saying here is that we cannot say that ATSIC is the total umbrella for the Aboriginal community. We should try to have the broadest possible representation. There can be absolutely no harm in that directive. I fail to see how anyone could say that there is an ulterior motive or some mischief afoot because, quite frankly, people who say that have an agenda of their own.

PARA.TAB: I said earlier that Senator Collins has said it all: the government would like the ILC simply to be a mirror of ATSIC. That is not in the best interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. What is in the best interests of any community, including the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, is having the broadest possible representation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, I would like to put a few points to Senator Ellison with respect to the argument he has just mounted. The one fundamental thing we have to acknowledge about ATSIC is that its members are elected in the same way as we are elected. Its members do not form a monolithic view. There are differences of opinion. There is a diversity of representation in ATSIC at the moment, as Senator Ellison saw from the press conference that was held yesterday.I think he has an outdated view about the way ATSIC works and the people who are currently elected to it. The fact of the matter is that people from other Aboriginal organisations who had previously disapproved of the structure of ATSIC have chosen to seek election and have been elected to it. So it has a broad representation at the moment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ellison says that there are no opposition members on it. There are people who have different points of view. There is no formalised opposition in the way there is in this place, but there are people who have different points of view.

TALK.START.PARA: —They had a look at you mob and decided not to do it.
—I take it that Senator Collins is referring to Senator Kernot.
—I did not actually hear what he said.
—Senator Kernot is not part of the official opposition in this chamber.
—No, she is part of the official government.
—I cannot make up my own mind—is that the inference?
—No; I take it back.
—I have had a lot of dealings in Aboriginal issues for many years. I say to Senator Campbell that, on this one, I feel totally confident that I know what I am talking about.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Collins said that ATSIC gives policy advice to government, in no way can we extend that to say, `Therefore, the ILC will be a mirror image of ATSIC.' It gives policy advice. ATSIC, through its regional council structure—imperfect or perfect, depending on the way in which some of the councils work at the moment—has an opportunity to canvass a broad range of views from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and therefore to mirror these views in policy advice to government. I can say that it is very judicious in doing that. It always makes sure that, where there is a difference of opinion amongst its commissioners, that is recorded and that is passed on.

Senator Ellison is right in commenting that there is nothing wrong with saying that there should be the broadest representation on the board, but I just do not like the arguments he used to prove that. I do not think we should all fear the way in which ATSIC is involved as the primary, but not the only, organised representative view of Aboriginal people in this country.

I repeat to Senator Ellison that it is probably more representative than ever because of the way in which Aboriginal people have chosen to be more actively involved in it. It is only a few years old. Senator Ellison made the point that Aden Ridgeway said that it was not monolithic. I have made that point many times. I do not think it logically follows that, because ATSIC has a role in this, it will not be broadly representative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens will be supporting this amendment. We would have preferred ours, but this is definitely a fall-back position. I would like to say two things. There is a rationale for saying that there should be one commissioner from ATSIC rather than two when we consider that there are only seven members of the board in total and that possibly only five of those will be Aboriginal people. Under this arrangement we would have two out of the five members who are already represented within the ATSIC structure and representing the views of ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: It is important to emphasise the difference between the ILC and ATSIC, even though both in their own way—but perhaps the ILC more so—are government appointed boards and de facto government bureaucracies. Nevertheless, because of the structure that we have seen emerging in this bill, this is yet another structure that is being created to conform to our white cultural understanding of a bureaucracy that distributes limited resources.

It is appropriate that there be only one commissioner, to emphasise the difference between the ILC and ATSIC. The committee will note that we are not suggesting that there be no representation from ATSIC; it is perfectly appropriate that ATSIC should be represented because the ways in which ATSIC operates are of extreme relevance to the IlC, and vice versa.

Senator Kernot said that two representatives from ATSIC would ensure that different points of view were represented. I have only to look at the position of Senator Margetts and myself to admit that we cannot possibly represent accurately the views of the Greens (WA) just in two ways. If we presented our own view in the chamber all the time—

TALK.START.PARA: —All the ATSIC commissioners should be on it.

—No, there is another alternative, Senator Kernot, and that is that both of us have a responsibility to reflect the views of everybody else. One commissioner would have no less capacity to consult all the other commissioners before coming to a decision. One commissioner has no less capacity to report to the ILC board what all the other ATSIC commissioners feel—rather than simply a personal view or two personal views. Two people might be able to do it as well, but one person can do it just as well as two can. When I was here previously, when Senator Margetts was here, and when Senator Vallentine was here before that, we had a responsibility to glean the views of all the people to whom we felt we were accountable when we voted or spoke in this chamber. When there are two of us we both do that. It does not mean that we both would not, but it defeats Senator Kernot's argument that having two people is a mechanism for ensuring that two points of view are presented. One person, with the right attitudes towards representation of all views on that board, has that capacity. There is a trust in that person to do so.
—But so do two people.

—Two people can do it as well, but that defeats the other point I am making, which concerns the separation between the ATSIC and the ILC structures and the appropriateness of consultations such that one commissioner is on the board, but the inappropriateness of two out of five Aboriginal commissioners on the board representing ATSIC. The government has been making threats through the media that, if we do not comply with what the government wants in this legislation, it will give it all to ATSIC. That is fine, but this threat has led to some considerable concern in the Aboriginal community, which I am sure the government was well aware of before it made the threat.
—They are concerned about what you are doing, too, Senator Chamarette.

—That is right; they are. I know. No doubt that is why the government devised the bill such that the ILC was independent of either ATSIC or land councils—that it was a new board. That is a legitimate request. It is therefore quite legitimate to say that one commissioner from ATSIC is sufficient to be represented on that board, which is why we support the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will simply make two quick points in response to what I have just heard. First of all, I am profoundly disappointed that the Greens are supporting this amendment. What Senator Ellison delivered was a bit rich. Senator Kernot made these points very succinctly, but I want to reiterate them. Senator Ellison said that one of the reasons why the opposition has proposed this amendment is that `ATSIC does not properly represent all of the Aboriginal people of Australia'. The coalition and the Greens, in supporting this, have a hide to keep chucking around the word `patronising' in respect of the government, because one cannot get much more patronising than what they have said.

PARA.TAB: ATSIC is a body which is elected nationally in national elections which are funded to be run nationally. I know of the intense interest among Aboriginal people in participating in those ATSIC elections—interest which is growing, I might add, from election to election. Every Aboriginal person in Australia is entitled to nominate and stand for office and to cast a vote in those elections—in other words, it is precisely the same basis on which this parliament is elected. There is no better system available in this country. Having provided that democratic process and a democratic method of electing that body—as Senator Kernot said, rightly or wrongly, depending on which region elects whom—Senator Ellison is patronising enough to assert in here, on behalf of the opposition, that this body does not properly represent the Aboriginal people of Australia.

The second and final point I would like to make, and it should be an obvious one, is that there is an absolutely crucial need—considering the necessary interlinking of the job that the ILC will do and the programs that are delivered by ATSIC—for the ILC and ATSIC to be inextricably linked. One of the fundamental reasons for the level of ATSIC representation on this body, which was carefully considered by the government, is the essential link that has to exist between the ILC and ATSIC so that these programs can be delivered effectively on behalf of the Aboriginal people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the points clearly missed by the minister is that what this amendment seeks to do is make the ILC broadly representative of the views, hopes an aspirations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people across Australia.
—Maybe we should have them elected.
—Oh, yes!

—Maybe the minister should move an amendment. The minister says that he is surprised that the Greens are supporting this amendment. He should not be surprised, because the Greens have an identical amendment in N3. Perhaps he is surprised that they are moving an identical amendment; he certainly should not be surprised that they are supporting ours.
—I am simply surprised in terms of where they say their philosophy is coming from, and their objection to being patronising.

—Senator Collins clearly understands his well thought out, crystal clear, visionary philosophy that he seems to live by. He would understands it very well. Other people would probably have trouble understanding it.

PARA.TAB: The realities are that, firstly, this legislation is part of the ATSIC bill. That is quite obvious. Secondly, in the appointment of all of the directors, the commission has a power that no other organisation in the country has. The part of clause 3 of the bill that the Greens unsuccessfully sought to amend last night provides that before a person can be appointed as a director, the minister must consult with the commission.
