He does not have to consult with anybody else. He does not have to consult with any other Aboriginal group or any other Aboriginal person. He does not have to consult with anybody, except with the Minister for Finance, which the Greens do not like. Before appointing a director, he must consult with the commission.

It is possible under this scheme for all of the directors to be commissioners of ATSIC. We are not saying that they cannot be. After consultation with the minister and even under the terms of our amendment, which is that the board should be broadly representative of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, it is quite possible that every single director of the ILC is an ATSIC commissioner.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you would say that that is not broadly representative.
—No, I would not, actually. I will take my argument to its logical conclusion.
—Illogical!
—No. Senator Collins has just properly argued that ATSIC has elections. We know from amendments to the ATSIC—
—Senator Ellison said it was not representative.

—Senator Ellison is also right. It is actually possible for two people to be right and look like they are disagreeing. Senator Ellison said that ATSIC does not represent all the views. We know that ATSIC is representative. As Senator Collins said, ATSIC faces elections. Quite properly, he also said that there is more and more interest in ATSIC elections. All of us think that is a very good thing—the more democratic involvement the better the institution will be. The coalition is committed to making sure that ATSIC is better than it has been in the past. We see improvements there. People like Senator Panizza would like to see more improvement but ATSIC seems to be going in the right direction.
—You did something last night which wouldn't support that.

—We can talk about that afterwards. I will try to get to my argument. The reality is that Senator Collins is right when he says that the ATSIC commissioners are broadly representative because they are all elected by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who all have the right to vote for them. So, under the terms of our amendment No. 36, they can be considered as meeting the qualification for broad representation.

PARA.TAB: This amendment does not say that there can be only one commissioner. It says that, as of right, there should be one commissioner and that all of the other commissioners should be broadly representative. Frankly, it is conceivable that every single board member of the ILC could be a commissioner. All we are enshrining is a very fine principle. It is not onerous to the extent that it requires the minister, as clause 3 of the bill does, to consult the commission in relation to the appointments. Clause 3 says he must consult the commission in relation to the appointment of the directors. So a name is put up—Senator Collins might be put up when he retires from here—and the commission has to be consulted. `Would former Minister Bob Collins be a good director of the ILC board?' Senator Collins would probably say, `No, I don't want the job because I'm sick of sitting on Ansett aeroplanes all my life.'

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I would say I didn't want the job because I think an Aboriginal person should do it.

—That is good. The reality is that the commission must be consulted, and the commission may well have a strong view about who is appointed to the board, and we can think of some names about which the commission would have a strong view. But that is the reality. No other body has that power. However, nothing stops the minister appointing every single director of the ILC board from among commissioners of ATSIC. We are saying that, sure, this bill says that one of the directors will be an ATSIC commissioner and that the board should be broadly representative. It is very similar to the clause where we talked about consultation with traditional owners.

PARA.TAB: I would love it if the media were able to report some of the incredible things that have been said in this chamber in the last couple of days. We had the minister saying, `You shouldn't have to consult with the traditional owners before you buy land.' I would love to be able to send that quote out to every Aboriginal person in Western Australia—that Senator Gareth Evans does not want the ILC to consult with traditional owners before it goes to buy land. That is a phenomenal statement.

Today we have a minister who is saying that when making appointments to the ILC board the minister responsible should not have to have regard to ensuring the broadest possible representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. That is phenomenal. I would love it if the media were able to write a little feature piece on the incredible hypocrisy of this government when it comes to Aboriginal affairs saying, `We are not going to consult traditional owners, and we don't want broad representation of ATSIC people on the board.' I would love a feature piece to be written about the hypocrisy that has come out of the mouths of these two ministers. I find it quite incredible that the government could oppose this amendment. I say again: I commend this motion to the committee. I will be appalled if it is opposed by anybody.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say one thing in response. I just want to build on a couple of facts. ATSIC has an important land acquisition and management component. I think it is very important and appropriate to have processes by which two members of ATSIC are on this board to make sure that the maximum information is passed on because under ATSIC different commissioners have different portfolios. Both the chair and deputy chair of ATSIC are on the council for reconciliation. We hear from both of them because we need to know about their perspective on the portfolio responsibilities they have.

PARA.TAB: In terms of land acquisition and land management, I think it is really important that the chair and an ATSIC commissioner be there to make sure of what we need to know to avoid duplication and to have sensible management of this regional and national strategy. It is possible. I think that the sharing, the fact that they are both there to say, `This is what ATSIC is doing; this is my area of responsibility and this is your area of responsibility,' means that we have an opportunity to make sure that the ILC and the ATSIC nexus works properly.

It would be like sending one member of the Liberal Party to speak on behalf of all members of the Liberal Party or all members of the coalition on constitutional reform. We have a coalition: a National Party and a Liberal Party. There are two points of view; two areas of responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are more than two points of view.

—All right. There are more than two points of view. I happily acknowledge that interjection, but I think it is appropriate that more than one person from ATSIC be represented because the nexus really is important.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply say to the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Kernot, and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy,

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins, that if they think the ATSIC commissioners are so broadly representative of the Aboriginal community—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are.
—If they are, what is the harm of agreeing to this amendment because naturally they will fit the test, will they not?
—They should be there in their own right.

—Of course they will. No, Senator Kernot cannot have it two ways. Senator Kernot cannot say they are broadly representative and when we say there must be a test that the board must be as broadly representative as possible then Senator Kernot says, `Oh, no, we don't want that wording because these people are broadly representative anyway.' I then say, `Well, they should fit the test,' and then she is worried they will not.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins was extolling the virtues of ATSIC and started this whole line of debate on ATSIC. I am quite content to leave it as the amendment is stated; that is, there must be a need to ensure the broadest possible representation and if they happen to be ATSIC commissioners, so much to the good. If not, so much to the good, as long as they are broadly the most representative group we can get. That is all we are saying; nothing more, nothing less. It is Senator Collins who has this phobia about ATSIC and brought it into the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the proposal for the reasons that I think have been adequately advanced in this committee of the whole. Unless I am missing something, I really cannot see that there is other than logic in the proposition that has been put forward.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it might be appropriate now to go back to the national strategy, which we put off yesterday. We have now distilled our respective positions, and I think that would take us back to opposition amendment No. 18 on the running sheet. We had reached opposition amendment No. 17, which was lost. I realise that opposition amendment No. 18 really runs in tandem with some amendments circulated by the Greens—that is, their J series of amendments, J1A to J8. It might be expedient if Senator Chamarette were to move her new J series of amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood we would deal with the J series of our amendments after we had completed dealing with our M series. I do not mind going through the J series now, but there are a few amendments in the M series which we could probably deal with very quickly.
—It would be cleaner if we did it that way.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: M4.Clause 3, page 17, proposed subsection 192B(2), line 25, omit "Minister's written approval", substitute "written agreement of the Indigenous Land Corporation Board".
M5.Clause 3, page 17, proposed subsection 192C(2), line 31, omit "Minister", substitute "Indigenous Land Corporation Board".
M6.Clause 3, page 17, proposed subsection 192C(3), line 35, omit "Minister", substitute "Indigenous Land Corporation Board".
M7.Clause 3, page 18, proposed subsection 192D(3), line 13, omit "Minister", substitute "Indigenous Land Corporation Board".
M8.Clause 3, page 20, proposed paragraph 192H(3)(b), line 24, omit "Minister's approval", substitute "agreement of the Indigenous Land Corporation Board".

This completes the Greens' series of amendments in relation to what we believe is the principle of independence of the ILC from the government. We have already dealt with—and the Greens have lost—three of those amendments. But the remaining amendments address the issue of whether the ILC board should approve the paid employment of outside duties for directors, rather than the minister, as is in the bill.

PARA.TAB: We want the ILC board to be able to approve leave of absence for directors, rather than the minister, and we want the ILC board to have power to delegate power to a chairperson to approve a leave of absence for directors, rather than the minister. We would like the ILC board to be able to determine the terms and conditions of leave for the chairperson and to approve paid employment of outside duties for the chairperson, rather than the minister.

They are all part of the same principle, which is that if we are setting up an independent board that is not an extension of the minister's office or of the government—and I do not know how effectively we are doing that—a consequent requirement should be that the ILC board is given the autonomy at least to determine the terms and conditions of its members in regard to duties and leave of absence.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As evidence of the abundant goodwill that exists on the government side in respect of seeing this matter expedited so that we can get out of here before we qualify for our old-age pensions, the government is prepared to accept these amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Democrats support the amendments—not because I want to get out of here but simply because I think it is the right thing to do.

—The coalition thinks it is the right thing to do. Mind you, when the minister says he thinks it is the right thing to do, we might have to reconsider our position! We think they are sensible amendments and we support them.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: J1AClause 3, page 10, proposed subsection 191N(1), lines 23, omit "191N.(1)", substitute "191P.(1)".
J2AClause 3, page 10, after proposed subsection 191N(1), insert the following subsections:

PARA.EMPHASIS: National indigenous land strategy to be based on regional strategies

SPEECH.PARA: " `(1A) The national indigenous land strategy must be based on, derived from and reflect the regional indigenous land strategies provided for under section 191P.'.".

PARA.EMPHASIS: National strategy to be amended if regional strategy varies

SPEECH.PARA: " `(1B) Where, as a result of a review under subsection 191P(7), a regional indigenous land strategy is varied, the national indigenous land strategy must be varied accordingly so that it is based on, derived from and reflects the regional indigenous land strategies. . .'".
J3AClause 3, page 10 and 11, proposed subsection 191N(3), line 34 (page 10) to line 4 (page 11), , omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Consultation on national indigenous land strategy

SPEECH.PARA: " `(3) In performing functions under this section, the Indigenous Land Corporation Board:
(a)must consult as widely as possible with representatives of those Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to whom this Part is directed; and
(b)must consult with the Commission; and
(c)may consult such other persons and bodies as the Board considers appropriate.".
J4AClause 3, page 11, proposed subsection 191N(6), lines 11 to 13, substitute the following subsection:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Copy to be given to Minister

SPEECH.PARA: " `(6) The Indigenous Land Corporation Board must give a copy of the national indigenous land strategy and a copy of any changes it has made to the national indigenous land strategy to the Minister within 2 months of the Board agreeing to the strategy or change.".
J5AClause 3, page 11, proposed subsection 191P(1), line 17, omit "191P.(1)", substitute "191N.(1)".
J6Clause 3, page 11, after proposed subsection 191P(4), insert the following subsection:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Moneys not to be distributed until regional strategy prepared

SPEECH.PARA: " `(4A) The Indigenous Land Corporation must ensure that no moneys are distributed from the fund for the performance of the Corporation's functions in a region until the regional land strategy for that region has been prepared.".
J7 Clause 3, page 12, proposed paragraphs 191P(5)(a) and (b), lines 4 to 7, omit the paragraphs, substitute the following paragraphs:

"(a)must consult, as far as is practicable, with Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations, Aboriginal persons, Torres Strait Islanders and trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts in the regional area; and
(b)must, if any part of the region is included in the regional area, consult the Regional Council for the region; and

(c)must consult with the State or Territory Government or Governments relevant to each region so as to ensure that regional indigenous land strategies complement existing State, Territory or regional land acquisition and management programs for Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.".
J8Clause 3, page 12, proposed section 191Q, lines 17 to 22, omit the section, substitute the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Indigenous Land Corporation to base land acquisition and land management decisions on the regional and national strategies

SPEECH.PARA: " `191Q. Decisions taken by the Indigenous Land Corporation in relation to its land acquisition functions and its land management functions must be based on:
(a)each relevant regional indigenous land strategy; and
(b)the national indigenous land strategy.".

I think I shocked Senator Evans when I referred to the government's amendments and the problems that the Greens have regarding the relationship between a national strategy and a regional strategy. We believe the regional strategy needs to be reflected within the national strategy. His solution was to remove the national strategy from any mention in the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is your solution. You didn't actually ask.

—Senator Evans did not actually ask the Greens whether they thought that was the solution to the dilemma. He decided and circulated amendments, and it is quite true that he then presumed that was very satisfactory to the Greens. As he did not consult us or the opposition, it remains for us to present amendments that we believe more satisfactorily address the dilemma.

PARA.TAB: The dilemma is this: in the bill as presented by the government the ILC board has the responsibility for developing a national indigenous land strategy and also a regional strategy. The bill does not actually spell out any relationship between the two; that goes along with the government's feeling that it should have maximum flexibility. However, our amendments are not necessarily about making the board more flexible and more open-ended in its powers—we see it essentially as a government appointed board, which it is—but about ensuring the accountability of the board to the wider Aboriginal community and on a regional basis.

As a consequence of that, we have proposed some new clauses—I apologise for the confusion this causes—called J1A, J2A, J3A, J4A, J5A, J6, J7 and J8. The first five replace the Greens' previous J series and are a merger with the opposition amendments in relation to this matter. I think the opposition has agreed to withdraw its amendments and vote on these.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are an amalgamation, I understand.

—They are an amalgamation, which does not, I might add, commit the opposition to having to support them totally. But we have agreed to move them as an amalgamation of the two to reduce the confusion over the issue in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: If people would like a bit more discussion on it, I will simply state what I believe the intention of these amendments is and then we can move to discussion of that. I think perhaps the most important one to raise here is J2A, where it basically says that the national indigenous land strategy is to be based on regional strategies. We believe it should be derived from and reflect the regional indigenous land strategies provided for under section 191N. Then we have a second clause that says that the national strategy should be amended. If the regional strategy varies from time to time, the national strategy should be varied accordingly so that it continues to be based on, derived from and reflect the regional indigenous land strategies.

To ensure that those regional strategies are developed in a way that gives consideration to the wider benefits of Aboriginal people throughout Australia, the J3A amendment covers the functions of the ILC in relation to that. The first one states that it should consult as widely as possible with representatives of those Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to whom the part is directed—presumably, every Aboriginal community in Australia which is in some way dispossessed. As every Aboriginal person is dispossessed—there is no disagreement on that—it means as wide a consultation as possible. It also states that the ILC must consult with the commission and that it may consult such other persons and bodies as the board considers appropriate.

So it is not excluding a consultation with ATSIC, but is ensuring that regional strategies are developed regionally independent of any other existing organisations or structures that exist. It does not mean that those structures cannot be adopted as regional structures; it just means that there is no presupposition that that is the basis of regional consultation. It is about adopting a regional strategy.

The clauses that go on from that refer simply to a copy of those strategies being made available to the minister within two months of the board agreeing to them and that moneys are not to be distributed until the regional strategy is prepared. I think the reason for that is straightforward. Many people around Australia will feel that if a proper consultation process is not developed for this ILC land fund allocation, those who will be consulted last will have the last attempt at gaining any money from what we know to be a very diminishing fund. Therefore, we feel that the money should not be distributed until the regional strategy has been prepared by the board. The other amendments deal simply with consultation processes.

Finally, the reason why we could not agree with Senator Evans's solution was that it is not sensible just to say it can be on a regional strategy. It is a reasonable request that a board would have some kind of national strategy either explicitly stated or implicitly operating. It is our position that it is better to have it explicitly stated because, as Senator Evans pointed out, then it can be found to relate to the regional strategies, and if it does not, that can be challenged. It is an accountability measure back to the Aboriginal community which is supposed to be the beneficiary of this fund.

We feel it is inappropriate to strike out `national strategy.' We want a national strategy. We think that that national strategy's priorities should be set from the grassroots, from the regional strategies. We want it made explicit in this legislation so that those two mentions of `national' and `regional' do not give an implicit approval that a national strategy should be set and then regional people consulted about where they fit into it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be strongly opposing these amendments. I have a strong personal view about the actual effect on the ground of these amendments and how they will actually work in practice. I have got not the slightest doubt from my experience with the operation of Aboriginal organisations going back a very long time, that these amendments will be absolutely counterproductive. Strategies for different regions inevitably will reflect different aims. The national strategy cannot be based on all of them and still remain coherent and meaningful.

PARA.TAB: The government actually saw the point that the Greens were making and wanted to respond to it in an effective way. We saw the difficulty that may arise out of having two different but concurrent strategies that may be inconsistent. I wish to clarify the public record at this point, because I had a discussion about this last night with Senator Evans. I hope that Senator Chamarette, when she said that Senator Evans did not consult the Greens on this and just sprung it on them, was referring to the actual draft of the final amendment. Senator Evans told me explicitly last night that not only had he discussed this with Senator Chamarette, but he had done so in the presence of her advisers—good old Cathcart, who I know, and lawyers—and had proposed a solution to this problem having seen the merit of what Senator Chamarette was raising and, to quote Senator Evans, `The Greens had agreed with the concept.' That is why we went off and drafted the amendments.

I want to make that absolutely clear. This is not something in terms of its philosophical base that has been sprung on the Greens. I do want to correct that. Senator Chamarette may have been referring to the actual drafted amendment. I am glad she has nodded and confirmed that. Senator Evans did say to me last night that the very reason we drafted these amendments was because he felt, after that discussion, that he had the Greens support for it.

The government was proposing, in the amendment that we have circulated, to go one step further and remove the explicit requirement in the legislation to have a national strategy. We want these organisations to be regionally based for the simple reason that we do know that the needs and requirements differ so widely across Australia from region to region. Of course the organisation, by necessary inference, would develop its national strategy simply by considering the regional strategies that come before it. That would be the actual effect of the government amendment.

The national strategy would be adopted, by necessity, through the organisation having regard to those regional strategies and developing a national strategy as a result. If that is not acceptable, the simplest way for us to proceed here today in expediting the passage of the bill, if there is going to be support for this, would be to withdraw the government amendment, and I am happy to do that.

I assure Senator Chamarette that the government gave serious consideration to her concerns. This was a genuine attempt to respond to them. As I said, having thought about it again, we were prepared to go one step further and remove the requirement which, at the end of the day, may result in having two concurrent strategies that conflict.

The reality is—to use that much worn expression; it has been given a fair old hiding in this debate—that we could end up with strategies that conflict. If we are going to have a coherent national strategy, it is impossible to give consideration to every single regional strategy. For those reasons, we oppose these amendments. If debate indicates that the numbers are there to support them, I simply indicate as a courtesy to the committee that we will withdraw the government amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to that because I think it needs clarification. It is true that two of us had a meeting with the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and his advisers. When Senator Evans heard our concerns, he immediately saw the validity of them. He might have agreed with them himself and worked on a solution that he felt was adequate to address the concerns he perceived, but we said we would go away and think about it. We received a copy of the amendments, but at no point did Senator Evans come back and ask us if they had addressed our concerns adequately. That is the reason why our amendments quite clearly present a different option.

PARA.TAB: Maybe it illustrates that we have not had enough consultation on this matter. We certainly do not believe it is a deliberate attempt not to consult. At the moment, it is a process of communication by circulation of amendments. Senator Evans thought he understood our concerns and had the solution, which he drafted and circulated. Perhaps he should have noticed when we circulated different amendments that his amendments did not address all the concerns that we raised with him. He may have misunderstood.

Clearly, in our minds, we knew that we could not agree to something until we had seen the solution in writing. We expected to come back and have a discussion about it. We have repeatedly written letters to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Senator Evans asking for discussion before we have gone public on any of our concerns about this legislation. We felt that, if the government wanted the bill to go through, it would be sensible to discuss it with those people who supported the spirit in which it was being put forward.

This is an illustration of where there has been an attempt of goodwill on the part of the government to try to meet our concerns. The reality is that it has not met our concerns, and that is why we are presenting this different series of amendments. I thank the minister for withdrawing the government's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will explain the rationale for the coalition's view. That might help the Senate in deciding how to proceed. Certainly, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) had some discussions with Senator Alston about the concept of getting away from national strategies. I think Senator Alston indicated at that meeting that it might be an idea.
—He said it was a good idea.

—A good idea. One of the problems that the coalition has always had with the Greens' proposed amendment to the scheme and the thing that we do not like about it—I think it is the only amendment that we will vote against—is that it is a tail wagging the dog amendment, particularly J2A and the second part of it. We certainly want to see the first part of that separated from the second part and vote on those separately
—You mean J2A(1B).
—That is right. That is what I call the tail wagging the dog part of it. There are regional strategies and, if they are changed in some way, they would change the national strategy.
—You could be forever changing.

—That is right. We believe that the national strategy is a strategic plan, almost a corporate plan. I might just go to our initial concerns. Under the government's scheme, the bill requires that there be a national strategy. I would have thought that for an organisation like the ILC it is sensible to have some sort of strategy. There are competing demands on funds and just over $20 million that has to be expended in each of the first three years or, if our amendments are successful, $45 million.
—Every board has to—

—That is right. There are examples in Australia and around the world of similar organisations that have regional requirements and a national perspective. We can think of many such organisations. Just about any national company, be it a property company or a company that sells cars, hamburgers or anything nationally, has a national strategy, be it for marketing, administration or anything else. They would also have regional, state or local strategies. That is quite sensible. That is why the coalition has always thought that the concept of a national strategy is plain commonsense.

PARA.TAB: The amendments that we brought to the committee—specifically our amendment No. 18, which has now been incorporated in J3A; our amendment No. 19, which has become J4A, under the J series; and Nos 22, 23 and 24, which have become J6 and J7 respectively—are all to deal with the consultation and accountability involved in a national strategy.

The government's proposal in the legislation quite properly says that there should be a strategy—and it looks at the sorts of things the strategy should consider. We believe that the strategy should be a broad objectives document. It cannot fall into the trap that Senator Collins envisages of having to represent in finite detail the piece-by-piece minutiae of the regional strategies. We do, however, believe that it should reflect what is in the region. There cannot be a national strategy that does not take into account what is in the regions. That is why we agree with the Greens broader philosophy that the national strategy must reflect what is happening in the regions.

So to come back to the government's scheme, it creates the strategy and no-one other than the board knows what the strategy is. We believe there will be a hell of a lot of people in Australia, particularly Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders, who will be interested in what the strategy is.

The core of our proposals, in summary, is to ensure that the national strategy, to begin with, is the subject of consultation, not only with the commission but also with a broader group of people. We believe that at the regional level the strategy should also be the subject of consultation not just with the ATSIC regional office but also with other Aboriginal organisations in the regions. As we all know, there is a whole range of Aboriginal organisations which will have an interest in this. Although the act says that the ILC could consult with anyone it wants, we think that it would be entirely inappropriate for it not to be required to consult with Aboriginal organisations that do have an interest in that area.

Equally when it comes to regional strategies—and I am trying to cover the whole rationale behind the coalition's view of this series of amendments—we believe that, when going into a region and developing a land management program, it is quite stupid not to be talking to the state or local government that has jurisdiction in the area. In just about every state of Australia, as Senator Collins would know, state governments have programs which relate to providing land and support for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. I think it is plain commonsense that, before the ILC comes along to a region, it should at least make itself aware of the goals and plans the state government—and, where necessary, the local government, but particularly the state government—has in respect of that.

By way of example, it would be quite stupid of the ILC to go to a town like Broome, which is familiar to me, and not talk to the Court government about the plans that it has for in and around Broome. Senator Chamarette and I might have disagreements about what those plans are. Broadly speaking, the government has plans to improve Aboriginal access to and ownership of land around Broome—a town that has become famous around Australia for its fantastic Aboriginal culture, its crocodiles and its tourism potential. This is a classic case of where it would be absolutely mad for the ILC to enter into a regional strategy in the Kimberleys—a strategy which would include towns like Broome—while not being aware of the plans of the state government. I think it is very sensible that the ILC be required to consult with the state in relation to its plans.

Although I am not so familiar with the plans of other states, I am sure that would apply equally to places like the Northern Territory and Queensland. I am sure Senator Kernot would know about the Queensland government's plans. I am not familiar with them, but I am sure that the Queensland government has programs that specifically deal with land for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. I do not know enough about the Queensland situation, but it would be absurd if the ILC went to Queensland and did not talk to the Goss government and its people about their plans in this regard.

I will make some final points about our plans. We plan, firstly, to increase the consultation and, secondly, to ensure that strategies are made available to those who wish to see them. As I said, under the government's scheme the strategies will be set out in a document for the board but no-one else to know about. We have a plan to ensure that the strategies are tabled at least here so that anyone who wants them knows where they are and so that they can become the subject of public consideration and discussion, if that is required.

That is the broad thrust of the coalition's proposals. Based on those arguments, we indicate that we will be supporting most of what the Greens are proposing. As I have said, a number of the provisions—J6, J7, J3A and J4A; specifically, 18, 19, 22, 23 and 24—are effectively amendments that were drafted by the coalition. We will be supporting them. However, we have a problem with the concept of the tail wagging the dog. We do not think the national strategy needs to be or should be amended every time there is a change in the regional strategy. We think the regional strategies need to be tied together. We cannot just have a whole bunch of potentially, as Senator Collins quite properly says, inconsistent strategies. There needs to be a national perspective. I think it is important to address particularly the point made by the minister that it is important that the national strategy takes into account the regional strategies.

Senator Collins has talked about the problems of having concurrent strategies that are inconsistent or conflicting. Quite clearly, if we take the bottom up approach, where we look at the regions first and then devise the national strategy, there is no reason at all why it should be inconsistent. All the regions have different demands and different needs. They therefore require entirely different strategies, one would expect. As Senator Ellison has said by way of example on many occasions, the strategy that would relate to urban fringe-dwelling communities in Sydney or the Swan Valley in Perth would be extremely different from those for the Kimberleys, the Northern Territory or Cape York. So we will have very different regional approaches and regional strategies, and that is quite proper. It is crucial, therefore, that the national strategy takes those into account.

I disagree with the minister when he says that we could have a national strategy that is inconsistent and conflicting. The national strategy should be a broad directional document that provides the strategic railroad for the ILC to run down for—as the bill provides—a three to five year time span. It is important that once the strategy has been put in place, once it has been the subject of consultation, and once it has been the subject of public scrutiny and tabling in this place, it should stay in place until the time provided in the act for it to be reviewed.

Later in this set of proposed coalition amendments we are also suggesting further parliamentary scrutiny by the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title. That would provide another level of potential input by the community. As the joint committee moves around Australia we will be able to take evidence in relation to the strategies and all the other operations of the ILC.

That is the nub of what the coalition is looking for. To summarise: we want more consultation with Aboriginal groups; consultations with the states that have existing land programs; more accountability so that the strategies are subject to public scrutiny; and, finally, a strategy developed that is coordinated and consistent. I think that can be achieved under this scheme.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Senator Campbell, do I understand that you are proposing to move an amendment to Senator Chamarette's J2A whereby you will be omitting the proposed section 191N(1)(b)?

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I say that I am prepared to withdraw that? I am more than happy to do that.

PARA.TAB: Amendment J2A(1B)—by leave—withdrawn.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be opposing these amendments. We feel that it is a completely unnecessary imposition on the ILC to make this kind of consultation a mandatory requirement. The bill already provides for a provision that the ILC must have regard to the desirability of consulting the commission and may consult other persons and bodies that it considers appropriate.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that I am indebted to Senator Campbell for his example. I will make sure that Aboriginal organisations in Western Australia are well aware that the Greens are very happy to support a mandatory requirement for them, in the formulation of their regional and national policies, to consult with the Court government of Western Australia. Something has suddenly occurred to me in respect of the attitude of that government to all Aboriginal issues—which has been one of obstructionism and white-anting, but mostly obstructionism. If this amendment is carried, with the support of the Greens, it will be a mandatory requirement that this consultation be carried out. What will be the situation if the Court government of Western Australia simply declines to consult, thereby having the effect of blocking that from happening at all under this legislation? I do not place any weight on that, but I simply say that I am indebted to Senator Campbell. Aboriginal organisations in Western Australia will appreciate the support of the Greens in imposing on them a mandatory requirement, in developing their own Aboriginal regional and national strategies, to consult with the Court government of Western Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree that it is entirely reasonable to have a national strategy, and it is entirely reasonable that that national strategy reflects the directions of the regional strategies. I do wonder, though, whether it is wise to say that the national strategy `must be based on, derived from and reflect'. I wonder whether that is just too prescriptive. We have all heard in this debate about the force of the word `must.' Senator Campbell said that he wanted the national strategy to be a broad directional document. I see that as being a little bit different from the mandatory nature of `must' do all of those things. I hope it would. I just wonder whether we should compel it to that degree.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased that amendment J2A(1B) has been withdrawn. It would have made things very difficult. I want to link the effects of amendment J3A(3), which relates to consultation with a range of Aboriginal and other people as considered appropriate, amendment J7, which relates to consultation with corporations, persons, trustees, regional councils, state and territory governments and governments relevant to each region where there are regionally indigenous land strategies, amendment J2A(1B), a requirement to amend the national strategy, and amendment J6, which says that we cannot spend any money until the regional strategy is prepared.

What sort of time frame does Senator Chamarette have in mind in which all this will happen? She must have an idea. She has said that this is the way it should happen. Do we expect this to happen in a year, or two years? Does she think this is a wieldy process? Senator Campbell said that one of the principles he was looking for was coordination. But I wonder whether that is what we are going to achieve if we vote for these many tiers of consultation.

I ask Senator Chamarette to explain what she has in mind with the term `must consult'. Senator Collins asked, `What if the Court government declines to consult?' Does the term `must consult' require an answer? Does it mean the government can say, `We have plans to do this in this area and we would like to know some details about what you propose.' Senator Chamarette talks about ensuring `that regional indigenous land strategies complement existing state, territory or regional land acquisition and management programs'. In order to complement each other, do strategies and programs have to be in agreement to start with? How will she procure that agreement?

TALK.START.PARA: —Fundamental questions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree. They are very important questions and it is very important that we consider all the implications of what we are putting in place. I thank the people who have contributed. I think Senator Collins raised—as Senator Kernot did—the mandatory requirement implied by the use of the word `must'. Amendment J7(a) says that the board `must consult, as far as practicable' with everybody. That is a recognition that, even if we consult right throughout Australia with every particular Aboriginal community we know of, there may still be others we never get to. So that is a recognition of the impossibility of the extent of consultation that is required. It leaves leeway for the board to consult as far as it practicably can, to say what the limitations have been and to accept that there will be limitations.

PARA.TAB: However, state governments are stationary bodies. Western Australians know that only too well. Therefore, we feel happy to support this amendment because we do not think there is anything to be gained by being blissfully unaware of the state government's stance, whether it is one we agree with or not, when we are making plans. It is a matter of courtesy to consult but, more than that, it is wise. It is foolish to set up regional strategies that do not take into consideration any new information the state governments may have. They might hide it and not give it to us; but that is beside the point. We should give them every opportunity to do so. It is a bit like Senator Gareth Evans assuming that his amendments had solved all our problems and not asking us whether we had a different idea. That is all that is implied here. I believe that, within the cabinet, the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) must consult the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) before export woodchip licences are issued.

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't take any notice of him.

—Exactly, Senator Kernot. And we know, to our sad and sorry feelings about the issue of our forests, that he does not have to take the advice; he simply has to make that communication. The states do not have to like it, either. It is just that it is sensible to put in a requirement of consultation. If they are intransigent and refuse—fine. They have placed their stance. It does not mean that they are bound. It simply means that the board should do it and that it is a wise practice. Whether or not the government or the department being consulted is to its satisfaction is not the issue.

PARA.TAB: We are saying that the board should devise its strategies in such a way that they complement rather than conflict. If there is no alternative, that is fine, too. But if it has not consulted and there is a conflict, then really the onus is on it to say why regional strategies have been set up and Aboriginal communities' hopes raised only to be thwarted by the state authorities. It is to prevent disappointment and unwise strategies being made that we think wide as possible consultation with all the official bodies is appropriate. Senator Kernot said she thought it might be too difficult—and that is why she felt she could not support our amendments—to get all the regional strategies together.

TALK.START.PARA: —What time frame?

—I wrote down that there were two parts: too difficult or too unwieldy, and what time frame did I have in mind. It is up to the board to decide its time frame to give it the maximum time for as much consultation as is practicable, and the minimum time so that there is not too much delay.

PARA.TAB: We have to remember that it is a very small amount of money. The longer taken to decide on a very small amount of money, the better the satisfaction in the long run of any people who are beneficiaries. The shorter time taken on the small amount of money, the more unhappy people will be. That is why we feel that the allocation of funding should not start until some strategy is devised on how that will be approached. I also refer Senator Kernot to section 191N(1) where it states:
The Indigenous Land Corporation Board must prepare, and revise from time to time, a strategy to be known as the national indigenous land strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: It then goes on to talk about its contents. The strategy must cover, but is not limited to, the following matters:
(a) the acquisition of interests in land for the purpose of making grants of those interests to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations;
(b) land management issues relating to indigenous-held land;
(c) environmental issues relating to indigenous-held land.
How will the board do that if it does not do it by regional consultation?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not objecting to regional consultation at all.

—Fine. All I am saying is that, if we do not have this as a way in which to devise the national strategy, the national strategy can be devised without it, quite clearly, according to the legislation—and that is of concern.

PARA.TAB: I would urge the government to rethink its refusal to support our amendments at this point. As Senator Evans was so generous spirited as to contemplate the removal of the words `national strategy', he has already given in-principle agreement to the regional strategies being the most appropriate ones to be mentioned in devising a strategy at all. That has underlain the spirit of the amendments that the government put and then withdrew.

So the only things that the government can be said to be disagreeing on are: consultation on a broad representative basis with the regions as far as is practical; and consultation with state or territory governments that are relevant to each region. So I want the government to reconsider that, if possible.

The in-principle acceptance that regional strategies are the logical base by which to move forward is accepted by the government's willingness to write out the words `national strategy' throughout the bill. Only a very little is being added to that. So it needs to be on the record that that is what the government opposes—it actually opposes having anything that guarantees regional groups that they will be consulted, or that the board will attempt to consult them as far as practical. And it writes out of the bill any responsibility that the ILC might feel it needs to state and territory governments relevant to those regions on the issues that it wishes to put in place. I think there are two very good reasons why we should have those provisions, and I am amazed that that is the basis on which the government is not supporting these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —If only this actual amendment was as mild as Senator Chamarette is suggesting. The reason I throw this in now is that—and have a look at the words—what the Greens are supporting does not do what Senator Chamarette says it will do. The senator talks about the government's concerns about what the Greens are putting in. We are profoundly concerned about what the Greens are taking out. Senator Chamarette should have a look at what the Greens are proposing to delete on page 12 of the bill. What has happened to Aboriginal self-determination in this exercise? The Greens are seeking to delete clause (5)(a) from this bill and replace it. Clause (5)(a) states:

SPEECH.PARA: In performing functions under this section in connection with a regional area, the Indigenous Land Corporation Board:
(a)must, if any part of a region is included in the regional area, consult the Regional Council for the region . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —It is still in there.

—It is still in there? If the Greens are taking that out, that is fine. Senator Chamarette should listen to the wording. It is not the mild effect that the senator is suggesting. The Greens proposed amendment to clause 3 states:

PARA.TAB: (c)must consult with the State or Territory Government or Governments relevant to each region . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I am not saying that we are going to support this but, from Senator Chamarette's own philosophical base, I am suggesting that the questions Senator Kernot has raised are absolutely pertinent to this issue. If the Greens put a full stop after that, they might not be in the trouble they are going to get into. The problem is the hook that they then get into. The proposed amendment to clause 3 says that the board must consult to ensure that regional indigenous land strategies complement each state, territory, etc.

PARA.TAB: In terms of being able to lay this organisation wide open to mischief-making by state governments the requirement is, in Senator Campbell's words, to consult with the Court government in Western Australia. We should not just consult with it, which is how Senator Chamarette has very mildly portrayed this amendment just now, but ensure that that consultation results in a decision that these things complement state government programs. What if the state government of Western Australia refuses to consult or says, and I am sure it will, that anything that is being proposed by this organisation flatly contradicts what is being done by the state government of Western Australia.

As Senator Kernot said, it is a value judgment that then has to be reached. There are questions that need to be asked: who reaches it; who makes that decision; who determines at the end of the day whether the requirements of this clause have been fulfilled; and who makes that decision? The problem is that if Senator Chamarette amends this section to comply with the explanation she has just given to the chamber, there might not be such a major problem. But that is a substantial hook that then goes in afterwards. If Senator Chamarette put in a full stop and deleted those other words, the proposed amendment might be in better shape.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to that very point because if we look at that subsection (c), we see it says that the board must consult with those governments mentioned there and then `so as to ensure' is a rider. If people try to consult with the body concerned and it refuses point-blank to consult, then they have discharged their legal obligation. They have fulfilled their function under that requirement.
—What if you consult and you can't get a complementary strategy? That is the other way it works.

—No. What happens is this. We have all conceded that the question of a body not consulting is no longer a problem because that is an easy question to answer. The other thing is, Senator Kernot is saying, if that body then says, `Okay, we'll consult, but we're not going to help complement or not tell you what we are doing'—
—No, we'll tell you what we are doing, but we do not agree that there has to be any complementary action.

—That question is just as easy to answer because the state government says, and we are talking in a hypothetical sense, `We don't agree with what you're doing. Here's what we're doing though.' That is all we need because the proposed amendment is to ensure that the regional indigenous strategy complements existing state services.

PARA.TAB: The state does not have to agree. There is nothing there which says that the state has any input in a decisive way. All the state does is tell you what it is doing. If it does not tell you what it is doing, then you have fulfilled your obligation because you have tried. If it does tell you what it is doing, you work around it. That is what it is basically saying. For instance, if there is a grant of land, as we have seen—

TALK.START.PARA: —So that they have the paramount power.

—No, they do not have the paramount power because if they say, `Look, under our Aboriginal affairs planning authority, we have granted this community freehold land in that area,' and they show you the title, there is no need to include that in your acquisition strategy. You might want to include it in your land management strategy but you do not include it in your land acquisition strategy. So the ILC says, `Good, that is a piece of land that we don't have to worry about buying, but it is a piece of land that we now have to worry about managing.' This proposed section requires the ILC to go to the state or territory government and ask, `What is your plan for this area?' If they say, `We're not telling,' then the ILC can go on its merry way. It has fulfilled its—
—You are making this up as you go along.

—No, I am not. The minister knows this is right. It would not stand up to any critical review. If the ILC fulfilled its functions, went to a state government and the state government slammed its door in its face, the ILC would be quite within its rights to walk away and continue with its regional strategy. If the door is opened, it goes in and the state government says, `We've granted these pieces of land to those various groups,' then the ILC plans its acquisition strategy accordingly, because it does not have to buy those pieces of land.
—Except that the state government sets the agenda and it may not be complementary.
—It is a matter of fact, Senator Kernot, that around the country, state governments have already developed plans for Aboriginal affairs under their respective portfolios.
—You are making more work for lawyers.

—Senator Collins has missed the boat. He knows darned well that in the states there are these schemes afoot—for instance, in Queensland and Western Australia. In fact, recently the native title committee heard evidence from Robert Bropho from the Swan Valley community that he had been granted an A-class reserve by the state government. I say to Senator Kernot that that is a fait accompli; much as she might dislike the state governments doing the right thing, they have done it and they have given the land in certain areas to certain people.

PARA.TAB: The strategies must then accommodate that. What would Senator Kernot have the ILC do—go and acquire that land again for the same people? Of course not. It must be accommodated, and that is what that means. The only requirement on the ILC is to go to the local governments in the area and say, `What have you got planned?' If they say, `No,' that is fine; they can get on with their strategy. If they say, `This is what we've got,' then they do not duplicate it by purchasing the land twice. It stands to reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —How could they?

—I am spelling it out pretty basically for Senator Collins's benefit. I tell him right now that with respect to the question of regional strategies versus national strategies, the government's bill has not set a time frame for the development of these strategies. Senator Chamarette was asked that question. I say to the committee that the government has not shed any light on this aspect, either, because there is nothing in the bill that says how quickly they have got to develop their regional strategies. What the bill does say is that a regional strategy should cater for a time period of three to five years, as should a national strategy. This means we would have some consistency for the future, which means that under this scheme proposed by the Greens we would not have some uncertainty. The decisions that are made are going to be for quite some time.
—How long will it take?
—About the same time as it is under the government's bill. Senator Kernot should answer that question, because the government cannot answer it. It will vary—
—It is the government's bill.

—Exactly—it is the government's bill. I would suggest it would vary from place to place because in a suburban area the issues might be quite straightforward. In a more remote area where there are conflicting interests with regional groups, it might be more complex.

PARA.TAB: That is where the regional strategies have to be maintained, and the government recognised this in its legislation. In the Kimberley the considerations are very different from those in Redfern, Sydney. It has to be taken on a region by region basis. Some will be developed quite quickly; others will not.

When it is developed, it will have to last for three to five years, as the national strategy would. So what we want to ensure is that, when a decision is made which is going to hang around for a bit—is going to be there for some time—it is the right decision and we draw up the right strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't want it to take three years to make a decision.

—No, it will not do. The ILC is going to be under a fair bit of pressure to get cracking on this when it is set up. There is going to be a fair bit of attention given to it by those people who stand to be recipients under this bill. They are going to be eager to get the scheme going, as, I assume, the government will be. I am sure it will be. The ILC will have the resources that the government will provide to it to get these strategies defined and drawn up. As for this question that Senator Kernot mentioned earlier, that we have this continual change, as the bill is drafted the regional strategies will be set for some time, as will the national strategy.
—No, that part has been withdrawn.

—If Senator Kernot's fears in that regard have dissipated, I will not address it any further, but I will address the aspect of a national strategy. When we are coming from an overall perspective—and this is for the government's benefit—dealing with a continent as large as ours, we need a national strategy and a national corporate plan. Most boards and most bodies have that sort of approach. But what we say is that, instead of going from the top down, we should come from the grassroots up. We would suggest that is a very good way—
—Like in the Liberal Party.

—Not a bad way to operate. That is a very good way to operate. We always go to the local people, we work out what their aspirations and hopes are, then we build it up to the next tier of government, and from there we build. These regional strategies are like building blocks for the national strategy. That is how it would work.

PARA.TAB: It would not be a disaster. The disaster would be having it around the other way so that we draw up this grand plan from Canberra. Canberra always seems to think that all wisdom resides here; unfortunately, it does not. In fact, if honourable senators go out into the local areas of Australia, they will find a good deal more wisdom there than sometimes resides in this honourable place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly on your side; that is absolutely true.

—It is apparent that Senator Schacht has not travelled through Western Australia. If he had, he would have seen that a lot of people in those areas have a lot of homespun logic and advice which this government could do well to take. That answers all Senator Collins's queries on that. It will work. It is a sensible way to approach things. There is no aspect of the ILC being locked out because there is no consultation from the state government.

PARA.TAB: I might just add—I think Senator Campbell is going to get into this—that the only state government that attended the recent hearings of the Native Title Committee and offered evidence was the state government of Western Australia, and the Premier himself appeared in person. We requested the Queensland government and the New South Wales government to attend, and they did not turn up. In the committee's report, which was a unanimous report, there was mention made of the cooperation given by the WA government.I might also add that the Land Titles Office in Western Australia has given a good deal of support to the National Native Title Tribunal, and that is a matter of record.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address some of the concerns that have been raised. Again, I stress that they are legitimate concerns and I think we should check what the impact is of any amendments before we put them in place. However, one of the things we have to realise is that we are not talking here about trying to work out a strategy that distributes $1 billion on the ground. The reality is that for the next three years the ILC will have $21 million.
—Yes, but people will fight—
—I understand that. Let us look at the practicalities.
—There is conflict.

—Of course there is, and we need to look for ways of resolving that conflict. If there is, say, $21 million, as we know, available through this fund each year for the next three years, and we arbitrarily divide it among the seven states—because it is up to the ILC how it deals with the money—then there is $3 million to WA. When the ILC is considering regionally, after consultation with regional groups, what the needs are in Western Australia, then with that $3 million, which, believe me, is not going to go far, it needs to find out what areas are going to be the easiest to access and what areas are going to be the most difficult to access.

PARA.TAB: They will also need to know whether the government is going to be cooperative. That will apply whether it is a Liberal state government or a Labor state government. I would therefore ask the government and the Democrats to think about this: if it were the same political party as the federal government, would it be any more willing to support this? If it is unwilling to consult even its state governments when they are of the same party—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are worse sometimes.

—I think it is a courtesy matter and it is also a very practical matter from which the Aboriginal groups can benefit. This is saying, `We have $3 million to spend in this state in the best possible way.' If the board consults with people and finds out what their plans are, it helps them to devise a much more effective way of operating. If it makes a plan without that consultation and then finds that it has actually chosen something that would be ideal in every other way except that the state government is intransigent and has a different plan in place for a particular area, it has wasted a lot of time. If it can find that out first what is practicable and what the states are doing—I think Senator Kernot pointed this out—that gives direction to its plan. There is no doubt about that. But the question is whether it is better to know that or not?
—It is better to know it, but you cannot force it to be complementary.

—That is an issue. We are saying that consultation is sensible. It may actually work in everyone's best interests because with the state bodies feeling as though they are being consulted, they might come on side. It may enhance cooperation, because it is actually quite an empowering thing for the ILC to be able to say, `We have some money. We want to use it as well as we can. We want to find out what the state is prepared to do.' That might elicit some generosity from the state.

PARA.TAB: If it does not and it brings out hostility, it is still better to know where that hostility is coming from when they are making their decisions. Complementing the states does not mean working in with what the states want. It just allows the board to know in advance whether or not they agree. It can either spend time fighting or, with this very scarce resource, it can choose something that is immediately accessible. It just gives a choice.

I hope I have explained why I feel this is not a constricting amendment. The minister implied that we were taking something out of the bill. We are taking nothing out; we are just adding two things. It was the government that was going to take something out, namely, the national strategy. We are just adding the requirement for consultation with the people who, and the agencies which, in our view, will have some de facto authority or capacity to thwart or assist the plans that are put in place. We feel it is better for that to be known when the strategy is being devised. It is just a sensible precaution. We have no problems with the words `so as to ensure as far as possible' that regional indigenous land strategies complement existing state—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is better.

—It is the same meaning. The Greens do not intend or want to do anything that would subject Aboriginal people to the mercy of state governments or anybody else. Clearly, that is not in our interests. What we are saying is that we cannot prevent their subjection, quite honestly. The only thing we can do is to know that through this amendment they are entering into that battle with full information or as much information as they have been able to access. That is the meaning of it. I again present it to the chamber. I do not know what those opposite feel because it was their amendment. Maybe they need to reply as to whether they feel comfortable and possibly move it if they want to.
—Are you saying, `as far as practicable'?
—Yes. That is in J7(c).
—I asked the opposition to consider that.

—Great minds think alike. It is to ensure that, as far as possible, regional indigenous land strategies complement existing state, territory or regional land acquisition and management programs for Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could run across to our party meeting that is going on at the moment and ask for approval, but I might risk my arm. I said to Senator Kernot privately that I do not want to commit the coalition without talking to coalition members, in particular Senator Alston. This amendment certainly meets the objective and we are happy to do that.

PARA.TAB: I need to respond to some of the things that Senator Collins has said. He said that he would like to get the bill finished today. That is certainly what the coalition would like. He said that he will try to stop provoking us, so we can meet this objective. Senator Collins has been much better today than he was yesterday.

The government seeks to criticise the Court government in relation to Aboriginal affairs. Mr Court is considered to be fair game by government senators. I will remind the government of a few facts about the performance of the Court government. Just because Mr Court and his government opposed the government's native title legislation does not mean that they are not fundamentally committed to improving the living standards and opportunities of Aboriginal people in Western Australia. The Court government is fundamentally opposed to the constitutional abuses contained in the Native Title Act. It is fundamentally opposed to the procedures that the federal government set up under the future acts regime and, it is fundamentally opposed to the government's creation of an unworkable regime in native title.

As we all know, the Court government has taken that argument to the High Court. The High Court judges are considering their conclusions and will bring down a decision on a range of those aspects, including the challenge to the federal government's legislation and the challenge to Western Australia's Land (Titles and Traditional Usage) Act by various Aboriginal groups. Those matters will be resolved.

I want to put on the record a fact that was determined and supported by the Joint Committee on Native Title and recognised by Justice French and members of the National Native Title Tribunal. Our obligations and requirements under section 206 of the Native Title Act are that our committee is to go around the country and consult with state governments to see how the Native Title Act is going. When we set out to do that, the committee—of which Senator Chamarette is a member—decided that we would go to New South Wales and Queensland, specifically Sydney and Brisbane. We also went further north in Queensland. We went to these places to make it easy for the state governments to talk to us about what they were doing about the Native Title Act.

What did we discover? Let us go to a Labor state—I do not want to criticise my friend John Fahey in a pre-election period—and see what cooperation we got from Wayne Goss's government. It said, `Sorry, we don't want to come along and talk to you.' We went to Western Australia, and who came and saw us? The Hon. Richard Court, Premier of Western Australia. On page 9, paragraph 3.11 of the report of the joint committee, this is what is said about Richard Court. It states:
It is of concern to the Committee that the NSW and Queensland governments did not accept the opportunity for consultations with the Commonwealth parliament . . .

SPEECH.PARA: We all know why. It is because 18 months after the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) promised that the government would pay compensation to those states for the validation of past acts, there has been no agreement. We know that not a single state in Australia has proclaimed legislation to implement native title. Two weeks ago, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) told us, `Don't worry, compensation will be negotiated. It will all be fixed.' We are no closer to a conclusion on the compensation issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are no closer to a vote on this before lunch.
—No, we will not have a vote before lunch because I have some points that I need to make. The unanimous, bipartisan report of the joint committee goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Hon Richard Court, Premier of Western Australia, provided this level of cooperation in meeting with the Committee in Perth on 15 August. The Committee would hope that State and Territory governments would cooperate similarly . . .

The Western Australian government is providing an enormous amount of cooperation with the National Native Title Tribunal. We were philosophically and fundamentally opposed to the tribunal, but the Court government is providing full cooperation with it, a fact that Justice French has confirmed on the record.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.
Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise to speak on the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1994. The bill enables the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, known as AQIS, to refund money to various industry groups it has overcharged. The refund will take the form of a rebate. This decision vindicates the concerns of industry groups who succeeded in persuading AQIS to establish an industry charging review committee. The committee subsequently found that AQIS had overcharged those industries by about $13 million and that the money should be rebated.

PARA.TAB: In effect, this bill amends the Quarantine Act to provide a limited remission power to apply to fees for quarantine services. The remission power will allow for revenue collections which are surplus to cost recovery requirements in any year to be returned to the relevant industry groups in the form of uniform fee rebates in the following year. It is proposed that $6.1 million will be rebated through this legislation and $6.9 million through regulations.

The affected industry groups and potential rebates are: processed food exports, $1.319 million; plant exports, $4.732 million; live animal exports, $0.94 million; post entry plant quarantine, $0.476 million; seaport quarantine, $0.774 million; airport quarantine, $1.132 million; and import clearance, $3.724 million. I understand the industries have been consulted about the rebates. Some have agreed to use part of the money for specific projects such as quality assurance facilitation and residue testing programs. However, the bulk will be used to provide fee rebates during the current financial year.

With that in mind it is timely to reflect on the role of AQIS. Over the years, AQIS has been condemned for obstructing the development of primary industry in this country, and for inefficiency, irresponsibility and inhibiting competitiveness. Let me quote a letter from Mr Nick Truelove, the managing director of a small, innovative meat exporter called the True Foods Corporation. In November 1993 he wrote to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I have had nothing but obstruction, discouragement and costly problems from your Department.

Quite frankly I have become so sick and tired of it (AQIS obstruction) that if I had not been a farmer and ultimately dependent on export business for the survival of the family property I would have long since chucked it in and gone into an easier business.
AQIS is the greatest single impediment to Australian meat exports and is costing Australian farmers who it is ostensively set up to serve, dearly.

That is damning criticism, but justified in the context of a series of examples that highlight the burden of 100 per cent cost recovery, excess staff and inefficient practices within the AQIS organisation. One example is meat inspection. The average meat inspector earns around $30,000 a year, but is charged out to the abattoir at over $70,000—well in excess of AQIS's 100 per cent cost recovery. If that is not bad enough, an Australian inspector only manages about 79 carcases a shift, while an American inspector gets through more than three times that amount, with around 300 carcases a shift.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has frequently highlighted the problems with AQIS. I am well aware of the work of my colleague Senator David Brownhill, who has made a particular effort to concentrate on this particular program and effort. While my colleagues and I support the bill now before us, we wish to place on record our continuing frustration with the government and its refusal to act decisively on AQIS.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support all the remarks made by my colleague Senator Tambling. This bill gives AQIS the power to refund to industries money it has overcharged. It is hardly a piece of legislation that one is likely to oppose. Senator Tambling has already outlined the groups and the moneys involved for some $13 million currently. Of more importance, this overcharging is another administrative flaw in the operation of the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service.

PARA.TAB: This service is our flagship to the world in terms of quarantine standards. We have an enviable record in Australia of being disease free in so many areas. The current drought and the need to import grains highlight the almost unique position we have in Australia. We need to import grain, but our grain industries are free of so many diseases, fungi and bugs that are found elsewhere, that import protocols are having to be developed to protect us.

We rely on AQIS to protect our industries; we rely on its integrity and attention to detail. Yet, last year we had example after example of AQIS making mistakes at the administrative level. We have had relatively minor matters of travel irregularities, the Audit Office has been concerned about auditing practices and now, as a result of industries complaining about charges, we have this bill to pay back money that AQIS has wrongly collected. The need for this legislation reiterates my ongoing concerns about AQIS and the need for an objective and thorough examination of its administration and operation. I moved for an inquiry to see what reforms have been put in place in regard to AQIS—quality assurance and all those other things. It is a user-pays organisation, it is based on that and it has to be responsible and up front.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 7 November, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. This bill amends the Beef Production Levy Act 1990 by introducing a conversion factor which will allow the levy to be calculated where only a cold carcase weight is available. The bill also proposes other minor amendments to levy acts. The levies collected for research and development, promotion, disease eradication and the residue survey, are currently calculated on a hot weight basis. The difficulty arises when the carcase weighed cold produces a lighter weight. This legislation introduces a conversion factor of 1.03 which allows for a weight reduction of three per cent for chilled or frozen meat and provides the hot carcase weight equivalent for levy calculation purposes.

PARA.TAB: Where neither the hot nor cold carcase weight is determined, a deemed carcase weight of 240 kilograms will be assumed in order to calculate the levy. It is worth noting that penalties are imposed for offences relating to the failure to use hot carcase or cold carcase weight when available. The maximum fine is 60 penalty units, the current penalty unit being $100.

In addition, the bill makes it clear that an agent, if involved in the sale of cattle, is responsible for collecting and forwarding the levy to the Commonwealth. The abattoir proprietor will only become responsible for collecting and forwarding the levy if an agent is not involved.
