Abattoir proprietors can also refuse to slaughter livestock, including pigs owned by someone else, unless levy payments are first made.

Meat processing is one of Australia's largest rural based industries. It employs more than 30,000 Australians, generates about $5.6 billion turnover a year, and is gaining increasing recognition and market share in Asia. Currently, more than 75,000 farms and pastoral properties in Australia produce livestock for slaughter. Together, beef and veal are our fourth largest export earner, generating $2,949 million a year. Certainly, the GATT outcome promises more opportunities for the Australian beef industry in the United States, Japan and Korea. Other breakthroughs are likely in Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Canada and Mexico. It is important to note the beef industry's commitment to research and development, and promotion and disease eradication, as well as the industry's potential for growth and expansion. On behalf of the opposition, I am pleased to support this bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY ELECTORAL LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 12 October, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports the Australian Capital Territory Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. This bill is before us because the ACT Legislative Assembly has enacted its own legislation covering the conduct of elections and related matters. There now exists an ACT Electoral Commission and its functions and powers are determined by the procedures laid down in the ACT's Electoral Act 1992, and amended in 1994.

PARA.TAB: The main aim of this bill is to amend and repeal those parts of the Commonwealth ACT self-government legislation which are no longer appropriate. The bill also makes provision for transitional arrangements dealing with disputed qualifications of members, which are not covered in the ACT's legislation in the period leading up to the February 1995 election.

The transition to self-government has not been without problems. The first ACT elections were held in 1989 under what was then known as a `modified d'Hondt' system, where counting alone took some nine weeks. It took more than two months from the time of the election to determine who was going to be a member of the legislative assembly. Furthermore, some 117 candidates stood for 17 positions and, as a result, the ballot paper was a metre wide. There were 108 different parties and nine independents. Apart from the Liberal and Labor parties, there were parties variously called Party! Party! Party!, Sun-Ripened Warm Tomato Party and Surprise Party. There was also a party committed to abolishing self-government. It was the biggest ballot paper ever seen in Australia and the second largest seen in the democratic world.

As the shadow Attorney-General of the ACT, Mr Gary Humphries, has said, it is appropriate that the ACT parliament take control of its own electoral system following a decision by the people at a referendum in 1992. This referendum involved a choice between single member electorates and the so-called Hare-Clarke voting system with a Robson rotation. Some 67 per cent of Canberrans supported the Hare-Clarke system and there was support for that system from every political party except the ALP.

Senators will be aware that after the referendum a major controversy broke out as Ms Follett attempted to undermine, in the view of many people, the results of the referendum with the Labor Party's proposals. In the event, the ALP had to back down, and the voting system in the ACT now reflects the wishes of the vast majority of electors. On behalf of the coalition I am pleased to support this bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.02 to 2.00 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Gareth Evans and Senator McMullan will be absent from question time today to enable them to travel to the sixth APEC ministerial meeting being held in Jakarta on 11 and 12 November. In their absence I will act as Leader of the Government in the Senate and answer questions relating to Foreign Affairs; Senator Cook will take questions relating to Trade; Senator Bolkus will represent the Minister for Administrative Services; and Senator Collins will represent the Minister for Communications and the Arts.

—My question is directed to you, Mr President. I refer to my point of order yesterday at the conclusion of question time, and your agreement to view a replay of question time to determine whether three opposition senators were on their feet prior to Senator Gareth Evans rising from his seat. I ask: did you view a replay as you promised; did the replay sustain the grounds of my point of order; if so, will you apologise to my opposition colleagues who were on their feet; and, in the future, will you undertake the role of independent chair of the Senate as opposed to being the assistant to the Leader of the Government in the Senate?

—I take a point of order, Mr President. My point of order is that you ought not be called upon to answer this question. The requirement on you, as I understand the standing orders, is that you should—
—What is your point of order?
—Order! Senator Cook is making his point of order.

—I will make my point of order in the appropriate manner and not as urged by Senator Macdonald. The point is that under standing orders, Mr President, you have to apprehend that someone is on their feet. It may well be that several people are on their feet but not within your field of vision; therefore, it is not appropriate for you to call on them. The standing orders are quite explicit on this point, and they use words to the effect that the President has to recognise somebody, which suggests that he first has to see them. This question is an offence against the dignity of the chair and should not be answered by you. It should simply be dismissed by you, Mr President.

—If I may address you on Senator Cook's point of order, Mr President, the situation is that at page 2753 of yesterday's Hansard it is recorded that you gave an undertaking to view a replay of Senate question time. That is an undertaking that you gave to the Senate, so it is appropriate to ask you whether you have fulfilled that undertaking, together with the other questions that follow on from that undertaking.

—I really cannot believe that this is serious. I have not viewed a replay because I have not had time to do that but, if I did, I would not really be able to tell you any more than I can now. I was focused on Senator Gareth Evans. I had closed my file. I was expecting him to rise, and I did not see anybody else at that stage. If that means that my field of vision was narrowed, it is because I was expecting Senator Evans to rise. But I must say that this is a very petty issue, and I take very real exception to your assertion that I am being biased in my judgments of affairs here. I am not, and I do not intend to be, and I take very strong objection to your assertion that I am.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can I ask you this: since when is it your role to comment on whether a question is petty or not? I would have thought it was your role to determine whether a question was in order or out of order and not to enter into the political debate. You undertook yesterday to view a replay of Senate question time. You have now answered that you have not. My supplementary question is: will you abide by the undertaking you gave to this house yesterday and, if so, when will you undertake that?

—What I am trying to tell you is that that was a jovial, throw-away comment. I did not take you seriously yesterday. That is why I said today that it was not a serious point. I will view it if you want me to but I think the whole thing is a joke.

—Mr President, to raise the tone of debate in this place I will address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to the October labour force figures, which are of interest to the people of Australia and which were released today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Can the minister inform the Senate—and hopefully those opposite will listen as well—of the current employment figures; and tell us whether they have improved in recent months.

—I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. There has been a welcome fall in the unemployment rate announced today by the ABS. For October the unemployment rate is now down to 9.1 per cent from 9.5 per cent in September. The sharp fall in October means that the unemployment rate has now fallen by a full two percentage points in the last 12 months and is now at its lowest level in 3 1/2 years. The results are particularly pleasing on a state basis with the unemployment rate falling in all states except South Australia, where it remained unchanged at 10.4 per cent.
—So it's great work that you have 800,000 unemployed!

—Today's labour force figures show that 31,400 fewer Australians were unemployed in October, and I am sure that Senator Macdonald is pleased to hear that. This trend is consistent with the Department of Social Security figures also released today which show a fall in the number of jobstart and newstart recipients.

PARA.TAB: In seasonally adjusted terms, employment fell by 11,000 following a sharp rise of 75,700 in September. At the same time, there was a decrease in the labour force participation rate from 63.3 per cent in September to 62.9 per cent this month. This significant volatility in the labour force surveys seasonally adjusted series over recent months is not unusual. The key issue is the unambiguously positive underlying trend. That trend is as follows: full-time employment has been increasing since September 1992; unemployment is at its lowest level since May 1991; and the unemployment rate continues its steady fall since October last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you note that youth unemployment is still 28 per cent? Why don't you boast about that?
—Senator Hill interjects but he could not even gain employment in Boothby, so I do not think he ought to be commenting about employment elsewhere.

—Mr President, I take a point of order on the issue of relevance. I have listened very carefully to what Senator Schacht has been saying in response to the question and he seems to have missed the critical point that there has been a fall of 42,000 in full-time employment.
—Order! Make your point of order. You should not be arguing your case.
—The point of order is: could he please give an accurate description of the figures presented by the ABS today and explain to us why there has been a sharp fall in full-time employment?
—Order! There is no point of order and you know it full well.

—Mr President, I take a further point of order. I think we have to take this matter further. That was a completely fallacious point of order. An argument was put forward that had nothing to do with the question asked from this side and the answer given. It was a deliberate interruption of the debate. If Senator Kemp wishes to debate the matter he should move a motion after question time to take note of the answer and argue about it. He should not waste the opposition's time—because his points of order are wasting opposition's question time more than anyone else's—by putting arguments forward and interrupting the debate. That is out of order, Mr President.
—I have already made the point that it is out of order and I ask Senator Kemp not to do that again.

—Thank you, Mr President. I was pointing out to the Senate, particularly to Senator Kemp, the general trends that have been going on in employment over the last 18 months—figures that those on the other side disparage continually because they hate good news on employment. They absolutely despise it.

PARA.TAB: I make this further point to the opposition: the DEET leading indicator of employment released earlier this week showed a continued rise in September 1994, suggesting that cyclical employment will continue to increase faster than its long-term trend through early 1995. The ANZ job vacancies index rose by 1.7 per cent in seasonally adjusted terms in October. In trend terms, job advertisements continued to increase, rising a further 2.1 per cent in October following a 2.7 per cent rise in September.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to full-time employment?

—An interjection has come from the other side asking about the actual number unemployed. It was published today, and the figure is over 800,000. There is no secret about that. We have had 300,000 extra jobs created in this country since March 1993—an unparalleled success in creating jobs—and all the opposition wants to do is deny the fact that there has been a substantial improvement in jobs in Australia, because every bit of good news is another nail in the coffin of the opposition for the next election.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the minister's response to my earlier question he mentioned the word `trends' a number of times. Could he now inform the Senate whether those figures he spoke of are an indication that the employment and economic strategies of the government are on track, are on trend?

—I am more than happy to respond to the supplementary question from my colleague Senator McKiernan to again emphasise to the opposition the outstanding impact of our economic policies in the last 18 months.
—You caused the recession; it was your recession.
—For the benefit of this whingeing fop opposite called Senator Kemp, only recently we heard the inflation outcome for the previous 12 months was 1.9 per cent.
—You caused the recession and now we are having the interest rate rises we had to have.

—I remind Senator Macdonald that for the September quarter it was 0.6 per cent. What was the opposition's inflation record the last time in the distant past it was in government? Above 10 per cent was the inflation record of the opposition when it was last in government.

PARA.TAB: That inflation rate is a particularly good outcome. Economic growth was well over four per cent. I have already mentioned that we have had employment growth of over 270,000 in the past 12 months, and a reduction in unemployment of 160,000 in the same period. Real household disposable incomes are on the increase. These figures starkly show the improvement in the economy and also show why those opposite are in such turmoil that, after only six months with one leader, they are now talking about dumping him. On the television today Mr Tony Abbott could not even endorse Downer as the leader. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer to the government's much publicised home child-care allowance scheme, which will replace the dependent spouse rebate and is a means tested scheme to be paid on a fortnightly basis, unlike its predecessor. Is it true that families who were due to receive their first payment in September have still not been paid?

—I am unaware that a delay in payments has happened. I will certainly seek information as to whether that is the case, and get back to Senator Reid. I had been given to understand that payments were proceeding, but I will certainly see what I can find out and inform the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I refer the minister to comments made yesterday by the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Fahey, that the Commonwealth has not responded to his request for the Australian Defence Force to assist in carrying water to New South Wales towns. Can the minister advise the Senate whether this is the case?

—It appears that Premier Fahey must have missed the answer that I gave to Senator Sandy Macdonald on this issue on Monday, but it is not surprising that not many people would be watching question time. Premier Fahey has said that he has had no formal response. Let me point out that Premier Fahey, in his four-page, very detailed letter to the Prime Minister, raised many drought issues, of which the army assisting in water movement was contained in just one paragraph. I have had previous experience of writing letters to the New South Wales government. If you get an answer within three months, you are lucky. But that did not stop Premier Fahey two days later again berating us in the press for not giving him a formal answer.

PARA.TAB: The Premier, in his letter, calls for a general assurance that, should the need for transporting water arise, the defence forces would be available to assist. There is no specific detail of what assistance is required. There has been no approach from the New South Wales State Emergency Service to Emergency Management Australia; nor has there been any approach to the Commonwealth from the drought relief coordinator. In fact, New South Wales has not even inquired as to what capacity the armed forces have for water transport, purification or storage.

On the basis of the Premier's letter, Emergency Management Australia has made inquiries of both those organisations. What is clear is that the situation facing drought affected towns in New South Wales is changing on a day-to-day basis in response to localised storms and the emergency measures being taken. It is also apparent that New South Wales has not yet determined what assistance, if any, it requires in water transport from the Commonwealth; they are continuing to assess the tanker capacity available in New South Wales. It would seem that there is excess capacity available through commercial tankers which are not being utilised.

I call on the New South Wales government to come forward with specific requests through appropriate channels. No-one wants a repeat of the Nyngan floods, when New South Wales ignored all the existing procedures and complained afterwards. The Commonwealth record of responding to emergency situations speaks for itself.

The recent assistance provided to the Queensland government in support of bushfire prevention is a prime example of the Commonwealth quickly and effectively responding when the appropriate procedures are followed. The fact that the New South Wales government has not followed up on these issues leads me to draw one of two conclusions: either New South Wales has not got its act together, or Premier Fahey is playing politics. The fact that the Premier's very general request arrived on Monday, and his condemnation occurred on Wednesday, can only lead me to the second conclusion. I assume there must be a state election in the offing in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. I refer to the results of the United States congressional elections and the comment by the likely new Senate majority leader, Bob Dole: `We have got a problem with GATT.' I ask the minister: firstly, what are the implications for the Uruguay Round agreement if the United States does not pass its GATT legislation? Secondly, how much of the claimed $4 billion in benefits to Australia will be lost if the Americans do not meet their Uruguay Round commitments? Thirdly, will the government continue to pursue unilateral trade deregulation if the United States persists with trade policies which hurt Australian producers? In other words, will Australia still sign if the United States does not?

—As I took down those questions, the answer to the first question is: that calls for me to speculate, and that is not a very healthy thing for ministers to do. The second question calls for me to then calibrate the effects based on that speculation, and I do not think that is appropriate either.

PARA.TAB: The third question asks whether we will pursue unilateral trade negotiations with the US. We always do. Irrespective of what multilateral trade negotiations are current, we always press unilaterally for particular trade advantages in areas where we perceive a necessity for that. I might say that, when we balance the size of the Australian economy and the international clout that we have against the size of the United States economy and the international clout that it has, unless we can point to particular areas of strong leverage in bilateral negotiations, it is a hard thing to do with a major country like the United States. It is far better for us to work within the structure of multilateral trade negotiations on major issues.

I have a brief on the US presidential elections and, since I am representing the minister, perhaps I should refer to it. It says that if the United States does not obtain the authority during the forthcoming special session of Congress to accept the World Trade Organisation agreement, it would be a factor affecting the timing of entry into force of the World Trade Organisation agreement, which is to be considered at the implementation conference scheduled to be held on 8 December this year. It is speculative to consider what the Congress may do with the Uruguay Round implementing legislation in 1995.

It is speculative because the new members of the US House of Representatives and the Senate elected yesterday will not be sworn until 1 January 1995. The Uruguay Round implementing legislation is due to be considered at a special congressional session in late November-early December and thus will be considered by the members who currently hold their seats prior to the newly elected members coming on board. This was anticipated in the lead-up to the congressional elections when the leaders of all parties indicated to the President passage of the Uruguay Round legislation. That is why it is all in the realms of speculation, and speculation into which it is not appropriate for me to delve.

In relation to the other questions, I can inform the Senate that the benefits that accrue to Australia from the Uruguay Round outcomes are part of the global endeavour. That is, they do not come exclusively from the United States; they come from our negotiations with Europe and other countries, including Japan. Obviously, the securing of these outcomes is dependent on the World Trade Organisation being joined by the major powers and on when it comes into operation itself. We are therefore consistently pursuing all of the macro-economic reform settings and the trade and industry policies directed to improving our international competitiveness in the expectation that the World Trade Organisation is established and that lower trade barriers exist so that we can take advantage of the Uruguay Round outcomes. But it also helps us improve the efficiency of the Australian economy and makes us more competitive, which makes it worth doing in its own right.

The timing of entry into force of the WTO is to be considered by the implementation conference on 8 December. The capacity of the majors to go ahead with the targeted date of implementation of 1 January 1995 will be taken into account at that conference. The government intends to be in a position to accept the WTO once agreement has been reached on the date of entry into force and the major powers have accepted. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling; sorry—Senator Spindler on a supplementary question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister misunderstood the first part of my question. I did not ask whether we would engage in negotiations with the United States. I asked whether we would engage in unilateral disarmament in the trade area, as we have over the last few years, irrespective of whether the Americans sign. That is the question the government needs to consider. My question is: is the government ready to consider this question and what is its basic stance? Will the government simply continue to meet our GATT arrangements and our GATT commitments, even if we do not get a quid pro quo?

—I understood Senator Spindler's first question to ask me to speculate on what the US Congress might do in passing the legislation in order to legitimise for the United States the Uruguay Round outcome. As I have indicated, that is the intention of the administration. I ought to take exception to the words `unilateral disarmament' because they are not appropriate in this debate. They apply to another debate which bears no resemblance in principle or in any key element to this debate.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about meeting trade obligations which strengthen the ability of the Australian economy to be more efficient, strengthen the ability of the Australian economy to be more competitive and enhance our ability as an economy to capture more world trade—things worth doing in their own right. The fact that they are part of a multilateral agreement gives extra reason why we should do those things. It means that other countries are doing them too, and access to their markets is improved. That is a debate between Senator Spindler and me that we have had a hundred times in this chamber. I do not expect my persuasive advocacy this time will change his views.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, and I ask: does the government maintain that the economic recovery is helping those most disadvantaged in the labour market? And, if so, what is the basis of such evidence?

—I am very pleased to have the chance to answer this question following on, as it does, from the answer that Senator Schacht has already given welcoming the fall in the unemployment rate to 9.1 per cent, which is the lowest level we have had in 3 1/2 years. The other side of that, which I am very pleased to be able to advise the Senate today, is that figures released on the number of jobsearch allowance and newstart allowance recipients for October do indeed show that the economic recovery is flowing through to the people who are unemployed. I believe that this question was something that Senator Hill interjected about in Senator Schacht's answer.

PARA.TAB: The number of recipients fell by 19,000 in the month and by 84,000 over the last year. This monthly fall of 19,000 follows a fall of 14,000 in September, 12,000 in August, and 13,000 in July. These reductions in recipient numbers have been widely spread, too, throughout the labour market; they have occurred in all states and territories and in 20 of the Department of Social Security areas.

Further, I think Senator Hill did ask something about young people. The number of young people actually aged under 18 receiving allowances also fell by more than 1,000 during the month and the number of people aged over 50 years receiving them also fell by more than 1,000. The number of women receiving allowances fell by 5,000 and the number of men by 14,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, youth unemployment is 28 per cent under your policies.
—Order! Senator Hill!
—She is referring to me.
—Senator Crowley, I would ask you not to, if you are doing that; answer the question.

—The number of newstart allowance recipients who are most disadvantaged in the labour market fell by 7,000 in the month and by 32,000 over the year to October. The figures show the government is achieving what the Prime Minister promised on election night—the unemployed are not being left behind. Indeed, that commitment shows up in these figures but it also shows up in the Working Nation document, the white paper. It, of course, is something that is of great concern to the community, as it is to this government.

PARA.TAB: In every one of the International Year of the Family discussions and consultations—I have mentioned these in this place before—the issue of income security or jobs for families has come up as one of the high priority issues. I am sure that the report coming from Professor Cass very soon to me will have recommendations about this matter. But it is not as though, as I have said, we have just discovered or will be waiting for those recommendations for this government to take action.

The figures already speak for this government's policies making a considerable difference. If one is not sure about it on the figures, one only has to look at that Working Nation document—a commitment by this government to forget no-one in this community. I believe that one will see, particularly with the social security changes under the One Nation statement, that our concern for people on benefits is shown in the commitment to reducing those numbers by getting people job opportunities and training and also by making those payments kinder through the introduction of the partner allowance and the income test for the jobsearch allowance. In all sorts of ways, the news that Senator Schacht reports and that I report is very encouraging indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I note that you acknowledged the call to me earlier. You seem to be confusing your role as that of President with that of Labor whip. My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Cook.

—Mr President, on a point of order. There are proper forms of decorum in this chamber and one of them is to give due respect to the chair. To make an allegation that reflects on your impartiality is offensive to the chair and senators who do that should be required to withdraw or themselves be prepared to withdraw.

—Mr President, on the point of order: Senator Spindler asked a question and when that question had been answered you then called me for my question. Senator Spindler then rose on a supplementary question, which was answered. Subsequently, you very deliberately did not call me, as previously acknowledged, but you gave the call to Senator Cooney. There was a deliberate action between yourself and the Labor side seeking to get the balance. Mr President, I am not disputing your impartiality as chairman, but you did not honour the commitment you gave from the chair.

—Mr President, on the point of order: what you did was follow the normal order, whether you called Senator Tambling by error or not. That happens in this chamber. Also, your view of half the chamber was obscured by people talking here; you could not even see Senator Spindler get to his feet. I say to Senator Tambling that there was really no insult meant by the chair. It was just a simple mistake.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I just want to get the situation quite clear. What Senator Tambling said is 100 per cent correct. Mr President, I watched you approach Senator Faulkner, who in turn approached Senator Foreman, who in turn approached Senator Cooney, to ask a question. You were acting as Labor Party whip to try to get someone to ask a question on the other side in the absence of one of them standing to ask a question, and at that time you asked Senator Tambling. So the statement that Senator Tambling made is quite correct. Mr President, you are playing two roles in this chamber, and that is unsatisfactory.

—Mr President, on the point of order: Senator Knowles, Senator Tambling and other senators might not have been aware at the commencement of question time when you gave the call to Senator Abetz and Senator Reid was on her feet that I drew your attention to the fact that one of the traditions, it may not be written in our standing orders, is that whips get precedence in questions in this chamber. Mr President, just for the opposition's information, I did approach you and indicate to you that had been the case. It is not an uncommon procedure in this chamber for the manager to discuss proceedings with the President, an Acting President or a Temporary Chairman. I can assure you, Mr President, that I will continue to ensure the good management of the chamber by involving myself in those sorts of actions with you or anyone else who occupies the chair.

—This is again much ado about nothing, I must say, but I can confirm that Senator Faulkner did approach me about Senator Reid and that it was drawn to my attention. She did get the call. What actually happened in this circumstance was that there is an agreement is between the parties that questions will be divided up strictly proportionately. That is not an easy thing to do sometimes, and I attempt to do that as much as I can. The party that is most disadvantaged by this is the government party, and I try to keep the questions as proportionate as possible.

PARA.TAB: In this case I would have called Senator Cooney, but he did not stand on the first occasion. I called Senator Tambling, but Senator Spindler came back with a supplementary question. When I called again or when the question rose again, Senator Cooney did rise. It was the government's turn so he got the question. There was certainly no offence meant to Senator Tambling. I will be balanced in this place, and the figures show that I am very balanced in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. On top of the recently increased interest rates, is the Australian Taxation Office preparing for another assault on embattled home buyers with a new sales tax on prefabricated factory-built family homes? When does the government propose to introduce this additional impost? Is the minister aware that this alternative form of housing is popular with elderly people and low income earners in metropolitan areas and will severely hurt Aboriginal communities in rural and remote areas of Australia with significant impact on the government's own budget?
—I have no briefing whatsoever that the tax office is planning such a tax. Therefore, I am not able to confirm—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There are persistent interjections that it has been in the press for a week. It may have been—it could have been for a month or a year—but I do not have a briefing confirming the issue that Senator Tambling has raised. Therefore, I cannot confirm that his allegation contains any truth at all. I am not in a position to confirm press leaks either. The point I make is that this question is also an inflammatory one aimed at startling home buyers and stirring problems, suggesting there will be problems which at this point, given the nature of my brief, are best described as illusory.
—What do you mean? You said you haven't got a brief.
—Yes, that is right.
—It's illusory, is it?

—Yes, it is illusory, unless I am briefed that it is true. Senator Hill may never serve in government and know how a ministerial office works, but let me assure him that if there were justification for such a story, I would have a brief before me.

PARA.TAB: I do know that the opposition has been speculating about interest rates and is continuing to do so. It is now in this form speculating further about imposts on home borrowers. The issue of alterations to interest rates is an indication of how strong the Australian economy is. It is an economy in strong growth. As we see today from the average weekly earnings figures, it is growth that is not being fuelled by wage-push inflation. Strong growth and low inflation—these are the problems of a growing economy.

That may not be something that is familiar to the opposition because when it had the chance it presided over deteriorating economies. This is a growing economy. The adjustments to interest rates which the Reserve Bank has undertaken, in the first instance, have not been fully passed on to home borrowers. Indeed, there is clear evidence of competition among banks, given the more competitive settings we have been able to introduce to ensure that there is still strong competition between them, not to pass on the full extent of the adjustments. Secondly, the purpose of making those adjustments is to ensure that inflation is kept under control or that larger interest rate adjustments do not occur in the future. In other words, they come into the category of responsibly managing an economy; that is what the Reserve Bank has tried to do, I believe successfully. It is because this is a strong and growing economy, producing the employment—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question was a very specific one: is there any truth in the rumours that a sales tax will be imposed upon low priced homes? Senator Cook has already admitted he does not know the answer. Now he is rambling on, filibustering, taking up question time. If he does not know the answer, he should sit down and allow further questions to be asked.
—On the point of order: if Senator Woods' point is right that this is a question based on rumours, it is clearly out of order because it is hypothetical.
—On the point of order: the question also contained reference to interest rates.
—I said `coming on top of high interest rates'. You can't get your words right.

—I thank Senator Tambling for the confirmation. The question contained reference to interest rates. That enabled me to answer that part of the question as well. I have concluded my answer, Mr President.
—On the point of order, I judged the question to be relevant, anyway.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am staggered at that answer. Not only was it in the Weekend Australian last weekend, which the minister obviously did not read, but it is also in a bulletin of the tax office—bulletin No. 23, produced by the withholding and indirect taxes program of the Australian Taxation Office, to apply from 1 November 1994. And the minister does not even have a brief on his desk! There is something wrong in the minister's communications. This is an issue that affects elderly people, it affects young people throughout Australia, it affects Aboriginal people, yet the minister is not in a position to confirm it and has the audacity to waffle on about the interest rates the government has already caused. My supplementary question is: will the minister deal with this matter as a matter of priority? Why should factory built homes be treated differently from homes constructed on-site? What has been the reaction of consumers and the building industry to this proposed new tax?

—I am a bit worried about Senator Tambling's health because for a moment I wondered whether he would be able to contain himself or whether we should adjourn the proceedings of this chamber so that he could calm down and assume a more reasonable demeanour.
—Mr President—
—Order! It is not relevant and I would ask you to answer the question instead of attacking the opposition.

—I do not have a brief on this matter. The fact that things are reported in the newspaper is incidental to that. My job here is to represent the Treasurer and to answer questions on his brief directly. I do not have one. Senator Tambling has drawn to my attention some other factors. I will take those into account. If there are other things that I can say in addition to the answer that I have given so far, upon advice from the Treasurer, I will give Senator Tambling a further answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Firstly, why is no information provided to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Australian Heritage Commission by the West Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management on logging operations in the WA central and Swan Forest regions about the export of woodchips and other forest products? Secondly, is it true that this is because there are no national estate areas in the region and because CALM asserts that there are no other reasons for it to provide the information? Thirdly, how does the government expect to ensure compliance with licence conditions when it is not provided with all the relevant information from the state agencies, such as CALM?

—The Minister for Resources has advised me that the answer to the first part of Senator Chamarette's question is that West Australian export woodchip operations outside the southern forest region do not involve the national estate and therefore do not require referral to the Australian Heritage Commission. Woodchips are not exported from the Swan Forest region. All approved export woodchip operations in Western Australia have been subject to environmental impact assessment to protect environmental values. Export woodchip operations in Western Australia's crown forests are managed by the state Department of Conservation and Land Management, known as CALM, according to a sustainable forest management plan, and compliance with the forest management plan is a requirement of export approval.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister informing me that the federal government is allowing 4,300 tonnes of woodchips to be exported from the Kerr Forest block in the south-west of Western Australia when CALM has not provided any information about this forest in the central forest region? Is he telling me that 4,300 tonnes of woodchip export licences have been approved by this government in an area where it does not have, and does not require, any information about the conservation values?
—I have nothing to add to the answer that I have just given Senator Chamarette.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. In light of the significant support that Senate amendments to the land fund bill have received from a broad range of Aboriginal organisations, does the government now recognise the legitimacy of claims that it has been listening selectively to advice coming from the Aboriginal community? Will the government—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order; it is a fairly stark one. Standing orders prohibit questions being asked on matters that are on the Notice Paper of the Senate. Not only is this on the Notice Paper, but we are actually in the middle of the debate and will start it again straight after question time, when I am sure the senator will have endless opportunities in the committee stage of the debate to ask any number of questions he likes.
—Mr President, on the same point of order: maybe some part of the question does not breach standing orders. Before you rule, I suggest we hear the whole of the question.
—I was about to make the point that I have not heard the question, so it is a bit hard to rule.

—Without repeating the first part, I will continue. Will the government acknowledge that the bill will now better reconcile different attitudes within the Aboriginal community and abandon its petulant proposal to withdraw the bill? Or does the government intend to continue relying on the advice of its small hand-picked group of advisers who have proved themselves to be less than fully representative of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups?

—Mr President, on a point of order. The question clearly relates to the fundamental question of the passage of the bill. I can assure the Senate that the bill will proceed and, hopefully, with the concurrence of the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens, move to its third reading today.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I do not quite know what that last intervention was all about. But the question that has been asked does not anticipate the debate at all. The question that has been asked relates to the government's assessment of Aboriginal opinion as it now stands in relation to the debate that has taken place. That is a legitimate question to ask, which does not anticipate the debate that is to follow this afternoon at all. In actual fact, it would be a very helpful answer to get, if the minister were prepared to answer the question. I wonder why he is so reluctant to answer it? Why do those opposite think he is so reluctant?

—Order! You have all drawn attention to the difficulty of making judgments in this area. There has generally been a very loose interpretation of what is meant by being before the chair, but it is being debated right now. I took that point of order in fact to be an answer from Senator Collins. I do not know whether you were intending it that way.

—I was, Mr President, but I will answer the question to make it clear. The bottom line, and I am sure Senator Calvert will confirm this, is that the question related—do not worry about the reasons—to whether the government would proceed with the carriage of the legislation. I answered it specifically. The legislation will proceed this afternoon, and it is the government's firm intention—and I will say it again—hopefully with the cooperation of the rest of the Senate, that we will move to the third reading today.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. There was another part to the question and that was: is the government still going to rely on the select group of advisers that it has on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, given the comments that have been made in the Aboriginal community about the advice he is getting on this particular bill?

—If Senator Calvert is asking me whether the government has reconsidered its opposition to the coalition's amendments to allow this fund to purchase property for individual Aboriginal people and allow them to sell that property five minutes after they get it, the answer is no, we will not reconsider our position to those outrageous amendments which I do not think would attract the support of the overwhelming majority of the Australian people. I think they are outrageous propositions, and the government will not reconsider on any advice our position that we will reject them.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the release today by the Australian Bureau of Statistics of preliminary estimates of average weekly earnings for August. I understand that the figures show a slight increase in wages growth for that month. In light of this, and the decrease in unemployment which has already been discussed today during question time, could the minister indicate to the Senate what the implications are for the economy and the outlook for inflation?
—I do have a brief on this matter.
—Not illusory?

—No, it is not illusory; it is a real brief. As the question implies, the Australian Bureau of Statistics today released the quarterly figures for the August quarter on average weekly earnings. The figures show that average weekly earnings for all employees rose by 1.1 per cent in original terms in the quarter and were 3.3 per cent higher than in August 1993. But the best measure for an accurate picture of what is happening in the earnings area is average weekly ordinary time earnings. On that index, for full-time adult employees the index increased by 0.4 per cent in original terms in the quarter, and was 2.9 per cent higher than in August 1993.

PARA.TAB: However, the underlying wage growth is lower than the gross figure of 3.3 per cent for the year, or 1.1 per cent for the quarter, than the AWE figure suggests. The reason is that underlying wage growth is best estimated by that second index I referred to, average weekly ordinary time earnings. This removes the influence of overtime, changes to part-time and full-time work, and the changed average hours worked by part-time employees. In seasonally adjusted and original terms, growth in average weekly ordinary time earnings in the year to August is 0.4 per cent lower—that is, a reduction—than it was in the year to May.

The other salient factor of this index that was released today is that the labour force survey indicates that part-time employment grew faster than full-time employment between May and August. Thus, the higher AWE figure cannot be explained by a reduction in the proportion of part-time employment. It is therefore likely—and I am quoting from the brief here—that the higher AWE growth is attributable to part-time employees working longer hours. In other words, not only are more Australians in work, as the employment figures have indicated, but the tendency is for those Australians in work to work longer and to earn more money in overtime.

The fundamental message in these figures is that there is no wage push on inflation. These figures are well below the inflation level; they are not exerting any upward push on inflation at all. Businesses that have regard to these figures can now factor into their long-term planning very low inflation horizons for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —But higher interest rates.

—No, very low inflation performance for the future. If we take these figures as well in terms of what is happening in the labour market, we have to consider that during the year 1993-94 productivity rose by 1.6 per cent in the community. A lot of the higher earnings that I have referred to are because wage increases have been generated by productivity increases; in other words, productivity is fuelling the economy and there is no cost push pressure of the sort that we saw during the Fraser years. That is a reference, too, to the fact that this government has been successful in generating workplace bargaining in the enterprise based on productivity as a way of capturing wage increases for workers in the community. It is the best scenario that we can have—high growth in the economy and low inflation.
—High interest rates.
—High growth and low inflation as a permanent feature of the economy—and it is by any measure, in any modern economy, in any developed society, very good news. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Why is Australia Post permitted to set up and promote shops, as in this promotional package I have here, which sell a wide range of stationery items from manufacturers like Faber-Castell, Pentel, Scotch and others, in full and open competition with private sector shops immediately after the government has initiated legislation which continues to prevent private sector competition with most of Australia Post's postal services?

—Australia Post has been operating in the commercial sector for years, and operating very effectively, I might add, in selling commercial packaging. Its ready-made packaging that it provides and sells across the counter is extremely useful. As far as the promotion Senator Chapman is talking about is concerned, I will refer that matter to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Australia Post is an extremely effective commercial enterprise and, I might add, has been made much more successful as a result of policy changes introduced by this government. I wonder whether, in conclusion, I might direct a question to the Leader of the Opposition and ask whether the federal coalition has been dissolved. I would like to know where the National Party is.
—No, you cannot, Senator Collins. Take your seat.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has missed the whole point of this question which is that what is good for the goose is good for the gander. The point of this question is that if it is good enough for Australia Post to be allowed to set up specific shops to sell stationery in direct competition with small business shops that traditionally sell these items, why is it not good enough for the private sector to be allowed to engage in full and open competition, with regard to postal services, against Australia Post?
—The supplementary question was simply a repetition of the original question. I have nothing to add to the answer that I gave.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. It relates to the government's commitment to phase out woodchipping by the year 2000 and particularly relates to the Australian Democrats' concerns that the Minister for Resources is considering increasing the tonnage in this year's woodchip licences by 1.5 million tonnes. Is there any logging in forests recognised by the federal department of the environment as having World Heritage value?

—In the first instance I can say to Senator Bell that there are no commercial forestry operations occurring in World Heritage areas. I understand that last year my portfolio provided advice to my predecessor, Mrs Kelly, that some areas of forest due to be logged in 1994 were identified as having World Heritage value. I understand also that that advice was given to the former Minister for Resources in the context of last year's round of woodchip export licence renewals. Obviously, the question does require some detailed analysis. I am happy to ask the new forest branch of my department to confirm the information that I have given. I do say to Senator Bell that the officers are very busy at this stage developing advice on the current round of licences.

PARA.TAB: With regard to this year's round of licence renewals, I am required as part of last year's cabinet decision to provide advice to the Minister for Resources on the applicability of the national forest policy statement to decisions on licence renewals. I have taken initiatives to identify areas that have been proposed for logging and those areas which are likely to have high conservation value and, therefore, might merit interim protection under the terms of the national forest policy statement. I think it is fair to say in relation to that issue that that exercise covers a range of values. Of course included in it is the issue of World Heritage values. Given that Senator Robert Ray has waved the white flag, I have taken that as a hint. As a result of that hint, I will conclude my answer at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am confused by the latest obfuscations. I wish to get this clear: did the minister say there are no logging operations in areas of World Heritage value?

—That is not what I said. Senator Bell will have to refer to my answer. I said categorically there are no commercial forestry operations in World Heritage areas. I then outlined information that had been made available to my predecessor, Mrs Kelly, and the then Minister for Resources last year. I have indicated to Senator Bell that, even though the forest branch of my department is under great pressure at this time of year, I will confirm the details of the process that I outlined in my original answer. But I have made it categorically clear that, within the boundaries of World Heritage areas, there are no commercial forestry operations. And we welcome back some of the members of the National Party from their plotting.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Senator Chapman asked me during question time today a question relating to Australia Post. I gave an undertaking to ask the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) for information, and he has very promptly provided it to me. Under the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989, Australia Post is required to perform its functions in a manner consistent with sound commercial practice. Like any other efficient enterprise, Australia Post continually reviews its services by examining costs, revenue and performance, including most importantly the capacity to meet contemporary customer needs.

PARA.TAB: Against this background I understand Australia Post is currently implementing an extensive modernisation of its retail network, known as Retail Post, which focuses on better meeting customer needs while eliminating over time the significant losses incurred by the network. The loss incurred in 1992-93 was around $60 million. Australia Post has advised that the basic tenet for this new retail direction is to improve customer service.

Market surveys have confirmed Australia Post's view that customers want the convenience of one-stop shopping. To this end, Australia Post has opened a number of new retail outlets that feature new points of sale technology and an extended product range, including stationery and cards. Australia Post advises that the products are priced in accordance with normal retailing principles and are not subsidised by postal revenue.

Some claims have been made by newsagents that the sale of stationery, cards and other postal related products by Australia Post is somehow inconsistent with its functions under the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989. Australia Post's view, confirmed by independent legal advice, is that the sale of these products is fully consistent with its functions and powers as set out in sections 14 to 18 of the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to Senator Reid's question about whether or not people are receiving home child-care allowance payments, I am advised that more than 500,000 families are currently receiving payments of the home child-care allowance. Around 80 per cent of these are receiving payment at the maximum rate, compared with around 60 per cent receiving the maximum rate of dependent spouse with child rebate in the 1992-93 tax year.

PARA.TAB: The vast bulk of all claims received to date have been processed and paid where people are eligible. Some families who have not provided all information necessary to determine their claims would not be receiving their payments yet but will do so as soon as all necessary information is provided and the claims are processed.

I take this opportunity to remind the Senate and Australian families that all those who have not yet claimed the home child-care allowance or are in the process of completing their forms will be back paid to 29 September 1994 so long as they lodge the forms by 3 January 1995 and of course are eligible. I am happy to follow up any specific cases that Senator Reid might want to refer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Reid this day, relating to the home child-care allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: The important aspect of this matter is that the department has indicated to some people that it is very behind with payments. Husbands in families will lose the benefit of the deduction that they previously had under the dependent spouse rebate. That is making things difficult for those families when budgeting. I would contrast the difference between this scheme and the child-care rebate which is not means tested and which can be obtained so easily. The families affected by this situation are frequently those with less income. By losing the dependent spouse rebate they lose about $28 a week in the husband's take home pay.

PARA.TAB: It is all very well to say that it will be back paid, but in the meantime it is making life very difficult for these families. I would urge the minister to make sure that the department is up to date with payments. Some people may not have provided enough information, which may not be their fault. It is something new and difficult. At this stage families do not need to be left with less income than they would normally have had. It is quite clear that $27.50 a week is a big reduction in the breadwinner's pay packet. A lot of families still function on that basis. It is very important that this money becomes available very quickly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Reid for those comments. The important point Senator Reid raised was that those payments are getting out of kilter. I take note of Senator Reid's comment about a backlog of payments from the department. I will follow that up. Senator Reid can be assured that we would like to see that in harmony because the point she makes about a reduction of $28 or more per week in a family's pay packet is a very significant amount.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Chapman this day, relating to Australia Post.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister has come back at the end of question time with a supplementary answer to my question about why Australia Post should be allowed to set up these Australia Post shops. The promotional material which I have, and which I displayed at question time—the 1994 post shop stationery catalogue—says `welcome to the post shop stationery'.

PARA.TAB: In his supplementary answer, the minister said that the capacity for Australia Post to establish and promote the shops is consistent with the act under which Australia Post operates. I assume he meant the pre-existing act. I am not sure whether the bill that recently passed through the Senate has been proclaimed; I expect it has not. That legislation amended the operation of Australia Post to some small degree.

The minister does not seem to recognise that there is an inherent inconsistency in Australia Post operating in this way. He says that under the existing act it is quite allowable and quite acceptable for Australia Post to set up stationery shops. It is not simply the postal services that are expanding or being added to. Australia Post is setting up specific stationery shops which will sell writing instruments, pads, books, envelopes, accessories, filing and storage material, business machine supplies, social stationery—a wide range of stationery items. As I said in my question, the shops will sell ballpoint pens, marking pens and rollerball pens produced by private sector manufacturers such as Fabercastel, Pentel, Bic and others.

All of these sorts of items will be selling in these shops in direct competition with the private sector, particularly stationery shops, which by and large are part of the small business sector. So here we have one of Australia's major government-owned corporations, the primary purpose of which is to provide postal services for the Australian community, setting up auxiliary businesses which really do not have any relationship to the postal services they are providing—if there is any relationship, it is extremely tenuous; I would say that there is no real relationship to their primary purpose of providing postal services—to sell these private sector stationery items. That is what is happening, on the one hand.

On the other hand, a piece of legislation has just gone through this place which continues the very severe restrictions on the private sector's capacity to compete with Australia Post in the provision of postal services. The legislation that went through this chamber did not allow any significant competition with Australia Post or adequate levels of competition with regard to the provision of courier services. It did not allow extended competition with Australia Post in the provision of direct mail services. In a whole range of other postal services, the legislation that went through this chamber continued the monopoly powers of Australia Post in the provision of postal services.

This is the sort of inconsistency we see on the part of this government. It is quite all right for one of its government business enterprises to set up direct competition with struggling small businesses, but it is not allowable for the same sorts of businesses to compete with Australia Post in postal services. What is good for the goose is good for the gander. If we are going to have Australia Post competing with small businesses in the provision of items that are traditionally the preserve of small businesses, then give them a fair go. Let us have decent competition for Australia Post allowed in the provision of postal services.

It is something I would have thought the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht, would have been taking a keen interest in, as the portfolio minister responsible for the health of small business. But we have seen small business in this country battered from pillar to post by the high interest rates and other policies of this government which have been particularly detrimental to the business climate.

Small business does not get a fair go from this government's general economic policies. Now we see small business not getting a fair go from this government's quite specific policies in the operation of government business enterprises.

This inequality in the way small business is treated is grossly unfair. It is something the government ought to look at very closely and do something about to ensure that there is not this inequality. If there is competition on one side, then the competition equally ought to be allowed on the other side.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator McKiernan this day, relating to unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: A typical example of the absolute arrogance of the Labor Party and the way it conducts government is that it is saying that the unemployment figures are tremendous and a good indication of where Australia should be going.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say that.

—All around the country, Senator Sherry, all of your people have been putting out press releases for the last hour saying what marvellous news it is that we now have only 800,000 people unemployed. The number of unemployed has fallen very marginally. But that is not a time for good news and rejoicing. What about the 800,000 workers—
—What about the new jobs created?

—Senator Burns is not interested in the workers. What about the 800,000 unemployed workers that Senator Burns's leader said we had to have in a recession? It was he who created the recession. He wanted those people unemployed because he thought that was what the country needed—just the same as he is now saying that interest rate rises are the interest rate rises we have got to have. What absolute arrogance from a government made up of a bunch of former union organisers and Labor Party hacks!

PARA.TAB: No wonder we get these sorts of decisions from the government. What about the real human tragedy of those 800,000 workers who want a job and cannot get one because the government has no interest in the real workers, no interest in those people who want to work? All the government can do is spend more money and push up interest rates to get the unemployed off the statistics by putting them into training schemes. The government spends money it does not have by putting them into training schemes for jobs they will not have at the end of those schemes. That is what is wrong with this government.

One can understand that arrogance coming from a bunch of ministers most of whom have spent their working lives as trade union officials never having to worry about a decent day's work. Other than that they have worked as hacks for the Australian Labor Party. That is why this country is in the mess it is in. To address those 800,000 workers who want a job, this country needs the government to get off the backs of small business. Senator Schacht is supposedly the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. His background in small business—

TALK.START.PARA: —Like you did with provisional tax.

—Hello! There is the fourth wing of the Labor Party, supporting it again, sticking up for their factional mates. Senator Kernot is always in their favour—we know that. Can Senator Kernot tell me whether her interjection has been approved by her president? I understand the Democrats have to get approval from their national president before they can criticise the leader any more. Senator Coulter has been carpeted because he chose to say what everybody knows, that Senator Kernot's leadership of the Democrats has taken her party straight down. Senator Coulter was carpeted by the federal executive of the party—if the Democrats have such a thing—for the criticism. Senator Kernot should stand up for herself. If she wants to discipline Senator Coulter, she should do it herself and not get her national president to do it. So there we are: the Democrats are again sticking up for the left wing, sticking up for the Labor Party, as they always do.

PARA.TAB: One must get small business working in this country. Senator Schacht has no idea of that. His qualifications for being the small business minister are that he was a teacher and then a Labor Party hack. What a great background for a small business minister! He would not understand, he would not have a clue. And we have Senator Burns from the unions and Senator Sherry from the unions—these are the sorts of people who are running the country!

We have to get government off the backs of small business. That is the only way to increase employment and make real, long-term jobs available. Right around regional Australia the statistics on those still looking for a job and unable to get one are an absolute tragedy. This government is not interested. If we get rid of taxes and make the industrial relations system a bit more flexible, we will encourage small business to expand and, in doing so, create real jobs. We will then not have this tragedy of 800,000 unemployed—a tragedy about which this crew opposite is today running around Australia saying, `Isn't that brilliant?' I do not think 800,000 people without a job is worth rejoicing about; it is a tragedy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take note of the same answer but in doing so point out the absolute hypocrisy in Senator Ian Macdonald's remarks. Just two weeks ago in this place, Senator Macdonald and his party declined to reduce the provisional tax uplift factor for small business. He is there shouting, `Remove the tax off the back of small business.' He had an opportunity to do it two weeks ago and he did not do it. He has lost any credentials that he may ever thought he had as a friend of small business in this place. He should go out and ask small business about it.

PARA.TAB: What weak excuse did the opposition give? It said, `Terribly sorry, we can't plunder the public revenue.' What was the answer to that? Over two years it cost nothing! The second excuse was, `Sorry, we can't block supply.' It has nothing to do with supply, as well Senator Macdonald knows. The third excuse was, `Honestly, we understand it is a huge impost on small business. We'd like to acknowledge that but we can't actually do anything about it at the moment. But we will put the government on notice that we will do something about it next year.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I know that you have always ruled that the debate on taking note of answers is wide ranging. Senator Kernot has now been speaking for the best part of a minute and has not related her remarks one iota to the answer given during question time. Mr Deputy President, I ask you to gently remind her that her contribution should have some relevance to the answer she is taking note of.

—On a point of order, if we look at the precedent that Senator Ian Macdonald set, we see that his contribution was pretty wide ranging. I do not think Senator Kernot is traversing any broader subject matter than Senator Macdonald did.
—On a point of order, Senator McKiernan's question to Senator Schacht related to today's unemployment figures, in case Senator Kernot does not remember. My speech was entirely on unemployment.
—I am able to make a ruling, Senator Kernot, if you are happy for me to do so.

—On that point of order: Senator Campbell said that I spoke for one minute without addressing the question. I go back to the allocation of time that Senator Ian Macdonald used in his speech and the amount of time he spent misrepresenting the position of the Democrats.

—I think it is fair to say that I allowed Senator Macdonald to discuss trade union officials, Labor Party employees and the general role of the Democrats and their President. It is probably not inappropriate that Senator Kernot has some licence to travel through the debate.
—I will try to link the two strands.
—Don't forget the President of your party, too!

—That is right, I have to make a note of that, too. It is rather rich of Liberal Party senators to be in here talking about leadership at this point in time when the press gallery is rife with rumours of the latest gaffe and the latest number counting that is going on within that party. I can agree with some things Senator Macdonald said. Putting people in training positions for jobs which will not be there is not necessarily a solution. We all know what has been done to retention rates in schools and the way those numbers are counted.
—Mature age allowance.

—Yes, the mature age allowance. Similar things can be done with employment statistics. If Senator Macdonald were serious about removing some of the imposts from small business, he could have taken the opportunity to do so two weeks ago. He did not.

—I want to also make some comments about the question asked of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Senator Schacht) about the latest unemployment figures. The tragedy of unemployment in Australia is ongoing. Every Australian will welcome the upturn in the economy after Australia's deepest recession in 60 years and the highest unemployment rate in living memory. The reality is that for young Australians—on whom I now have to focus a lot of attention as the shadow minister with responsibility for youth affairs—the government's Working Nation document aims to reduce unemployment in Australia to five per cent by the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: The point was made very well yesterday by Julian Pocock, Executive Director of APAC, the peak youth organisation. For young Australians, this means that the federal government has adopted an unemployment target of 15 per cent. Julian made a very good point yesterday when he said that politicians should go to primary schools because, by the year 2000, it is young Australians now in grade six who will be entering the employment market. He said that we need to pick out 15 per cent of the children in a class of 30 and say, `The Australian Labor Party's policy is to ensure that 15 per cent of your class will be highly unlikely to get a full-time job in the year 2000.' That is the human tragedy that Senator Macdonald referred to.

We must all welcome the turnaround and growth in employment. We must also look at the other problems in the Australian economy. The poor people who get jobs these days have bought houses in the hope of an economic recovery. A hell of a lot of people have believed the rhetoric of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer (Mr Willis), who are saying that we have this brilliant recovery, and have bought a house. More people have bought houses in the last year or so than ever before. We have been told, `It is all hunky-dory. The economy is going along very nicely.'

But what happens? We had the admission by Senator Cook in another answer today that interest rates are going up and that that is just a natural part of a booming economy. As Senator Kemp interjected, if interest rates hit 20 per cent, will that mean we have got a really good economy? We are heading into double digit interest rates again. Those in middle Australia with the Australian dream of owning a home are now being forced to pay $100 or more a month extra for the privilege of having a house and a mortgage, and $100 would go a heck of a long way towards paying for a week's groceries. I know in my home we used to be able to buy a week's groceries for $100. For mum and dad with a couple of kids and their grocery bill, by the time interest rates reach the 11 or 12 per cent mark, they will be up to $100 to $150 a month worse off. That will impact on middle Australia very badly.

Senator Macdonald made the point that fundamental reform of the Australian economy means getting away from centralised labour laws. We have seen the most massive centralisation of labour laws in Australian history in the last two years—more central control than ever before. We have training systems that are not working. We have a community sector which is dealing with the problems of youth unemployment, youth homelessness, youth suicide, youth drug abuse, vandalism, crime and graffiti. Non-profit community organisations such as the Salvation Army and the Central City Mission—a whole range of community initiated groups—are struggling to meet these overwhelming needs, and we have this crisis out there.

The government is promising young Australians a 15 per cent youth unemployment rate by the year 2000. I do not think any of us can accept that that is a worthy target. So every time these employment figures come through, we should, of course, welcome them. Every time someone who has been unemployed gets a job, that is a welcome relief for one family somewhere in Australia. But we should never lose sight of those young Australians, particularly in the 15- to 25-year-old age group, who have no hope of getting a job. They are totally dejected about the training schemes. They know that they go into many of these training schemes, come out at the other end and there are still no jobs.

Even though, as Senator Kernot pointed out, retention rates are rising, what Mr Pocock pointed out yesterday, quite rightly, was that the retention rates do not look at what is happening to kids under the age of 15. We have the greatest drop-out rate and truancy rates that this nation has ever seen. We have the highest youth suicide rates in the world. It is a national disgrace. It comes back to the failure by this government to implement fundamental economic reforms—reforms that could change the lives of so many Australians right across this nation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Patterson proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of this government's economic and social policies over eleven years, evidenced by the widening gap between the rich and the poor in Australia and the shameful situation that in the International Year of the Family two thirds of the 1.8 million Australians living in poverty are members of families with children.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Patterson, I understand that informal arrangements have been entered into between the whips providing specific times for the speakers during today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I propose to ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, cringes every time he goes to an official function where the national anthem is played. If he does not, he ought to. Every time he hears the strains of Advance Australia Fair, what ought to be going through his mind is that he and his party—he as Treasurer and then as Prime Minister—have created a situation whereby what we now have is `advance Australia unfair'. That is exactly what is happening in this country. So every time he hears the national anthem, I hope he hears that refrain—`advance Australia unfair'—because that is exactly what has happened.
