PARA.TAB: Mr Hawke said to us that by 1990 no Australian child would live in poverty. It is a memorable quote, and we keep reminding members of the Labor Party that that is what he said. I suppose they cringe when they hear that, too—like they ought to cringe when they hear the national anthem. Two years later, on 12 April 1989, Mr Keating said in parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result—
of the new tax scales—
we will achieve this year the child poverty benchmarks promised by the Prime Minister—well ahead of the 1990 target.

Mr Keating blithely makes these sorts of promises. He tells us that we will have tax cuts that are l-a-w and, as soon as the election is over, those tax cuts disappear. He tells pensioners that they will be taken out of the tax system and, five days after the election, that promise disappears.

PARA.TAB: As I said before, all that is being advanced in this country is in fact a lack of fairness. What we are seeing is an ever increasing gap between the rich and the poor. The fact is that almost 700,000 Australian children are living in poverty in 1994. We can flip figures around so that they do not sound very much. But we are talking about 700,000 children. That is a disgrace. For those of us who grew up in a country in respect of which we were proud to use the words `advance Australia fair', it is a disgrace that there are 700,000 children currently living in poverty. The gap between the rich and the poor is widening.

TAB.TAB: Mr Keating said earlier this year:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are saying as a society we won't have an underclass. If the Americans want an underclass they can have one. If the British want an underclass they can have one. But we won't have one.

I have news for Mr Keating: Australia now ranks third amongst western countries in the unequal distribution of income for families—just below the UK and the US. Australia also ranks third in terms of the lowest proportion of income in the hands of the poorest 20 per cent. The message to Mr Keating is that we have an underclass and it has developed over the 11 years that he has been pulling the levers in government.

PARA.TAB: The irony of the situation we now find ourselves in is that Australia has always prided itself on being an egalitarian country where most people are relatively well off and the differential between the rich and the poor is not as great as in many other countries.
This is increasingly not the case under this current government. A headline in the Sydney Morning Herald of 3 November read `Something's rotten in the land of fair go'. The article went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We Australians like to think we live in a pretty egalitarian country, so that while there are some rich people and some poor people, most of our national wealth is divided up with the evenhandedness you'd expect of a society without an inherited class structure. And if there were some inequalities in the past, 11 years of government by a party committed to a fair distribution of income would certainly have ironed them out. Not so!
They have not been ironed out; they have been made worse.

PARA.TAB: The government would have us believe that we live in an era of social nirvana. We have only to look at three important measures and their social indicators to comprehend the huge deception being perpetrated by this government. If we look at the number of long-term unemployed in this country, we see that the number is exploding. Last year or the year before I predicted that we would have 300,000 long-term unemployed people.

I remember former Senator Richardson mocking me across the chamber because I had the audacity to predict that there would be 300,000 long-term unemployed. We now have 410,000 people unemployed. I wonder whether he would laugh at those predictions across the chamber now. As I said, he mocked me across the chamber because I said that I thought in a year's time we would have 300,000 long-term unemployed people. Unfortunately, I have been shown to be correct. Worse than that, the figure is much higher.

The other thing that causes the gap between the rich and the poor in this country to widen is that this government has allowed the net foreign debt to increase seven-fold from the time it came to power. In 1983 the net foreign debt was $23 billion; in June of this year it was $161 billion. We cannot continue to live beyond our means in that way without there being ramifications.

One of the ramifications of living beyond our means is that we see an ever growing gap between the rich and the poor. We only have to look at some of the facts. Sole parents continue to be the group most likely to be in poverty. About one in every five sole parents lives in poverty, and there are estimated to be 232,000 people living in poverty in sole parent families.

The second most likely group to be living in poverty, just under one in every five, is the younger singles, or the non-elderly single people. Couples with children are the third group most at risk with 12 per cent being below the Henderson poverty line. There are an estimated 933,000 people in couple with children families who are living below the poverty line.

What is the government's response to this undeniably shameful record? It is painfully predictable. When Mr Keating answered a question the other day he rolled out his script, rolled out the sort of lines that he likes to use to salve his conscious and hide the figures and the facts. How did he explain that the rich had got richer and the poor had got poorer, and that this had increased over the 11 years that Labor has been in power? He did not have the answers.

Mr Keating stood there, he shot the messengers in the foot by castigating the reports of people who have said that this is happening. He gave us a whole lot of figures. He fudged around. He did not tell us the facts in the answer to that question. He said that the Labor government had addressed poverty through employment growth, through transfer payments of over $6 billion such as family allowance, et cetera, and through tax cuts. Then he said—I found this amazing—that the tax-free threshold is $5,400. In 1983, when the coalition was in government, it was $4,750.

Taking those figures into account in terms of the rate of inflation, if the tax-free threshold was going to be at the level it was in 1983, it should be around $8,500. How he could stand there and give us the tax-free threshold figure—considering what it was in 1983 and what it is now—and not index it is beyond my comprehension. But that is the sort of fudging he does all the time. He makes the figures fit his story, which is fallacy, which is fabricated and which does not hide anything from the Australian public, because they know. They see poverty every day; they see people lining up at the welfare agencies looking for assistance and help.

He either ignores or he does not realise—but I do not think that is the case; I think he most probably chooses to ignore—the statements made recently by a large number of people who are highly regarded in this area. For example, the director of the Social Policy Research Centre at the University of New South Wales, Dr Peter Saunders, stated that poverty grew rapidly in the 1980s despite growth in employment and the introduction of the family allowance supplement for workers on low incomes.

In May 1994 the Australian Bureau of Statistics released a study called Australian Social Trends, a survey which showed that since Labor came to power, Australia has experienced growing income inequality, rising welfare dependency, greater family breakdown, the emergence of a working poor and an alarming surge in the suicide rate of young men. Those figures are there for us to see.

A Bureau of Immigration and Population Research study, commissioned by the Bureau of Immigration and Population Research and the Brotherhood of St Laurence, released on 30 September 1994 found that an increasing number of children from non-English speaking backgrounds are living in poverty and sometimes going without food or adequate clothing. Then we see another study by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling, University of Canberra, a report released in the middle of this year. Professor Ann Harding reported that the rise in unemployment and the decline in full-time male employment between 1990 and 1993 would lead to a greater increase in inequality in the early 1990s than was experienced in the 1980s.

Last week Ann Harding again presented a paper titled Poverty and Inequality in September 1994 to the ACOSS national congress which reported that 11 per cent of Australians now live in after-house poverty. How many studies and how many reports does Mr Keating have to see before he will admit that there is a growing gap between the rich and the poor, brought on and induced by this Labor government and its policies?

In fact, the greatest gap is between those families that we read about in those reports—those families who are struggling to pay their electric light bills, to find somewhere to live and to keep food on the table for their children—and Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, who is spending his time planning his retirement in his $2.2 million house. That is where the biggest gap is, between the poor in Australia and our rich Prime Minister, who chooses to engage in buying French clocks and a $2.2 million house. `Advance Australia unfair' is the refrain we ought to be hearing in our national anthem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Patterson was doing well until the last bit. She particularly referred to the rising gap between rich and poor, especially in this International Year of the Family. It is very difficult to argue this MPI because it is based on a false premise; there is no rising gap between rich and poor in Australia. I will spend the time allotted to me trying to explain—
—Tell Ann Harding that.

—I will, certainly, and I will quote Ann Harding. Senator Patterson is lifting quotes from Ann Harding for her preferred view and is therefore skewing the debate. But there is no rise in the gap between rich and poor. That is because this federal government has taken steps, including and in particular the social wage elements, that are never calculated into the measures of equality and inequality.

PARA.TAB: I might also say that we might well sing Advance Australia Fair. We have not been singing it for all that long. We would like to think that Australia is a fair and even country. This year in my state we are celebrating the centenary of women's suffrage. That means that we have a lot of opportunities to look at what the world was like 100 years ago in South Australia when it was anything but fair. To suggest that 100 years ago in South Australia for women—or for men or for families—everything was equal and fair and that we have made it worse is an absolute nonsense, just the same as it is a nonsense to talk about equality during the Depression or to say that there was not much trouble during the war years or even during the halcyon years of the 1950s and 1960s.

In the last 11 years of Labor government there has been a dramatic improvement in the lot of people in this country, and no widening of the gap. If we spend the time this afternoon, as I suspect we will, with my quoting my sources and Senator Patterson quoting her sources, I do not suppose we will feel any more convinced at the end of the time. But I think it important to put on the record some of this government's achievements and, in particular, to again remind those opposite that none of the calculations of poverty or measurements of inequality calculate in the social wage, which has made such a considerable difference not only to the quality of people's lives but also to how they are able to manage their lives.

First of all, let me say that there has been great growth in jobs in this government's time. There are now two million more jobs; a 26 per cent increase in employment. I am very heartened by the figures we have heard today which suggest—in fact they do not suggest; they actually make quite clear—that the recovery in the economy is now being seen in jobs and in the falling number of people relying on pension benefits. Evidence relating to newstart allowances is that those payments have fallen by 25,000 in the last six months.

We have also established a wages system with an award safety net, and social security payments have dramatically increased during the life of this government. The base pension rate is up 15 per cent relative to the CPI. If we include rent assistance, particularly for those people who are able to be assisted in that way, the increase is from 106 per cent to 113 per cent of the so-called Henderson poverty line. Sole parent pensioners with two children, renting privately, have had a 37 per cent increase in real terms, from 91 per cent to 103 per cent above the poverty line. Family payments for low income families are up by 50 per cent to 100 per cent, depending on the age and the number of children.

Senator Patterson has not mentioned these factors. Of course, they do not fit easily with the thesis that she is running this afternoon. It is important to note what I said in question time today and what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has often said—that what our Working Nation white paper is about is making absolutely sure that our commitment is to every Australian having a decent and reasonable way of life. That is what our social security payments are about. In the past people eked out a very miserable existence or had no access to social security at all. I can remind those opposite what it was like in Australia 100 years ago and of what in fact it was that women were campaigning for: improving the lot of families, a fair wage, equal pay, health—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not talking about 100 years ago; we are talking about now.

—Yes, but you were talking about how good it was in the past. I thought I would give Senator Patterson a real example of how bad it was in the past and of how much better it has become since then, and of how much better it is since even 10 years ago.
—It is definitely better than 100 years ago.
—I am glad you admit that.
—I didn't say anything about 100 years ago.

—Let us not be too romantic when we look at it with a rosy glow and say, `All was good then.' Let us just look at how it was 11 years ago. That is what you were talking about—11 years ago. I have just read the figures that point out how inequality, the gap between the poor and the rich, is not as Senator Patterson says because in particular of the increase in payments, which means that people have an assurance of food and shelter and assistance with the rent—all benchmarked and indexed payments on behalf of children, particularly those in low income families. All those things are in place, and all those things have dramatically increased in the life of this government. They are real increases, not just increases.

PARA.TAB: This fact is not captured in many of the academic studies, which generally use the ABS distribution survey. That undercounts social security and veterans' affairs expenditure by $3 billion. A few other important things do not get counted: Medicare, for example, whereby families earning below about $20,000 and single people earning about $11,000—I do not have exact figures—do not have to contribute to the Medicare levy. Those families have complete health coverage with not $1 outlay by them.

The number of people who have gained access to an education in the life of this government has gone up. The number of students and children remaining at school to year 12 has increased from 37 per cent or thereabouts when we came into office—and that was a disgrace the Fraser government left us with—to around 80 or 85 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is 11 years ago, not 100 years ago.

—Yes, it is, and we have more than doubled it in our years. Those in the coalition ran it down; they did not care about the children of Australia, but we do. We have given them education opportunities; we are giving them training and tertiary opportunities in numbers that have never been known before, and Australian families are benefiting from it. Those things do not get factored into the equality measures; and neither does housing or child care. Those opposite howl in horror when I point out that there were 46,000 child-care places when we came into office and that now there are a quarter of a million—a five times increase—and that those places are available and affordable because of child-care assistance, and are of quality because of our national child-care accreditation program.

PARA.TAB: These things are not factored in or measured as part of the benefits families have, yet they must be, because they are the things enabling families to do many things—to go to work; to study; to train; to participate in voluntary work; and to contribute to the community in all sorts of ways. Those sorts of things make a difference about whether people feel all right and feel as though they are participating in our society. No academic study takes all services into account.

A paper by the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling at the University of Canberra shows that, when health and housing benefits are taken into account, the inequality falls by over 20 per cent. A recent article by Peter Whiteford, a leading Australian academic in this area, compared Australia's performance with that of the UK between 1983 and 1990, and he concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: Living standards were higher and inequality slightly lower in 1990 than when Labor took office. If poverty is measured by reference to a constant real poverty line, then poverty had fallen substantially.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is one person's view.

—Senator Patterson has only one or two people to quote. We have a major difference in the assessments. I am not suggesting that we are complacent; indeed, we are not. That is why we have the white paper, the commitment to people who are unemployed, the jobs compact payments and so on. We are committed to having a truthful analysis of these arrangements. Senator Patterson is saying that there is a gap. For a number of reasons, I am saying that there is no gap. One reason is that a lot of the things like the social wage are not counted in the equation; another is that what I would call very reasonable and honourable critics conclude quite differently. Mr Whiteford also said:

SPEECH.PARA: Many critics considered only part of what has happened over that period since 1983 . . . It is the partial nature of such analysis that leads to misleading conclusions.

I suspect that Senator Patterson and I would probably much rather try to tackle these problems based on accurate conclusions rather than misleading ones. Perhaps the most comprehensive work in this area has been carried out by Travers and Richardson, published last year in their book Living Decently. I will quote one of the things they said:

At the end of the 1980s most Australians were indeed `living decently'. Material affluence was at an all-time high. Australia was not the world-leader in equality, but it still ranked around the middle of the dozen most equal countries in the world. Australia is a world-leader when it comes to social mobility; that is, both privilege and disadvantage are less likely to be inherited in Australia than in any other country. There is disadvantage, of course, but one of our more positive findings is that disadvantage in one aspect of life is often offset by advantages elsewhere. Our positive picture of high levels of affluence and of relative equality is at variance with the `gloom and doom' that is typical of many editorial writers and political and social commentators.

I will move on to some figures about the so-called comments attributed to Ann Harding and the claim that her papers purport to show that 1.8 million Australians are living in poverty. These figures are a gross exaggeration. Indeed, Professor Harding herself suggests that her work should be used in analysing the distribution of poverty, not its total level. Her analysis uses the so-called Henderson poverty line—an arbitrary line based on the 1966 basic wage, adjusted for family composition according to a study conducted in New York in 1954. By fairly common agreement, it is no longer a reliable baseline which, by the way, has increased by 16 per cent over the last decade as a result of increasing household disposable incomes, partly as a result of rising labour force participation by women. This means that this poverty measure has the perverse result that rising affluence in the 1980s actually increased poverty. So I do not believe we can settle for those kinds of conclusions.

PARA.TAB: An earlier study by Harding which used actual social security payments suggested that there may be as few as zero sole parents in poverty. We have to appreciate that these studies do not include all of the same data, nor do they compare apples with apples or pears with pears. It is difficult to make any reasonable conclusion on studies that are not using the same data, not analysing all of it in the same way or, in fact, including much of the social wage data anyhow.

Another problem with this study is that it ignores assets. A business person, for example a farmer, with substantial assets but having one bad year is counted as poor or a family which has deliberately taken on a large mortgage in order to buy a large house may be counted as poor. Members of the opposition quoted an article from the Economist—from my reading of what happens in the other place, they often quote from this publication. That article purports to compare inequality across countries but it uses completely different data from country to country. For some countries it uses tax data; for Australia it uses income distribution survey data which undercounts over $3 billion in social security and welfare payments.

We have to be careful here. We have to know what the opposition would do about these questions. The rate of employment growth under Labor is 2 1/2 to three times what it was under Mr Fraser's government. We are doing the job in terms of jobs; the coalition did not.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't compare apples with pears.

—It is very interesting that Senator Patterson is touchy about that. Here are a few more facts to get touchy about. Pension rates, when measured against the CPI, have increased by 15 per cent under this Labor government but fell by two per cent under the Fraser government. The evidence shows that countries that have experienced the greatest increase in inequality are those countries that have implemented the sorts of labour market policies proposed by the opposition. One example of this is the United Kingdom. The opposition wanted to slash $10 billion off the social wage at the time of last year's election—and it still tells us it wants to slash the deficit. There is only one place we can go to slash the deficit—that is into welfare; cutting welfare payments.

PARA.TAB: How can those opposite stand here and say that they would like to see a more equal world when they are determined to reduce the opportunities for people at the lowest end of the scale, the poor? I cannot accept that analysis. I would like to quote what Mr Howard said on the score of helping families in poverty. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me pay a tribute to the Labor government. The family assistance supplement—
now renamed—
which supplements the income of low income working families has been a successful and well targeted social welfare measure of enormous benefit to low income households.

Mr Howard's policy of splitting incomes to help families contradicts his words of praise for the Labor government. I also worry about the policies of Senator Minchin, who wants universal family payments that effectively would take $70 off people at the lowest end and redistribute it to people at the top end. The coalition's policies do not stand up; our policies are delivering.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1987, the then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, coined that now infamous quote—some say epitaph—`By 1990, no Australian child will live in poverty.' In 1994, the Year of the Family, nearly 20 per cent of Australia's children live in a family with no breadwinner. Only three short years after that ill-fated date in 1987, and some 11 years under the Labor government, Australia is no closer to solving the problem of inequality and poverty. In fact, studies show that during the past decade, poverty and inequality have risen dramatically. Poverty, Adam Smith wrote, is `not having enough to live without shame in your own community'. In communities around this country it seems that more and more Australians are forced to live in shame.

PARA.TAB: Within 30 years Australia has gone from being the most egalitarian nation in the world to one of the most unequal. According to a recent world competitiveness report, out of 18 similar industrialised nations, Australia ranked as the least equitable nation as far as wealth distribution was concerned. In addition, Australia has the dubious honour of having one of the highest levels of affluence coupled with one of the highest levels of poverty in the industrialised world.

Ironically, Australians have always considered themselves to be part of an egalitarian society, a homogeneous middle-class society free from the vast disparities of wealth evident in other nations. Yet this perception of a middle-class society is nothing more than a myth, a vestige of the 1950s and 1960s ethos when the middle-class was a growing sector in our society. In the 1990s we are a much more polarised society. Australia's middle class is shrinking while both ends of the economic spectrum are growing.

In Australia today, the wealthiest one per cent control around 25 per cent of the nation's wealth while the top 10 per cent control around 60 per cent. This contrasts dramatically with the poorest 40 per cent of people in the country who, only a decade ago, controlled 22 per cent of the nation's wealth; whereas today they control little more than nine per cent. So it is fatuous to say that this change has not occurred in this period.

What we have today is a case of the poor getting poorer and a striking display of the rich getting richer. The poorer members of our society are becoming even more powerless over their future. In contrast to these growing sectors in society, Australia's middle-class—the perceived mainstay of Australia's society—is an endangered species.

While the problems of the long-term unemployed and the elderly constantly surround us, attention must now be directed to a new class of Australians, a class equally powerless and some say even more disenfranchised from the power base than the two I have just mentioned. We are now witnessing the emergence of the working poor. These are young Australians in full-time, low-skilled jobs, taking home low wages, with some wages just above the poverty line. These are the people who are trying to build a home, raise a family and keep some hope—yet this hope is fading fast.

These hardworking young Australians now constitute almost 10 per cent of the bottom income earners in this country. They are the forgotten poor. These are the working poor. These are the single income families who are battling to stay off the social security system, battling to maintain the self-esteem that having a job represents. Yet, because of both government intervention and inaction, these battlers are almost destined to join the ranks of the unemployed.

As we have seen, having a job does not restrict people from the poverty trap. For the low wage earner, benefits, like those provided by the state to the elderly and the unemployed, are scarce. In fact, studies show these working poor are the most affected by the inequalities in wealth distribution. So by just looking at income levels we may get a distorted picture of the poverty levels and wealth distribution. In measuring wealth transfer levels in Australia we need to draw comparisons between those at different stages of the life cycle and different levels of the work force and assess just how the scarce public funds are to be distributed.

In measuring poverty we must also look at needs. The needs of those struggling with unemployment are well documented, but the needs of those struggling with employment are not so apparent. If we are to effectively reduce poverty in this country, we must not limit ourselves to those without work. Our efforts must include bolstering the vulnerable at the lower end of the income scale.

With the declining importance of such institutions as the church, the extended family, the local neighbourhood and community, we are looking somewhat blindly towards the state to provide the services that these failing institutions once maintained. We are now heavily dependent on the public sector to provide a large proportion of our needs. There are 8,116,000 people receiving benefits from government—read taxpayers—in this country.

These figures highlight the growing level of government involvement in the economy and society. The state is quickly assuming many of the traditional roles performed by the family and institutions, yet its use of budget deficits to pay its way is self-defeating. The problem with borrowing today is that we will burden our children with the debt of tomorrow. It is the next generation that will have to pay for our failures today. As leading industrialist John Ralph said last year, `We have mortgaged the future of our children.' We are ignoring the issue of intergenerational equity and allowing the future of this country to rest in the hands of foreign banks and financial institutions. It seems ironic that, at a time when we are striving for greater autonomy and independence as a nation, we are quickly chaining ourselves to be servants to foreign lenders. The shackles of this debt may not be released for many decades to come.

One of the greatest arguments for the redistribution of wealth is founded in the area of health. Health is too often treated like economics. People are encouraged to think that the size of the cake is more important than how it is shared. This argument is particularly sensitive in the area of health and inequality. There is a stronger belief that a nation's health and living standards are positively correlated, but such beliefs can be misleading. The constant rhetoric about rises in GDP gives little comfort to the ailing in our society. In fact, it is estimated that between only 10 and 25 per cent of the improvement in life expectancy can be directly attributed to rises in living standards. Thus in health economics the connection between living standards and health standards is tenuous. The real relationship is between income distribution and health.

When measuring the rise in poverty levels in Australia, our ageing society cannot be ignored. With the number of retired people growing by over 10 per cent each year, the level of income inequality in Australia is directly linked to the growing number of pensioners, with more and more people leaving the work force and retiring on the old age pension. The effects of this on the social welfare system, the health system and the work force are evident.

Australia is moving towards a society of two classes. We do not just have a division between those with a job and those without, but more a society divided between the poor and the rich. Australia is losing its middle class. Consequently, we are seeing a surge in the level of the poor and the wealthy.

While the state attempts to provide an infrastructure to combat the social effects of unemployment, the state could never replace the family. Research shows that funding for family counselling is over 60 times more cost effective than spending on crisis services once the family has broken up. That is rational economics. It is our aim to bring a sensitive—(Time expired).

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a short contribution on this matter of public importance. I will start by saying Senator Herron raised a number of important issues in this debate—issues that go to the question about how we measure poverty and inequality in Australian society. Senator Herron, in making some of his points, highlighted the first point that I wish to make, which is that at this stage we are not able to get a proper measure of wealth and of income distribution in Australian society. That is partly due to some of the issues that Senator Herron raised about the changes that are occurring in Australian society—the different work patterns, the different family living arrangements and a whole range of other issues that mean that references to things like the Henderson poverty line are woefully out of date.

PARA.TAB: This points to the need for a much more reliable analysis of wealth and income distribution in Australian society. All of the measures, such as the ABS income distribution series, fail to address the totality of the picture that one would need to have to make a proper analysis. I question whether there is a widening gap, but it is difficult to come to any conclusive view on that question because there is no proper analysis that takes into consideration all the necessary points, such as those the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, mentioned—the social wage and in particular Medicare—and other issues such as the increase in superannuation in the Australian work force and further changes in the taxation area, which will also need to be accounted for in any proper analysis.

We have already highlighted the change in the bottom marginal rate from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. The impact of the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax on wealth distribution in Australian society also need to be taken into account. With the fringe benefits tax, the cashing out of previously uncounted income will have quite a substantial impact on some of the measures that were traditionally used in assessing these issues. We have to move towards a much better analysis in this area. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs has been looking at some work that is being done on social and economic indicators in Australian society so that debate can be much more informed and less dominated by prejudice and politics.

There is poverty in Australian society but I think the record of this government in attacking the causes of that poverty is a good one. The key issue in determining poverty in Australian society is employment. No government has been more committed to creating employment in its economy than the Australian federal government. We realise that the general condition of the economy is the key to that employment growth, but we have also been very conscious of the need to help the long-term unemployed—those who are most likely to become the long-term poor.

That is what Working Nation was all about—ensuring that, as we got economic growth and as we got growth in jobs, we took the long-term unemployed with us. We wanted to ensure that they were not left behind as the economy started to grow again. We are seeing that growth, and we are starting to see growth in the employment figures. It was announced only today that the October unemployment rate was down to 9.1 per cent. I think all senators would welcome that.

As I say, the key to alleviating poverty in Australian society has very much to do with creating jobs and making sure that people are not unemployed. I think the full two percentage point drop in the unemployment figures over the last 12 months gives us great hope. The trend in employment is very encouraging. It will go a long way towards tackling the issue of poverty for so many Australians.

There are also issues relating to the wider economy. The Liberal Party for one is always telling the government that the key issue in the economy is growth. We have growth of over four per cent. That is helping create jobs and generally improving the economic potential of Australia. That will have more effect than anything else in terms of helping alleviate the poverty that exists in Australian society.

There are other excellent signs in the economy as well, such as the growth in real wages, low inflation and the increase in household disposable income—all things that will help ensure that we—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The failure of this government's social and economic policies has never been more evident than in rural Australia today. Senator Crowley says that there is no evidence of an increasing gap between the rich and the poor. I suggest that she is not in line with any of the social commentators. I suggest that she take a look at the drought-ravaged areas of eastern Australia today.

PARA.TAB: The cupboard for people who live and work in rural and regional Australia is bare. It is bare thanks to a government that has grossly neglected its responsibilities. It is a very un-country government despite its rhetoric about being inclusive.

The cupboard is bare because the Keating government has a big city focus, and has had this focus for the 11 years that it has been in power. It is myopic to the changing face of rural Australia. The tale going around is, `When did the Prime Minister see that there was a drought?' The reply is, `It was when his backbenchers told him.' The reason it took so long is that there are not too many ALP members in the vast tracts covered by the present calamity of drought.

Today, in the brief time available, I would like to outline a number of major areas of this government's culpability in regard to rural Australia. There are a number of reasons why the people of the bush have been brought to their knees by this government.

Firstly, for many years this government ran a high inflation economy. The farmers who export most of what they produce are subject to the vagaries of international markets. Because they could not pass on the increased costs of production they found that their costs were rising by anything from 10 to 14 per cent every year throughout the 1980s. That helped to precipitate a massive collapse in their terms of trade.

Secondly, interest rates soared way above the levels of those of our competitors and have continued to stay there. It should not be forgotten that, for over 18 months, farmers paid interest in excess of 20 per cent per annum. Even now, many farmers are still paying in excess of 14 per cent. While the government bleats about what it is doing to help farmers and the rest of rural Australia, it is still pursuing economic policies that continually push interest rates up for everybody—not just farmers, but for home buyers as well. With the current account running as it is, and with the deficit increasing, there can be no other result than higher interest rates. The recent one per cent rise in interest rates alone will cost the farm sector approximately $170 million extra in yearly repayments.

Thirdly, the government stands condemned because it has allowed the farming community to bear the full brunt of the costs of deregulation. This government has left everyone else insulated from the harsh realities of economic life while it has stripped away virtually every assistance that the farming sector receives. It still costs up to three times more in this country to process a kilogram of meat than it does in America, or twice what it costs in New Zealand or Argentina. These are the nations we are competing against in Asia. Take a look at the shipping industry in this country. It is still disappointingly ineffectual after the now Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, was put in charge of reforming the waterfront. That process cost taxpayers nearly $400 million. I do not think we got value for money.

Fourthly, the government is culpable because it has gutted the income equalisation deposits scheme—the prudent farmers' drought insurance—just when it was needed most. It has burdened isolated employers with the fringe benefits tax. It has pushed fuel prices unnecessarily high by using fuel excise as a way of raising nearly $10 billion per annum, of which only $870 million is returned to the national roads program.

The tragedy of rural and regional Australia is the sharp increase in suicide and marriage breakdowns suffered by families due to the intolerable pressures often caused by their debt and their poverty. Thanks to this government, country Australia will never be the same again. Rural and regional Australia have been disgracefully neglected and mismanaged. This neglect is reflected in our massive debt and balance of payments crises. Each and every Australian has suffered, or will suffer, from this government's apathy towards rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the issue of poverty to the extent that Senator Patterson believes that there is a growing gap between rich and poor in Australia. This is a very serious matter, and I believe that Senator Patterson raises it with some considerable integrity. However, unfortunately for Senator Patterson and a number of others in her party, they are on very weak ground because they are not in a position to state what their policies would be.

PARA.TAB: It is all very well to come into this place and say that the government is not doing enough—and I will come to that because I believe that the government has a very firm and sound record in this regard—but where are the opposition policies? What are the opposition's views about how to overcome the problem of people still living in poverty?

Of course, poverty is of major concern to all honourable senators. However, it is a matter of the policies that best suit this country and best suit the respective parties. Whilst we have a government that has put forward a series of major initiatives to reduce levels of poverty, we have an opposition that continually vacillates and refuses to put forward policies.

I am sorry that Senator Sandy Macdonald has left the chamber because he actively decided to focus on rural Australia. I believe that I am, perhaps, in a better position than he to talk about the changes in rural and regional Australia after the 12 years that I have been in this parliament. I happen to come from regional Australia. I have travelled extensively around rural Queensland.

Over my time in parliament I have noticed the dramatic changes that have taken place in terms of the infrastructure, the services, the programs and the reaching out so that people in rural and regional Australia do have government services. I would be the very first to admit that there is more to be done. I would always say that rural and regional Australia needs even greater recognition.

Senator Patterson should contrast the current situation with that when I was first elected in 1983. One could go into the major towns and cities in Queensland and there would scarcely be any evidence at all of federal government services or programs.

Let me take up the question that Senator Patterson raises today. It is important in this debate to seriously examine the extent to which we take into account the social wage. We have to look at all the social infrastructure that the Labor government has provided. Here are just a few facts about the social wage. We introduced Medicare. Before we did so, two million Australians had no health insurance. It is very easy to forget these figures.

Under Labor, the pension has increased by 14 per cent in real terms. Support for low income families has increased by 78 per cent in real terms. Did the Fraser government of so long ago know anything about rent assistance? We take rent assistance for granted now. Rent assistance for low income families has increased by over 100 per cent. Child care has increased from 46,000 places to nearly 250,000 places. It is quite clear from the statistics that Labor is the government for families.

We have dramatically increased the value of family payments. For low income families with young children the payments have increased by 80 per cent; they have increased by 150 per cent for families with teenagers. What does this mean? It means that low income families with children now get an extra $20 per week and families with teenagers get an extra $33 per week.

Let us look at what the opposition will do. The present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer)—I do not know who it will be tomorrow—has said quite clearly that there will be further cuts in assistance to families. He said, `There will be some cuts, and I don't want to leave a false impression'. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not really surprising that two-thirds of the 1.8 million Australians living in poverty are families with dependent children. Firstly, the income tax system no longer recognises the number of people who live on a given income. Secondly, there has been a stagnation in real incomes over recent years. We heard Minister Cook today almost boasting that wage levels have been kept down and that the income from that area has been kept down to point something per cent. Thirdly, both the federal and state governments have increasingly resorted to increased indirect taxes which bear more heavily on families, especially larger families.

PARA.TAB: Fourthly, governments are moving towards either increased charges for basic facilities, such as water, or are levying disguised taxes on consumers of basic utility services through forced dividend requirements on public utilities. Fifthly, because family payments were inadequately indexed, their real value is less than what it was in 1979 when family allowance was introduced in place of tax rebates and child endowment. I have talked about this before and I do not want to go into that further today.

Faced with these unfavourable trends, there has been a predictable but sad economic and demographic response. Fewer people are choosing to have children, and many are having fewer than they would otherwise prefer. Couples are hanging on to living standards by both seeking paid jobs and avoiding, in many cases, having dependent children. Fewer and fewer families can now exist on one income, and that is devastating. Much of the demand for child care for children of mothers in the paid work force is really generated by necessity, and not choice. One of the big demands that is not fulfilled is for infant places in child-care centres.

TALK.START.PARA: —Baby places.

—Baby places. That is distressing. Surveys have shown that mothers of those very young children would rather not be forced into the situation of putting their babies into child-care centres. Many families actually need two incomes to survive. The entry of so many mothers with those young children into the paid work force is not a sign of prosperity but of relative poverty.

PARA.TAB: The government should come clean and stop pretending that its child-care policies have anything to do with the welfare of families, children or women. The reality is that the government wants to force women and mothers with dependent children out of the home and into the paid labour market. I have been working for many years, and still am, for the cause of women in the paid work force. I am proud to do so. I am proud of our record in that case. But we have to look at the question of choice, and what occurs when we do not have that choice and the effect of that not only on the people concerned, but also on others.

If it is not the government's intention to try to force mothers into the paid work force, why else would it discriminate so harshly in financial terms against those mothers who wish to care for their own children and not compete for scarce jobs. Indeed, the government has implicitly admitted that its policies are not directed towards free choice. Have honourable senators heard that? The government has admitted it. On page 12 of Australia's national report on population at the recent Cairo conference on population development, the government stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the aging of the population is likely to result in greater demands on health and medical services and other support systems for the aged. It also poses particular challenges for the social security system.

The government goes on to state that one of its responses has been to foster an increase in the size of the labour force through encouraging the increased participation of women. So there we have it—admissions in the International Year of the Family that the government sees mothers with young dependent children as just another pool of tax slaves. Forget choice; forget what is good for children or for their parents; forget what they want; Treasury needs and must have its taxes. That is what a lot of this is all about.

PARA.TAB: What seems to be passing unnoticed, however, by both the government and most economic commentators is that the government's policy is not even economically rational. The more mothers are forced into the paid work force by the declining real wages of their husbands—or vice versa—and increased tax burdens and charges to take up paid employment, the less able they are to have the children they might otherwise want. The more mothers or fathers are forced into the labour market when they would prefer not to be there, the higher the participation rate and the more difficult it is to reduce unemployment.

Treasurer Willis has admitted this. At the press club luncheon on 11 May 1994, after the budget, he admitted that increases in the number of married women with children seeking to join the paid work force made `the job of getting unemployment down very, very difficult'. They are his words, not mine. He might have added that taxing people out of being able to afford the number of children they would otherwise want is also another very good way of adding to the Treasury's problems with an ageing population.

We reap what we sow. The shocking statistic that one in 10 families with children has both parents unemployed is a logical result of an economic system which has been designed to force labour force participation by both parents. Surveys by the Institute of Family Studies have shown that many mothers want genuine choice. Why does the government not give them genuine choice? They and their husbands value direct parental input in bringing up healthy, well-adjusted children. They are being told by the government that they are second-rate citizens and that, unless they are clocking a nine-to-five workday on top of their obligations, they are somehow slack halfwits. This is not equality, this is not fairness to families, it is slavery.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the couple of minutes available to me—indeed, even in eight minutes, if I had been able to negotiate that—one simply cannot deal adequately with this issue. Therefore, I seek leave to table a speech Senator Cheryl Kernot gave to the Australian Council of Social Service last month.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make two brief points. Firstly, I want to comment on what the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) alleges—that is, that basically this is not occurring and somehow we are imagining it. I find it amazing that the minister can assert that this simply is not happening. Not only is it happening here in Australia, it is happening internationally. It is happening inside countries and between countries as some countries get wealthier and others struggle to feed, educate and clothe their populations.

PARA.TAB: The only point I will concede to the minister and, indeed, to two other Labor Party speakers is that they have done something substantial for some of those on the bottom rung. They have not catered adequately for carers, nor for people in rural Australia, nor for single parents, nor for those with mental illness—there are no doubt many others we should be listing—but at least they have done something for those on the bottom rung.

I cannot finish without quickly commenting on the lack of Liberal Party policies. I commend Senator Patterson for raising this issue today; but I have been listening very carefully, hoping that somewhere in something said by members of the opposition we would have some policies, some direction and some indication about what it is going to do about this problem.

Unfortunately, again, while it quite rightly criticised the government for doing very little, we still have nothing concrete. Presumably we have to wait until an election is called before we have anything. It would be nice to know what the opposition plans to do for this problem that, as I said, is not just an Australian problem but one that is worldwide.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the very few minutes available to speak on this report, I should like to briefly point out to the Senate and, of course, to the taxpayers of Australia the situation we are facing with road funding. It might be all very well for Mr Brereton to put out a glossy report like this on what has happened in land transport in Australia in the last 12 months—and worthwhile programs have been carried out or even completed in the last 12 months—but unfortunately road funding in real terms is dropping and dropping and dropping.

PARA.TAB: The situation is that we spend on roads not quite 7c a litre from the fuel excise gathered by this government. At the last count, the fuel excise is about 32c and, of course, will rise again under indexation twice a year. That excise escalates without anyone knowing—it just turns up at the bowser on the appointed day; and the government does not really get the flack it would get if a bill went through each time.

Of that 32c or thereabouts, give or take a few decimal points, just under 7c is going back on roads. It is certainly far short of what should be going back to maintain roads at a standard expected in a country of this size, where there are massive road distances and massive rail distances—after all, this report covers rail as well.

I notice that at the last count the National Rail Corporation's network is not as up-to-date as we were given to believe in the Working Nation package. I do not know quite how long ago that was, Mr Acting Deputy President; you might be able to fill me in on that—but it is a while ago now. Whatever was supposed to have been spent on rail in that time, to my knowledge, has not led to the completion of that network.

We did have one good measure from one of the programs some time ago when, I think, Mr Brown, who was Minister for Land Transport at the time, put in place the black spot program. I criticised it at the time as a vote catching exercise in places where the government had marginal seats.

However, I am happy to admit that I was wrong in that criticism because, under Mr Brown, that plan worked successfully. The program having worked successfully by fixing a lot of the black spots that existed around Australia, I thought the government would have kept that program up and picked out priority areas where the highest number of accidents occurred and concentrated on those, as well as on the other areas on which road spending should have occurred along the line.

Of those black spots on which work has been done, the engineering has been well done and the works have been carried out to make them safer. I can point to a particular spot in Western Australia where, unfortunately, a son of a good friend of mine was killed last year.

Unfortunately for him, that particular road was rectified under the black spot program only a matter of months after the accident, and now one would have to be blind to get into a bad situation there. It is not too late for the government to look at getting this program on track again.

Outside of that, this government must increase spending, because in real terms what has been allocated to roads is far below in real terms that spent by the Fraser government in its last year in office. With the ever increasing excise on fuel, at least some of that extra funding should go back on roads.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Housing and Regional Development

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a couple of matters that I want to raise in relation to this report. I will start with program No. 3: the National Capital Planning Authority. I read with interest the report of the authority. I think the authority generally does a good job. It is well staffed and directed, in my opinion.

PARA.TAB: I was concerned that—in spite of my raising in the Senate and at estimates committees on a number of occasions, and in spite of the National Capital Planning Authority telling me that the ramshackle buildings down opposite old Parliament House are illegally there—

TALK.START.PARA: —Slums.

—My colleague calls them slums, but certainly they are illegal, temporary buildings with suspect sanitation and sewerage, I would suspect. In spite of me raising that in the Senate and at estimates committees a number of times, nothing seems to have been done about it. I have raised this with the authority.

PARA.TAB: I have some sympathy for the authority because I do think the authority would like to do something to remove an illegal set of buildings. But the authority seems to be curtailed because the minister and the government show no leadership or fortitude in dealing with what is clearly a breach of law on what has been reported to me in the Senate as an illegal building or dwelling.

Canberra is a beautiful city. It is, as the national capital, a city that all Australians can be proud of. Some of the buildings are quite magnificent, but I think it is unfortunate that this building has been allowed to continue to exist for, as far as I can see, no appropriate purpose. I do not really want to enter into the question of who is operating the building and what it is supposed to be.

There have been suggestions that when the set of temporary buildings was set up—I think it was about seven years ago—there may have been an appropriate reason for them to be there. But that reason no longer seems to exist.

I wonder when this government will have the courage to do something about those buildings which should not exist. As well as being an eyesore—and I would think there are health risks there—there does not seem to be appropriate sanitation or water. I will continue to raise this question at estimates committees and elsewhere until I can get an answer from the minister on why he is acquiescing in the continued operations of an illegal establishment—an establishment which I am told has no proper function there.

I make note of the comments in the report on the better cities program, which the department is in charge of. There will be $816 million spent over five years. Some of the projects being entered into are appropriate, but I wonder what progress has been made and what limits have been imposed upon those groups using the money as to when those moneys have to be expended. I have put some questions on notice to the minister, though they seem to be taking a long time to be answered. It is a program that one would hate to suggest was done for political reasons, and I would just like to get an update on that and an understanding of what the limitations are in expenditure.

There have been a number of reports on regional development. The McKinsey report and the Kelty report are two of the most prominent. I am interested in the fact that although a lot of money was spent on the Kelty report the government has picked up very few of its recommendations.

The McKinsey report, which I suggest is a much better exposition of the way our country should be developed in the regions of Australia, made two major recommendations to get rid of government on-costs and to make labour conditions more flexible. But the recommendations seem to have been completely ignored by this government.
I wonder why the department and the minister keep engaging these consultants, setting up these task forces and getting these reports if they are, in one instance, going to ignore them. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Administrative Services: Annual Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report was apparently tabled during the break. It is a very large and extensive report and covers the very wide range of activities of the Department of Administrative Services. I think that it bears very close reading.

PARA.TAB: Some of the areas that this department covers, particularly in the provision of business services and the performance of the business units, are important, not only in terms of their ability to make a profit and to cut their costs and the services they provide to government but in some areas where they happen to compete with the private sector.
The performance of these business units has generally raised considerable controversy in the Senate over the last year and there are some very brief matters I wish to comment on.
I will be pursuing some of these issues more extensively in Senate estimates, which are coming up in the next couple of weeks.

There are a couple of issues that I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate in relation to Australian Construction Services and Asset Services. The performance of these two particular units has been poor in recent years and, as I mentioned earlier, Australian Construction Services in particular has been subjected to considerable debate in this parliament.
I was recently passed a letter from the department which shows that further restructuring of these two particular units is planned.

I do not believe this is apparent in the annual report but, once again, we have another period apparently pending further extensive restructuring in the department in relation to Australian Construction Services and Asset Services.

I have a letter here signed by a Mr J. A. Mackay, the executive general manager, commercial, dated 31 October. He pointed out that both Australian Construction Services and Asset Services have had difficulties over the last 18 months. Certainly, the figures demonstrate that. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: Ongoing reform will be necessary to improve our ability to grasp the many opportunities that will emerge as the Australian economy picks up.
He then goes on—and this is very important:

Against this background I have sought and obtained endorsement to some structural changes which need to occur as soon as possible. In essence these changes involve combining the management and administrative infrastructure of both ACS and Asset Services. Substantial improvements in the efficiency and effectiveness of both businesses will result.

We have had that promise before and undoubtedly we will have it again. Apparently, there will be another upheaval in the department in relation to these two units. Apparently, Terry Halestrap has decided to retire and has left ACS.

TALK.START.PARA: —A dedicated and hardworking officer.

—I am happy to record Senator Campbell's views in the Hansard. Apparently, ACS and Asset Services will continue to operate with their existing business identities and separate trading accounts for the remainder of this financial year. However, this issue will be revisited in about six to eight months time following consultation with staff, unions and clients. My understanding is that a number of years ago these two business units, along with a number of others, were separated. Now, according to Mr Mackay, there will be further restructuring and these business units are being brought together.

PARA.TAB: As my time is running out, I flag that one of the units which seems to be enjoying particular success is Dasfleet. It continues to show fairly booming profits, but the nature of those profits will be a matter which will have to be carefully examined during the estimates which, as I said, are coming up in the next couple of weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to make some remarks on the annual report of the Department of Administrative Services, following those made by my colleague Senator Kemp, the shadow minister for administrative services. One of the matters which has concerned me over the past year is, of course, the way in which the Department of Administrative Services runs its property operations, particularly in relation to the Casselden Place building in Melbourne. On the last day of the previous sitting week a report by the Auditor-General into the Casselden Place building revealed that there had been significant financial incentives offered to DAS businesses within that building which, of course, is also owned by a DAS business and, ultimately, by the Australian taxpayer. That report revealed that the department has lost, on its own valuation by the Australian Valuation Office, no less than $103 million.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Walker QC, has said in a press release that that is only a paper loss. He compared it with losses made by the private sector in other buildings in Melbourne. Of course, his defence of that loss of $103 million of taxpayers' money entirely ignores the fact that no other landlord in Melbourne—and he referred to a number of landlords who have lost money on property deals in Melbourne during Mr Keating's recession—had the benefit of captive tenants who were not only forced to go into the building by the lessor, that is, the Commonwealth Keating government, but also were captives in relation to the terms and conditions of the rentals.

The crucial point to make here is that in the government's handling of the Casselden Place cover-up, it initially sought to refuse to table documents relating to the leases in Casselden Place. I refer specifically to what occurred on 5 May 1994 when Senator McMullan said in the Senate, `There were no particular incentive packages involved in these deals.' Senator McMullan actually misled the Senate. Mr Walker not only misled the Senate by having a letter tabled which stated there were no incentives involved; he also repeated that in his press release of 20 October in which he said, `There were no incentives involved in these deals.'

On that day, 20 October, Mr Walker tabled two letters, both from the Australian Property Group and both addressed to the DAS business units that lease these buildings. He said in his press release—and he probably hoped that no journalist actually read the letters—that they proved conclusively that there were no incentives involved, so he had not misled the parliament. The sad thing is that at least I read the letters, and the letters specifically describe the incentive packages offered to all the individual DAS business units.

These incentives were offered to business units such as the Australian Archives. In a letter dated April 1993 there is specific mention of incentives, including a free fit-out and rent free periods to Support Services; Asset Services—contribution towards fit-out, rent free period; DAS Interiors—free rent, contribution towards fitting-out costs; and Project Services was given the same incentives. All of these businesses were offered incentives. They were used as inducements to ensure that these groups entered into leases with the Commonwealth. Those leases have yet to be signed. So they are incentives; they are inducements.

I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that both Senator McMullan and Mr Walker have misled this parliament and the people of Australia in their attempts to cover up a $103 million scandal. Both of those ministers need to be required to explain why they sought to mislead this parliament. If that explanation is not satisfactory, those ministers should certainly be called on to resign.(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
