DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Museum of Australia: Annual Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always look forward to receiving this report because I believe a museum of Australia is something this country should have, not just as a monument, but as something which is preserving the history of this nation for those who will come after us. I refer to the objects of the museum as set out in the report—a museum for all Australians, incorporating the inter-related themes of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture, Australian society and history, and people's interaction with the environment.

PARA.TAB: Of course, this year I felt considerable sadness at receiving this report, knowing that just in the past few weeks the government has effectively abandoned the museum. On page 2 of the annual report I see these words:

SPEECH.PARA: The Council of the National Museum has reaffirmed Yarramundi as its preferred site for the Museum . . .

The site was chosen by the council of the museum and has been reaffirmed a number of times, after extensive examination. I think initially 12 sites in the ACT were looked at to see which of them was the best site for the museum to incorporate this theme. The Acton Peninsula was at no time considered as an appropriate site for the museum. I admit that the hospital had not closed at that time, but the area there was not considered.

PARA.TAB: The Yarramundi site is agreed by everybody, except the Prime Minister, as the perfect site for the museum. There are a lot of Australians who know and understand why the collection is kept. There are over 200,000 items already in the Museum of Australia collection, most of which presumably will be dispersed or got rid of, in spite of people having given them because they, too, believe in the museum being the history of this country. I quote from page 1 of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: The museum is making its collection relevant and accessible to as many Australians as possible—through travelling exhibitions, new communications technology, joint projects and other outreach activities.
It is worth going back to the ALP cultural policy of 1993. I do not have time to read all of it, but I will read this portion:
Concurrently, over the next four years, there will be a staged development of the Museum's site at Yarramundi including exhibition, education and conservation facilities.

To celebrate that, there was a big publicity photo opportunity event at the site. This was leading up to the 1993 election campaign. There was much celebration about the jobs for Canberra and what it would all mean to the country. The museum was going ahead; $26 million was promised in the next budget for it. And what has happened? This year in the cultural statement it has been abandoned.

PARA.TAB: As a supplementary to this, the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies will be put on Acton Peninsula, and we are meant to pretend that that is the Museum of Australia. It is not a suitable site for the Aboriginal pavilion of the museum. Yarramundi is. Those Aboriginals who have been involved with the project from the beginning prefer Yarramundi as the site. This is not a museum of Australia. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a letter published in the Canberra Times on 25 October from Emeritus Professor David Ride, who was a former member of the Museum Council and chair of the site development and building committee, in which letter he sets out his views about the current government's proposal.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Museum plan unworthy of us

PARA.TAB: Keith Scott's article "Cut-down museum finds home at Acton" has got it absolutely right (CT, October 14, p 1). A museum that has a gallery of Aboriginal Australia on the Acton Peninsula, constitutional displays in Old Parliament House, a bit in the Old Customs House, Sydney, and the rest of the national collection consisting at present of some 200,000 items (and that is only the beginning) dispersed among travelling exhibitions and state museums all over the continent will not be a museum worthy of the people of the Commonwealth of Australia.

The vision that we hope all Australians can share and identify with will tell of the past, present, and future of our nation—the only nation in the world that spans an entire continent—and one being created by people drawn from every continent. Our museum at the centre of our national capital will be as youthful and exciting as its people. It will tell the history of the 600 million years of its nature as well as the history of the Australian people from the first Australians to those of tomorrow.

Detailed planning started in 1980 at government request. Out of many consultations, arguments, options, world-wide investigations and expert advice, emerged a superb architecturally low-key treatment of the wonderful site that Yarramundi offers—and which we are now being told we must give up. A vision of display pavilions sited to allow the spacious environment, the lakeside, and the Brindabellas, to contribute their essence to what the museum will tell of land and people. Displays that will also emphasise the interactions between Aboriginal people and those who came later. And interactions between people and the environment.

With the plan realised, the National Museum of Australia will be a museum to experience—not just a museum to visit. A development that will be in the forefront of broad-acre museums like Skansen in Sweden, Ironbridge and Beamish in Britain, and Orlando in the USA. It will be user-friendly to time-watchful tourists—but it will also be a great place for families and parties of children to spend the whole day.

As a former member of the Museum Council and chair of its site development and buildings committee, since the closure of the Royal Canberra Hospital I have often been asked whether we would have preferred the Acton Peninsula in 1982 when we chose Yarramundi. At that time the interim council assisted by the NCDC rejected 12 other sites in the ACT (including the parliamentary zone) but did not consider the Acton Peninsula as an option.

Certainly, we should never reject an opportunity to consider a better option. And it may not be too late to look at this alternative—but the option could only be considered after wide consultation with the people of Aboriginal Australia. Their story must be an indispensable feature. The museum must be as much theirs as it is of post-Aboriginal Australians.

If the Acton Peninsula is a real option then it must be reviewed honestly and publicly. It would not be a cheap option. The present buildings on it would have to go and planting be replaced if the vision is not to be lost. Any consideration of the Acton Peninsula must not form part of a hidden proposal to scrap the great concept of a unified national museum in a spacious setting incorporating both indoor exhibits as well as outdoor vistas, events, and displays to tell the story.

We Australians want to tell the story of our Australian continent and its peopling, warts and all, but with pride in our achievements—and they are many in all facets of life. To most of us it is the most wonderful of all stories. Yarramundi will tell it superbly.

SPEECH.PARA: (Emeritus Professor)
David Ride
Hughes

TALK.START.PARA: —We should all do what we can to see that this absurd decision is overturned and that Australia joins the other OECD countries in having a museum of which it can be proud, so that the children and grandchildren of those of us now making decisions will be able to see what this country is and how it has become the sort of place that it is. I do not believe we should abandon these ideals. It has been put in legislation. It is something that really ought to go ahead. One can only speculate about why the Prime Minister is so totally opposed to a national museum. I cannot imagine why any person in his position would have so little regard for his country, for its history and for how it has been developed that he would want to abandon this project. As I said, it is with considerable sadness that one reads the report this year, knowing that everybody who is concerned about it would want it to go ahead.

—As Senator Reid has said, it is extraordinary that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) would want to abandon this project. But I suppose there are some reasons that do suggest themselves. This is a Prime Minister who wants to abandon our flag and wants to abandon our constitution. He has no respect for our past. This is a government, for example, that refuses to allow the Navy Hydrography Office in Wollongong to be called after the extraordinary achievement in the Tom Thumb of the people who discovered or, if you like, first chartered the area—because they were English. There is a determined refusal in this government to acknowledge our heritage and our traditions. This action is simply part of that persistent anti-history, anti-tradition approach by people who, frankly, have a vested interest in destroying our heritage.

PARA.TAB: One would have thought that `Matthew Flinders' was a very appropriate name to put on the Wollongong Navy Hydrography Office. One would have thought that it was appropriate that there should be a national museum of Australia. Whether it should be a Rolls-Royce one or a Mini Minor one is perhaps something there could be some discussion about. But the fact is that there is a determined approach to destroy the things that so many Australians regard as vitally important to them, and that is their heritage.

This Prime Minister and this government, by seeking to damage the symbols of our history, of what we stand for, the symbols that are so important to so many people, are seeking to make changes that happen to suit their own agendas. Those agendas relate clearly, it seems to me, to the holding and exercise of power by any means. In other words, there is something far more sinister, it seems to me, in this general rejection of our heritage than simply in some sort of view that the particular heritage the Prime Minister comes from, an Irish one, should be one that predominates and should destroy, say, the Anglo-Saxon traditions or any of the other traditions that exist in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think he will change the names of the seats of Blaxland, Lawson and Wentworth?

—Good interjection. Will the names of the House of Representatives seats Blaxland, Lawson and Wentworth have to be changed? Will history have to be rewritten? I suppose the Labor Party is pretty adept at rewriting history. It had one of the best rewriters of history—late lamented, but nonetheless very proficient at rewriting history. Of course, this may be the removal, or the apparent destruction, of the concept of a national museum of Australia as part of this rewriting of history. It is certainly writing out our traditions.

PARA.TAB: We see in this parliament the way this government is seeking to make the executive all powerful and how it resents the role, for example, of the Senate, which has involved itself in the vital roles in Australia's history, part of our heritage. I would see this not simply as an isolated attack, but part of a general pattern of disregard for the things we stand for. I must say I think it is in very close association with the negative approach to the Australian flag, the national flag, which in one form or another has been with us since Federation. It is all very well having these nonsensical arguments about whether it had a red background, a blue background or a white background; the fact is that that flag in structure has been with us since Federation. It is that aim of destroying our heritage that, I believe, motivates the government in this negative attitude to the National Museum of Australia. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the Senate and I thank the parliamentary secretary. The Australian Sports Drug Agency report clearly demonstrates that Australian professional boxing has got to smarten up its act. It has to clean up its act. We have a situation, as is evidenced on page 114 of this report, of two failures to comply in boxing—in other words, people refusing to take a drug test. When that happens in other amateur sports we find that sanctions are applied.

PARA.TAB: For example, in athletics on 30 July 1993, there was a failure to comply with a drug test and the athlete was suspended for four years. In powerlifting on 16 August 1993 there was a failure to comply and the athlete was suspended for three years. But what do we find when we go to boxing? Failure to comply, no sanctions, because the people involved were professional boxers. I do not know what professional boxing thinks is the right thing, but apparently if you are a professional boxer you can be up to the eyeballs in dope and still be allowed to participate in that profession.

It is not a matter of professional sports not abiding by the rules. Look at rugby league. Rugby league accepts the proper and reasonable role and, in fact, hires the Australian Sports Drug Agency to ensure that the sport is clean. There has even been testing for cannabis, which one could hardly regard as a performance enhancing drug, in rugby league. There have been cautions for inadvertent use of stimulants and also anabolic steroid tests—in fact, there was a ten-week suspension for one rugby league player.

It does seem totally inadequate that professional boxing does not end up with sanctions against those people who have been found by the Australian Sports Drug Agency to have failed to comply with its tests. We have not seen a situation where there is a positive test in boxing, presumably because there must be some sort of instruction around the professional boxing business that says, `Look, don't get tested, just refuse, because there are no sanctions and it doesn't matter anyway.' That is totally unacceptable. I do not know what should be done about it but it seems to me that there should be the capacity for firmer action to be taken. One would hope that whoever runs professional boxing in Australia—in fact, in the world—should do something about this sort of ludicrous behaviour.

There are some problems that strike me from the tables on pages 113 and 114 when the Australian Sports Drug Agency has not yet been advised of positive tests that took place up to a year ago. It is very important not only that these tests should be taken but that there should be appropriate follow-up action, and that the Sports Drug Agency should be advised of what it is.

There are couple of other matters that I want to raise. One is that the report reveals that in May 1994 a review of the cost of drug testing services was initiated, and Price Waterhouse has been engaged to develop a costing model and provide advice on the full cost of the drug testing service. These results should be available in the current financial year.

As the Senate would be aware, the coalition has long taken the view that there should be a great deal of cost recovery in this area, and I hope this Price Waterhouse report leads to this. I would also like to stress that the agency maintains its emphasis on out-of-competition testing by allocating 56 per cent of tests to this purpose. That is a very sensible approach, and I think we lead the world on that. Over 2,220 elite national level athletes identified by their national sporting organisations were exposed to year-round testing throughout this program. In other words, it is not good enough just to test people in competition, we have to do out-of-competition testing to see whether they are trying to build themselves up illegally and improperly away from the testing area. It is a very effective operation, because the threat of testing is very effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to follow Senator Baume in commending the Australian Sports Drug Agency for its activities during the last 12 months. I draw particular attention to the excellent work being done by Professor Peter Baume, the chairman of the Sports Drug Agency, who is well known to all of those in the Senate; and to Steve Haynes, the Chief Executive, who has done a magnificent job since the legislation was passed setting in place the Australian Sports Drug Agency.

PARA.TAB: I might say in not too unkind a way, I hope, that it is also good to have a minister who, in the short time he has been the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, gives the impression of at least having some understanding of sport and the problems with drugs in sport, unlike his predecessor who, at one stage, said that she thought that the whole Australian ethos had rather gone over the top in terms of our concern for and preoccupation with drugs in sport.

I am reminded by one of my colleagues that it was Mr Ted Harris, the chairman of the Australian Sports Commission, who said that one of the trials and tribulations of being chairman of the Australian Sports Commission was that he had to put up with this Senate committee of inquiry into such matters and he had had to combat the types of findings and conclusions we were making, all of which have been thoroughly and utterly vindicated, and as a result of that inquiry and its findings, this Sports Drug Agency had its genesis.

I am pleased to note in the report that the Australian Sports Drug Agency has managed to begin negotiations with the Chinese. I see there was a visit to China by members of the Australian Sports Drug Agency following a visit to Australia by Chinese officials, and my understanding is that they are now some way towards setting up a bilateral agreement between those two countries. It is very important because even the most casual observer will notice the similarity between not only the training methods but also the confirmation of the Chinese athletes, particularly the Chinese swimmers, with the East Germans of an earlier time. Now that we are working towards that bilateral arrangement, it will give an opportunity for testing. There is very little testing presently done in China and it will give the Australian officials an opportunity to test, as I understand it, both in contests and outside the period of competition.

What does concern me is that there has still been no success by any nation in the world to enter into a meaningful arrangement with the American amateur athletic track and field organisation—its proper name escapes me but it is the American amateur track and field body—which refuses to enter into bilateral or multilateral arrangements with other countries which allows for testing of the American amateur athletes. The reason for that is that so many of them are taking drugs and cheating against the rest of the world, and the Americans are concerned not to have their cheats exposed.

My understanding is that the United States Olympic Committee is prepared to enter into some sort of arrangement. But, ultimately, it does not have the capacity to clean up drugs in sport in America. That is something for the track and field body.

It is also of concern to me that the International Olympic Committee still seems reluctant to play any significant part in leading the world in drug testing.The situation now is as it has been in the past: if an athlete tests positive during Olympic competition, that athlete is simply banned and sent home. No penalty is imposed by the IOC. If an athlete tests positive prior to Olympic competition, and in the event that no sanction is imposed on that athlete by an appropriate body, he or she is able to compete in the Olympic Games. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with the remarks made by Senator Baume, a former shadow minister for sport, and Senator Crichton-Browne, a very active deputy chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. That committee brought down the landmark report on drugs in sport which led to the foundation of the Australian Sports Drug Agency, ASDA, now chaired by Professor Peter Baume and headed by Steve Haines.

PARA.TAB: The work of ASDA is very important. It is fair to say that when the agency was established it had what could only be regarded as a very large and enormously important task ahead of it. That task was to bring into existence a regime that would control the use of performance enhancing drugs—which, in many cases, can severely hurt the wellbeing of those who use them—thereby making competition in Australian sport, and international sport where possible, fairer. People who choose to use performance enhancing drugs against the rules of competition should not be able to achieve an unfair advantage over athletes who choose to compete without using performance enhancing drugs.

One of the dilemmas facing Australia in our fight against the abuse of drugs is, as Senator Crichton-Browne said, that it is all well and good testing during competition, but unless random testing is done outside major competition as well, abuses can and will continue and the regime will not be fair. ASDA is to be commended for the initiatives that it has taken in this regard.

So many of the athletes that I have spoken to in my short time as the shadow minister for sport are vitally interested in the fairness of international competition. A recent Four Corners or some other current affairs program highlighted the problem encountered by so many Australian athletes who compete internationally. They live by our rules under a strict drug detection regime but they have to compete against international athletes who abuse performance enhancing drugs. It is crucial in the years leading to the Sydney Olympics in the year 2000 that ASDA remains in the forefront when it comes to entering into negotiations and agreements with nations that still have problems. That way, come the Olympics, Australian athletes will not be at a disadvantage.

We need to ensure that the Sydney Olympics are a clean Olympics and that overseas competitors have no advantage through the abuse of performance enhancing drugs. Of course, that will be an enormously difficult thing to achieve. Among the nations of the world there are different levels of enforcement. In some there is very little enforcement and little motivation, incentive or intent to introduce appropriate regimes.

The dilemma was highlighted by Lisa Curry-Kenny. Talking hypothetically, she said that if she came 11th, 12th or 13th in an international swimming race against the sort of competition that we have seen in recent months, she would still regard that as a great achievement. She said that if she knew that the 12 people who beat her were all on performance enhancing drugs, she would know in her own mind that she had won because she had played fair.

I can say from my own experience in international sporting competition that it is not a lot of fun coming second or third, knowing the person in front has been cheating. Australian athletes have to sacrifice so much for athletic excellence. When they compete internationally and are the best on the day—they have done the preparation and training, they have made the sacrifices in terms of income, family and home life to be able to travel and compete internationally—it is not fair if they are denied a gold medal or a world championship or whatever because they are beaten by a drug-enhanced performance.

That is the challenge for ASDA. We, as parliamentarians, and all Australians should be proud of ASDA as being a very successful Commonwealth agency. As someone who has criticised quangos from time to time, I am pleased to say that this is one that is working effectively. I commend its annual report and wish it well for the forthcoming year.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the government response to the report on video and computer games and classification issues by the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies. I am pleased that the minister responsible, the Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, has responded positively to most of the committee's recommendations. I will come back to some of the crucial issues raised by the committee, and which the Attorney-General detailed in the government response, about regulating X- and R-rated computer games in Australia. Firstly, I would like to give the Senate some background to this matter.

PARA.TAB: The advent of new technology in computer games saw promoters developing violent and sexually explicit material in a new format. The absence of any regulation by the government when the technology first came to Australia created a new gateway for X and R type material that states and territories needed to close. State attorneys-general became alarmed by the access of youth to this material, particularly after a lot of strong parental and community concern. This was stated to all parties.

The Senate Select Committee on Community Standards became involved and after representations from similar groups, it decided to undertake a full inquiry into this matter. People should really understand that the material in this new type of technology which is driven by CD-ROM is very different from videos and films. It is far more graphic and intensive. It is very repetitive in nature and the material can be interactive. The impact on young minds is dramatically greater than the impact just from videos. The difference between videos and this material is as great as the difference between sound and video. The quantum leap in the effect is that great.

The psychological impact, particularly on young minds or disturbed minds, can be very great. It is believed that there can be long-term effects on users. Overseas evidence seems to demonstrate that 17 per cent of minors gain access to this material as the technology spreads in other countries. The committee was so concerned that it undertook a series of hearings across Australia. We took evidence from child psychologists, educationalists and people in the medical profession. Most importantly, we also took evidence from people out in the community—parents and children. We had one very dramatic day here in the parliament when we brought in children from a local high school to tell us about the way they use these sorts of games and materials. It was a very eye-opening session when we heard from the young people.

After these hearings we recommended that no R or X material would be allowed in computer games. What was needed, we felt, was a very strong regulatory regime to control this material across Australia to protect youth. The Senate report pressured the state and territory attorneys-general to rethink the need to bring in further regulations in their jurisdictions. We stressed at the time the need for full cooperation in our federal system to close this gate.

At this point, in late 1993, one state, the ACT and the Northern Territory would not go along with this recommendation. Terry Connolly, the Attorney-General in the ACT, in particular was holding out strongly, wanting the R and X classifications to be allowed in this state. The great worry with that, even though the ACT is only a very small area, is that it would create a gateway like the one we currently have with X-rated videos through to the rest of Australia. The worry was that by mail order and computer modem transfer, this new material would also spread to the children of Australia.

The information superhighway which is now developing would be a great conduit for carrying a lot of this material. It does not necessarily have to go through the mail. In the Northern Territory, our committee had heard evidence of the terrible impact on the Aboriginal community of the less graphic R and X video technology. The committee heard evidence that this material was causing social chaos with Aboriginal families. One suspects that this was the major reason why the Northern Territory then joined with the other six states in agreeing to stop R and X video games.

The state, Northern Territory and federal censorship ministers agreed to act to ban R and X classifications for computer games. In April this year the Governor-General signed the ACT ordinance allowing the X and R classifications. This was a crisis point as the gateway to distributing the material to Australian children was now open, irrespective of all other governments' proper actions. It could all come in through the ACTU—I mean the ACT.

TALK.START.PARA: —ACTU? That's a bit of a Freudian slip.

—Yes, it is. It could come in through the ACT because of the ordinance the Governor-General had signed. This situation, I believe, made the federal government rethink and act to close this loophole. The minister, Mr Lavarch, gave an undertaking to amend the ACT ordinance to make the ACT conform to the national standard. Ministerial cooperation from the Northern Territory and the states was a high point in action to protect our youth. I thought that when the ACT was forced to join, that was an excellent demonstration of cooperative federalism.

PARA.TAB: I would like to pay particular tribute to the work of the New South Wales Attorney-General, Mr Hannaford, who even took on Terry Connolly in debate on radio over this matter. His argument, particularly about parental concern, was one of the things that finally determined the issue.

This issue raises considerable concern about the whole area of classification. It points to a number of problems with the national classification code. On the one hand, this code says that adults should read, see and hear what they want. On the other hand, the same code says that minors should be protected from material that is likely to harm and disturb them. Those two principles clash constantly in the area of this video game material in this time of very rapidly changing technology. To the minister's credit, he has supported most of our recommendations in this area to bring the sale and distribution of this material under control.

Recommendation 2 says that ministers need to enforce measures with strong penalties and prosecution as a realistic deterrent. Mr Lavarch must emphasise this to his ministerial colleagues in the states and territories, because they are the people who have the power to enforce penalties. Recommendation 4 says that parents will not able to stop children viewing material if the gateways are open. We were pleased that the minister saw the weight of this argument. Recommendation 5 says that there is a need for an MA classification for video and computer games to protect children 15 years and under from unsuitable material. The minister says that some states and territories will not have this MA rating, allowing access to games for people under the age of 15. This loophole will be closed very soon because the parliament now has before it new uniform Commonwealth legislation, the Classification (Publications, Film and Computer Games) Bill which will solve that problem.

Recommendation 11 says that the length of tenure of censorship board members needs review. Unfortunately, the government has ignored this recommendation. The committee during the hearings became greatly concerned about the way the office of film and literature classification operated. We believe a lot of the problem comes back to the way the board is staffed. People are there for a very long time. A number of them are ideologically driven. They are desensitised and there is no proper community input.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an outrageous suggestion.

—It is not an outrageous suggestion. I refer Senator Schacht to the annual report which lists the people who are part of that board. Virtually all of them are either lecturers in journalism or are journalists. The chief censor keeps telling us that it is a representative cross-section of the community, but it is not. It is a number of trendy journalists who have a particular ideological view—and it is driving censorship in this case. We have made a number of very sensible recommendations including that the chief censor becomes the chief executive officer. We believe that the government would be wise to follow this recommendation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the committee that put this report together, it was unfortunate that I could not speak the last time it was presented. I have had to wait this long to say a few words about the matter. The report that was put together was called In the public interest. In the seven years I have been in this parliament and considering the number of committee reports I have been involved with—they have been numerous, as they are for every senator in this place—I have to say this is probably the most involved report that I have been associated with.

PARA.TAB: I suppose the main reason for that is the huge amount of personal evidence we were given. We heard a whole litany of evidence from people who felt betrayed, who had sought justice, are still seeking justice and have not received the justice they should have received.

My motivation for becoming a part of this committee—and I believe every other member of the committee had similar motivation—was the number of people who approached me on a personal basis about injustices they believed had been forced upon them, whether they be in the Public Service, the police force, the bureaucracy or private enterprise. I know that one of the reasons why the chairman, Senator Newman, brought this matter forward was a case involving a person in Tasmania who, I am pleased to say, has received some sort of justice since this report was brought down. He has received a financial payment from the bank that he was having problems with. That all appears in the evidence.

It was not an easy job converting all of the evidence into a readable report. I congratulate at the outset Elton Humphery, Yvonne Marsh, Sue Irvine, Angela Stanley and Winifred Jurcevic for their excellent work in putting together this report in such a professional manner, and also my fellow members of the committee—from all areas of the political sphere—who put together a unanimous report with, I believe, very significant recommendations.

We were most impressed with the genuine evidence that was given to us throughout the inquiry. Whilst I will later touch on some of the personal things that I remember so well about this report, I would like now to touch on the major recommendations. They fell into three categories. We felt, first, that it was very important to change the attitude of people towards whistleblowers and the public interest benefits that proceed therefrom. It was very easy to get the impression during the hearings that people can easily be tagged as dobbers. I suppose most Australians do not like a dobber. In the cases of the people we spoke to, they were genuinely concerned not only about their jobs but about the organisations they worked for. They were mostly concerned that no action had been taken in lots of cases and in other cases they had been victimised and shunned for trying to do the right thing.

Secondly, we felt that the procedures that currently exist fall very short of the mark. The internal systems and reporting systems that should exist within organisations, whether they be in the private sector or the public sector, were just not good enough to deal with the cases of maladministration or corruption that people were finding in the system. In estimates committees and as part of our parliamentary duties we get evidence all the time of waste, of mismanagement and of fraud. It is most important that people be encouraged to report those matters so that not only can justice be done but also the government can save what would run into many millions of dollars.

The most important recommendation we made was the recommendation for the creation of an independent public interest disclosures agency and a board to undertake and oversee that agency. One of the concerns we had was that a lot of the people who came before us had been through the system as it exists. They had been to merit protection and review agencies, the ombudsman and all sorts of people. Initially, these people went straight to their immediate boss. One of the things that came to my attention and impressed me was that, in these long drawn-out cases, the initial report that was done on a particular public servant, or whoever, almost became the benchmark. If people looked at a case further down the track or went for justice somewhere else, whoever was investigating that—whether it was the ombudsman or whoever—always went back to the first report that was made by the superior officer or the manager of the person making the complaint, and there was a mind-set. No matter what happened, that initial report—no matter how good or how bad it was—became the standard for what followed.

I think this is why it is most important that we have an independent agency to which a person who feels he has not received justice by going through the normal process can go and know and trust in the people he is dealing with. The board we recommended would consist of nominees from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission, the Privacy Commission, the Commonwealth Ombudsman's Office, the Merit Protection and Review Agency, a recognised whistleblower support group, a public interest advocacy centre, an ethics group, a trade union and other national community organisations. There would also be a parliamentary involvement, with the appointment of a senator and member of the House of Representatives. I believe we would have a totally independent and well-intentioned board and agency that could handle the huge amounts of requests which are coming from people within the Public Service and private enterprise.

We were somewhat critical of one or two cases, particularly in Queensland. I will not go into any great detail about those particular cases. My colleague Senator Woodley, from Queensland, has touched upon one of the cases involving a person called Kevin Lindeberg. My colleague Senator Parer spoke about the same matter. I know that Senator Chamarette has the same sorts of feelings that I do about this. So we have four senators who, after hearing dozens of witnesses, at the end of the day came down with the same opinion: that Mr Lindeberg was sadly done by. I refer to a press report which appeared in a newspaper in Queensland and in which he had the opportunity to put his point of view. He said that he was still a member of the Labor Party even though he has not received any justice from the Labor Party in the state government in Queensland. We noted in our report our concerns about this particular matter and about unresolved cases.

The CJC looked at the matter. We do not believe the reply it gave us was satisfactory. The issue all revolves around the state minister Ms Warner, the shredding of the Heiner documents and the accusations that the Goss cabinet deliberately misled the state archivist. Senator Woodley has already very eloquently put that matter forward.

In the evidence that was given to us it was harrowing to see witnesses break down. I will never forget one particular case. A professor who was giving evidence to us had, on that very day, been removed from his office because he dared to criticise the vice-chancellor about research in the university and where the money was going. It was not only unusual but very memorable.

I note from a letter from the Premier of Queensland, who refuted our criticisms, that the Queensland government has subsequently produced and passed comprehensive whistleblower protection legislation in the time since Senator Woodley made his comments. (Time expired).

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to speak for very long, but I would like to congratulate the members of the committee who produced this particular report. I wish to especially recognise Senator Newman and Senator Calvert. People in Queensland who appeared before the committee felt that those two senators were particularly sympathetic to their cause and have continued to pursue the issues on their behalf. Many of those people believe that the only glimmer of hope they have had in all of this has been this particular Senate committee. It just shows the importance of the Senate. It underlines the critical role of the Senate—and especially Senate committee—in Australian history and politics.

PARA.TAB: I would add that some of the evidence given to the whistleblowers committee will be the subject of an extended program on Channel 7 next Tuesday night at 8.30. Honourable senators may be interested in seeing that program. In addition to the names that Senator Calvert has mentioned, I might mention some of the other witnesses such as Des O'Neill and Gordon Harris who are still pursuing what they believe to be injustices perpetrated against them.

If State governments will not take action, then I believe that the Senate may have to continue its surveillance of the situation of whistleblowers in Australia and follow up on the recommendations that have been made. I believe that the work of the Senate committee in this regard is not finished and may need to continue. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister for Human Services and Health Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women
Senator S. West
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator

I refer to the report of the Committee's Inquiry into Breast Cancer Screening and Treatment in Australia which was tabled on 9 June 1994. The report was very timely for the Program as it amassed a large body of information, including statements of view from many influential individuals and groups. This information will be extremely useful in developing policy and planning for the future of the Program.

A Government response to the report was due within 3 months of tabling. However, many of the issues raised in the report are outside the scope of the Department and we are in the process of consulting widely with other Commonwealth Departments, and the State and Territory Governments to formulate a response.

The following general comments in response to the report are provided for your information at this stage. On the whole, the report supports the general direction that the National Program for the Early Detection of Breast Cancer is taking. The outcome of the Inquiry was strongly supported by the State Program Managers.

The report recommends that the Commonwealth Government, in co-operation with the States and Territories, undertake a national education campaign promoting the Program. Such a campaign is currently being developed and is due to be launched in February 1995. The campaign will be targeted at both women and General Practitioners and will specifically address some of the issues raised in the report. In addition, a Working Group on the Provision of Consistent Information to Women has been established. The role of this group is to liaise with the States and Territories to develop consistent messages on a variety of issues within the Program. This will ensure that State/ Territory education campaigns and general methods of information provision carry consistent messages across the nation.

The report recommended that the supply of radiographers and radiologists be regularly monitored by Commonwealth and State and Territory Governments. This is currently an issue of great importance within the Program and workforce issues remain a standing agenda item of the Commonwealth and State/Territory Managers meetings. The Commonwealth is currently developing a strategy to investigate the problems related to the supply of radiographers and radiologists for the Program.

The report also recommended that the Program improve access for women in rural and remote areas. Under the funding arrangements for the continuation of the National Program, funding will be provided to better enable the States/Territories to provide services to these women. That component of funding will be calculated at a higher cost per woman screened. The formal offer of this funding to the States/Territories will be made in September.

The National Advisory Committee has recently endorsed a paper titled Policy and Practice in Relation to Symptomatic Women in the Program. The statements in the paper are consistent with the recommendations in relation to symptomatic women in the report (Recommendations 11 and 12). It is intended that a number of similar policy papers will be written and included in a Manual of National Program Policy Documents. This will also assist in the promotion of consistent information about the Program to various audiences.

It has not been possible to undertake the level of consultation necessary to prepare an adequate response for tabling by 8 September 1994. It will also not be possible to respond to recommendations 18 and 19 until after the House of Representatives Committee has reported. It is expected that the Government response will be available for tabling by mid-November.
Yours sincerely
Dr Carmen Lawrence

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the government's response to the interim report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the financial report of political parties. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the response.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE INTERIM REPORT OF THE JOINT/STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS ENTITLED `FINANCIAL REPORTING BY POLITICAL PARTIES'

In May 1994 the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (JSC) resolved, pursuant to its more general reference covering the conduct of the 1993 election, to take evidence on the funding and disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (the Act). It did so in response to a number of representations on the administrative burdens imposed by the requirement for registered political parties to furnish to the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) Annual Returns of income and expenditure. This requirement was introduced by the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act 1991.

2. The JSC advertised its inquiry in the national press and in response received nine submissions from individuals, political party organisations and the AEC. Public hearings were conducted on 6 and 7 June 1994.
3. The Interim Report of the JSC entitled `Financial Reporting by Political Parties' was tabled in Parliament on 30 June 1994 and contained nine recommendations.
Recommendation 1

4. That Division 5A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and associated regulations be amended as necessary so that Annual Returns by registered political parties list a total amount of expenditure, rather than individual transactions within that total.
Response
5. Supported.

6. The Government remains fully committed to the essential objective of disclosure as expressed in the second reading speech of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 that "electoral financing in Australia should be open and transparent" to minimise the risks of corruption in funding political campaigns. The Government does not believe, however, that this objective is significantly enhanced by the requirement for parties to record and report transactions within set categories as currently set down in the regulations. The Government proposes, therefore, that the requirement for parties to disclose their expenditure under particular categories should be removed.

7. In order to maintain the spirit of the current legislation, the Government would wish to retain the requirement that payments to any individual or organisation equal to, or exceeding the threshold of, $1500 be disclosed. It would no longer require parties to disclose the individual transactions within that total. It proposes that the legislation be amended so that only transactions of $500 or more need to be aggregated when determining whether the threshold is reached. These changes would apply to individual party units and therefore substantially lessen the administrative burden placed upon them.
Recommendation 2

8. That section 314AB of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that Annual Returns from registered political parties are required to be lodged within 16 weeks after the end of the relevant financial year.
Response
9. Supported.

10. This recommendation is welcomed by the Government as it would enable more timely processing of Annual Returns by the Australian Electoral Commission prior to their release for public inspection. The Government realises, however, that the shortened reporting deadline would be a further burden on political parties if the reporting requirements were not streamlined and acknowledges that the shortened period is only practicable in terms of party administration if recommendations 1 and 3 are implemented.
Recommendation 3
11. That the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended as necessary so that $500 is set as the threshold for disclosure of individual amounts received and paid by, on or behalf of political parties.
Response
12. Supported.

13. The Government proposes that the recording and reporting of income received by political parties be simplified. This would be achieved by removing the reporting categories specified in the regulations and the requirement to report certain individual income transactions. It is proposed therefore that only where individual transactions exceed $500 will the particulars of those transactions be required to be recorded by party units. In addition, only where the total of such receipts (i.e. sums exceeding $500) by a party unit from an individual or organisation aggregates to $1500 or more would the source and total of that income then need to be disclosed. The requirement to disclose each individual transaction within those aggregates would be removed.
14. These changes would substantially lessen the administrative burden across the party, and particularly on the party agent.
Recommendation 4
15. That section 305A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that donors to registered political patties or State branches thereof are not required to lodge a return with the AEC.
Response
16. Not supported.

17. While the Government is in favour of simplifying reporting requirements as far as possible, it is of the view that there remains a need for sufficient checks to ensure that the integrity of the system is maintained. The Government sees one means of achieving this as being the maintenance of third party reporting which would enable an appropriate level of verification to be conducted by the AEC.

18. The Government does believe, however, that third party reporting should be made consistent with the disclosure requirements of political parties. The Government proposes, therefore, that the legislation be amended to require donors to lodge annual disclosure returns rather than submitting returns following an election. Consistent with this annual reporting requirement, the disclosure threshold would be reduced from $4500 to $1500.
Recommendation 5

19. That procedures for AEC compliance audits be amended so that agents of registered political parties are required to be present at local audits, and are responsible for presenting to the AEC such records for audit as are required.
Response
20. Supported.

21. There is nothing in the current legislation which prevents State agents or any other party official from being present at local audits, and indeed it has been the practice of the AEC to allow them to attend. The Government acknowledges, however, that the present provisions do not guarantee party agents the right to be present if they so desire. Accordingly, the Government is prepared to amend the legislation to provide party agents with the right to be present but, in order to retain an appropriate degree of flexibility for all involved, it proposes that the agent be given the power to delegate this responsibility or waive the right of attendance.
Recommendation 6

22. That Part XX (Election Funding and Financial Disclosure) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to clearly require disclosure of income received by registered political parties from any trust fund or similar fund or account, where such income is above the disclosable amounts set out in the Act.
Response

23. The Act already requires the disclosure by political parties of all income received from any trust fund or similar fund or account. The Government proposes that disclosure be extended to include not only the donations made to political parties but also the deposits of capital into such funds and accounts where the fund or account functions substantially for the benefit of a party or parties. The Government does not seek to impose retrospective disclosure in respect of past returns, rather it proposes that if the Party receives any future interest payment from the same fund or from any new fund containing all or part of the original fund then the base source of capital that earned the interest must then be fully disclosed.

24. The Government also proposes that the legislation be amended to ensure that there is full disclosure of the transactions of all bodies over which a party exercises control or which exist substantially for the benefit of a party or parties.
Recommendation 7
25. That Part XX of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended as necessary to enable parties to designate officers to sign correspondence on behalf of agents.
Response
26. Supported.
27. The Government would also aim to ensure that full accountability under the Act is maintained.
Recommendation 8
28. That section 294 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that the same amount of public funding is payable for a Senate vote as for a House of Representatives vote.
Response
29. Supported.

30. Currently a Senate vote attracts a funding rate equal to one half of the rate payable for a House of Representatives vote where both elections are held simultaneously or three quarters of the funding rate for a House of Representatives vote where the Senate election is held separately. The election funding rates applicable at the 1993 federal election were 100.787 cents for a House of Representatives vote and 50.393 cents of a Senate vote.

31. The Government proposes an increase in the level of public funding for a Senate vote so that it is equal to the funding level for a House of Representatives vote. The level of public funding for both Houses will be increased to $1.50. On the basis of election funding payments made at the 1993 federal election, this proposal would result in a budgetary increase in a joint House of Representatives and half Senate election of around $14.656 million.
Recommendation 9

32. That Part XX of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to provide that political parties registered on a national basis receive public funding for elections directly to their federal or national offices, via national agents. Where political parties registered on a State basis do not notify the AEC that they wish to receive public funding on a national basis, those parties shall continue to receive public funding through their State agents.
Response

33. To give effect to what it understands to be the intention of this recommendation, the Government proposes to amend the Act to require a party agent making a claim for election funding to provide a statement either nominating a registered political party to which payment is to be made or advising that the claimant party does not wish to make a nomination. Where a nomination has been made the AEC must make the payment to the nominated party. This will enable State/Territory branches of parties to nominate that payment be made to the National Secretariat of the party.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works I present the 9th report of 1994, relating to the mid-life upgrade of Blamey Barracks, Kapooka, New South Wales, and the 10th report of 1994, relating to the proposed stage 2 redevelopment of the Royal Military College Duntroon, ACT. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The first report I tabled involves the mid-life upgrading of Blamey Barracks, Kapooka, New South Wales. I would like to acknowledge the fact that Senator Woodley asked me if he could buy one of those mid-life upgrades, and I said that I did not know where he could buy them.

PARA.TAB: The committee has recommended that the project proceed at an estimated cost of $21.5 million. Most of the buildings at Kapooka were constructed in the 1950s and the 1960s and are now in need of refurbishment. Present working and living conditions at Blamey Barracks are below standard, with the rank and file and the recruit kitchen not meeting the building codes of occupational health and safety requirements. A need therefore exists to provide suitable working and living conditions for the recruits and staff stationed at Blamey Barracks, Kapooka.

While at Blamey Barracks, Kapooka, the committee was impressed with the green areas around the base. The committee compliments the Department of Defence on reticulated treated effluent from the sewerage treatment facilities being used to irrigate these landscaped areas at Kapooka.

During the public hearings concern was expressed that local industry would not be given an opportunity to be involved in the project. The Department of Defence has since held meetings with the building industry in Wagga Wagga and assurances were given that the construction manager for the project will not be tendering for construction works at Kapooka.

The committee was advised by the Department of Defence that it intends to conduct a seminar with the building industry in Wagga Wagga to discuss forms of contract and tendering processes. The Department of Defence advised that each package or trade element will be awarded as a result of a competitive tendering process. Local companies should therefore be in a strong position to make competitive bids.

The committee has recommended that the Department of Defence continues to have discussions with the building industry in Wagga Wagga and proceeds with the intention of conducting a seminar for the building industry in the near future. The committee has commended the Department of Defence on its willingness to liaise with members of the building industry concerning the proposed works.

The second report which I have tabled involves the stage 2 redevelopment of the Royal Military College, Duntroon. The Royal Military College is the premier institution for the training of officers for the Australian Army. It trains men and women in the skills of leadership, tactics, military law and administrative procedures.

The proposal examined by the committee involved the provision of modern and functional facilities to support the training objectives of the college and comprises a new logistics complex and headquarters building, extensions to the gymnasium, officers' mess, military instruction block and the medical centre, and the upgrading of playing fields and ovals, along with adjustments to the existing road network to provide safer and more efficient traffic circulation.

The committee has recommended that the work should proceed at an estimated turn-out cost of $28.7 million. A significant element of the proposed works is the construction of a new logistics complex. The committee concluded that the existing complex is housed in inadequate and deficient accommodation and should be replaced.

Another element is the proposed construction of a new headquarters building. The committee concluded that the proposed location and design of the proposed new headquarter buildings are consistent with the master plan and should be compatible with adjacent buildings. A feature of the redevelopment, which those honourable senators who travel to and from Canberra airport will notice when the work is completed, will be the provision of a new main entrance. This is dictated largely by the ACT government's proposed duplication of Morshead Drive, which was examined by another committee some years ago. The committee has recommended that the Department of Defence and the ACT government should discuss coordination of road construction with a view to the work being undertaken concurrently as soon as possible.

In connection with the upgrading of the playing fields, the committee was pleased to discover that the army has a pilot project under way involving the use of grey water to water the playing fields. If the pilot project proves feasible, substantial savings in water and funds will be achieved. The committee has therefore recommended that, if no salinity problems emerge, the use of grey water should be extended to all playing fields at Duntroon and the Australian Defence Force Academy, as well as other defence establishments where practical. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: DELEGATION TO HONG KONG AND THE PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Hong Kong and to the People's Republic of China which took place from 4 to 17 July 1994, and to move a motion in respect to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: It was my privilege to lead the Australian delegation to Hong Kong and China. There were eight members and senators on the delegation. The very able secretary was Ms Andrea Griffiths, from the Department of the Senate. I think she would be known to all in this chamber. She did an excellent job in looking after our requirements before leaving and while in Hong Kong and China.

PARA.TAB: We went to Hong Kong for four days prior to our visit to China. It was not my first visit to Hong Kong. I was a member of a parliamentary delegation that visited the territory of Hong Kong four years ago. It was interesting to compare some of the changes that have occurred just in that brief four-year period. The major and quite overwhelming issue for the future of Hong Kong is the reversion of sovereignty to China to occur on 1 July 1997. Clearly, that is a major economic and political issue for people who live in the territory of Hong Kong.

Whilst we were in Hong Kong, amongst other matters we paid a visit to the legislative council. We met leading members of the LegCo and it is our hope that there can continue to be links between the LegCo and the Australian parliament. We paid a visit to one of the detention centres, where we were able to meet boat people from Vietnam who are held in detention. I find this particularly depressing in the sense that these people are locked up for very long periods—in some cases, for years.

Some 24,000 refugees have been returned to Vietnam in the four years since I was last in Hong Kong. We have recommended that the only durable solution to the asylum seeker problem should be to continue to support the efforts of the Hong Kong government in returning back to Vietnam people who are not fearing for their lives because of political repression in that country.

Interestingly, a significant number of Vietnamese boat people in Hong Kong do not arrive by boat. They come over land through China. They are assisted by relatives or friends in southern China. They live under very trying conditions. I certainly think the policy of repatriation will give the signal to those refugees that attempting to enter other countries via Hong Kong is not a feasible proposition.

I have never been to China. I can recall in 1966, when I visited Hong Kong with my family, looking over the fence from Hong Kong into China. That was at the time of the height of the cultural revolution and people could not visit China. Looking across that same area today, one can see a city of some millions of people. That city has grown up in just the last decade.

What really hits one in China is the enormous economic changes that are occurring. China is one vast construction site. One cannot help but be impressed by the very significant economic growth, averaging about 12 per cent. That was clearly evidenced everywhere we went. Generally, the economic growth is widely welcomed by all sections of Chinese society. Of course, that comes at some expense. The pollution of the environment was quite obvious everywhere we went. There was quite severe air and water pollution.

Health and safety are issues of major concern, particularly in the workplace. Just before we visited Shanghai there had been a major industrial accident at a building site where a concrete pour had gone wrong and a number of people were killed. There is quite a serious level of accidents at the workplace in China. Interestingly, that issue and the issue of pollution of the environment are matters that are relatively openly discussed by Chinese people and by the official Chinese media. Corruption appears it be a significant problem. That, combined with the other issues, undermines confidence in the economic progress that is quite clearly being made.

The events of Tiananmen Square are certainly remembered by people. The delegation raised the issue of human rights on a number of occasions during the visit. Interestingly, China is not a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and is very actively seeking entry into GATT. The delegation raised a variety of issues, including better access for our semi-processed wool in particular. Various issues relating to access for horticultural products were also raised, including the issue of access for apples from my home state. I am pleased to say that, since returning from China, that has been listed as an issue of priority for consideration for technical assessment for phyto sanitary conditions to allow access for apples into China.

As part of the restructuring of the economy, there is a requirement by the Chinese government that a significant number of business enterprises become profitable and, in doing so, many of them are entering into joint ventures with overseas firms. The modernisation that is occurring in a number of areas—for example, management and capital upgrading—is again obviously leading to significant economic growth.

Also of interest was the fact that a number of the plants that we visited—for example, the ACI bottle factory in Shanghai—were employing the very latest in technology. The Chinese were not simply relying on lower costs—for example, lower wages—but they were also relying on the latest technology to ensure not just a significant increase in production but a significant increase in productivity.

It was again of interest to consider a bottle factory in Shanghai, amongst the most modern in the world, one of the largest in the southern hemisphere. However, the nature of the Chinese economy is such that the distribution system is very basic. In fact the bottles are hand-packed into hessian bags and then hand-loaded onto trucks for distribution within China. It is a very outmoded system of distribution which leads to a significant wastage of bottles through breakage. So one has this contrast between a very new technology, very modern techniques and high production and productivity levels in some areas of the economy, and a very basic distribution system in other areas.

An Australian business person, Mr Peng—this has certainly been raised in this Senate and the other place—has been arrested and held in detention for a significant period of time, between six and nine months. The delegation raised this issue in Hong Kong. Certainly the treatment of Mr Peng does not engender confidence as to the treatment of Australian business people in China.

They are just some of the matters I want to mention. I once again thank Andrea Griffiths, the secretary of the delegation, and my parliamentary colleagues for their cooperation on what was a very worthwhile trip.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add a few words to what Senator Sherry, the leader of the parliamentary delegation to China and Hong Kong, has just put on record. I was fortunate enough, with Julia, to be a member of the delegation and, as Senator Sherry said, it was indeed a fascinating experience. I do not wish to go over all the detail again; but in reference to China in particular, I would like to lift out a couple of points.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry mentioned economic development. Although China is indeed one vast construction site, it has reached rather differential stages of development. On our trip through Shaanxi Province, when we visited a school where the Australian Embassy had provided school books, which in itself was an experience, it was quite apparent that work both in the countryside in agricultural pursuits and in the cities in semi-industrial activities work was still being carried out in a very primitive manner.

If one adds to that the speed of development and the introduction of technology, one cannot help but wonder what the social and employment effects will be. Very clearly, not only thousands but millions of people will become unemployed as technology increases in China. That is one of the major problems that the rulers of China, whoever they may then be, will be faced with.

I also wish to address the subject of the legal system as it interacts with human rights issues. Over an eight-day period of negotiations with representatives from the department of foreign affairs of the Chinese Republic, I was finally able to get them to accept a list of 222 political prisoners who had been arrested following Tiananmen Square, as well as a list of the 16 Tibetan nuns. I got an undertaking to have these lists processed through the department of justice and through the department of internal security to answer two questions which I posed: firstly, what is the well being of these people at this stage? Secondly, is there any likelihood of an early release? So far, no answer has been received, but I have written to the department again today, coinciding with the tabling of this report, requesting that an answer be provided.

The argument that finally seemed to sway the departmental representatives to pay some attention to the human rights aspect was interesting to me. It was the argument that, if the legal system were being reformed to cope with corporations law, to cope with contract law, to cope with the general opening up of economic affairs with other countries, then people dealing with China or being asked to deal with China could not expect to have any confidence that the laws on corporations and contracts would be observed if the laws on the freedom and safety and security of individual persons were such that people could be, without due process, arrested and held. When in future we put forward human rights issues in our dealings with China, it will perhaps be useful to use that argument. If China wants to deal with us on an even footing as commercial partners, it must also accept the responsibilities of a legal system that guarantees the security of its citizens.

It would be remiss of me not to pay tribute to Senator Sherry as the leader of the delegation. It is in large measure due to him that the delegation was a success and was received with respect by dignitaries and other people in China. The delegation had the benefit of the services of Ms Andrea Griffiths, the Deputy Black Rod, who made sure in a very difficult environment that all the administrative details, of which there were many, were attended to with superb efficiency and with a cheerful face. The thanks of the delegation are due to both Senator Sherry and Ms Andrea Griffiths. I might add that although the delegation comprised members from across party lines, not only did we manage to survive the 15 or so days in a cooperative and friendly manner but we actually enjoyed each other's company. I will recall that trip with great pleasure in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
