SPEECH.PARA: EMPLOYMENT SERVICES BILL

Mr President, one of the major commitments in Working Nation is to ensure that the long-term unemployed get extra assistance to enable them to participate better in the jobs growth. The success of Jobstart in targeting long-term unemployed assistance is reflected in the drop in the number of long-term unemployed. The number of long-term unemployed has fallen by 53,000 over the last year and by 73,000 since the last election, that is, out of a total seasonally adjusted job growth in that time of 356,000 people. This is against a backdrop where, during the 1980's, it took seven years and 1.6 million jobs to cut long-term unemployment by 109,000.

This legislation takes the targeting measures one important step further; it significantly extends case management services and opens those services and their provision up to competition. Experience is that this targeting of intensive one-to-one servicing is very successful in improving the opportunities for long-term unemployed people to obtain jobs. Case management will provide a continuing relationship between a job seeker and a case manager. Together they will develop a personalised package of assistance that will focus on effective job searching and matching to identify job opportunities. Where job search activity fails to result in employment, labour market program assistance will be provided.

The aim of this legislation is to promote full employment by providing a free employment service and to draw on a diversity of public sector, community and private sector resources, to achieve this goal as cost effectively as possible.

This legislation will improve the quality and effectiveness of employment services through enhanced case management services for the long-term unemployed and those at high risk of becoming long-term unemployed.

The legislation provides the framework for development over time of an open competitive environment for the supply of case management services. A new regulatory body, the Employment Services Regulatory Authority (ESRA), will be established independently of the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET). One of its central responsibilities will be to encourage and facilitate contracted case managers to provide case management services in competition with Employment Assistance Australia which will be DEET's case management organisation, formed from part of the CES.

ESRA will promote competition and fair and efficient market conduct. These arrangements are intended to meet the needs of job seekers, employers and the local community while maintaining high standards of accountability and probity in the use of the public resources. The longer term aim of the legislation is for job seekers to have a choice of case manager. The legislation also ensures that there are reciprocal obligations on job seekers through the use of Case Management Activity Agreements which will outline an agreed course of action for the case manager and job seeker. Agreements will focus the efforts of case managers and job seekers firmly on attaining employment for job seekers.
The Commonwealth Employment Service and Employment Assistance Australia

The legislation establishes the Commonwealth Employment Service within the Department of Employment, Education and Training. This provision confirms that Australia will continue to meet its obligations under ILO Convention No 88 to provide a free public employment service.

There is provision for the establishment of a national committee to advise the National Director on the operations of the CES. A CES Advisory Committee already operates and will continue to operate under the provisions of this legislation.

There is also provision for the establishment of Area Consultative Committees (ACCs). Working Nation allows for the establishment of up to sixty area consultative committees to consist of representatives from local businesses, community organisations, local and state governments, regional development bodies, training providers and unions. These committees will provide an avenue for local input to program and service delivery decisions to ensure that CES services will complement local development and employment initiatives.
The legislation establishes Employment Assistance Australia as a separate organisation, within the department, to provide case management services.
As part of its regulatory functions, ESRA will monitor the operations of Employment Assistance Australia and make recommendations to the Minister about those operations.
The case management system

In Working Nation the government made an undertaking to tackle long term unemployment by providing individually tailored case management services. Case management involves a one-to-one service provided to job seekers with the objectives of placing them in jobs by matching their skills and capabilities with the requirements of employers. Case managers will provide continuing support to the job seekers before, during and after the program of assistance.

Case managers will work with the job seekers to negotiate Case management activity agreements. This will set out a course of action tailored to the particular needs of the job seeker and agreed between the case manager and the job seeker.

Case managers will provide counselling and job search assistance. This will be supported by access to labour market programs, such as vocational training, relevant remedial courses in literacy, numeracy or English language skills and community-based work experience or subsidised employment. The case management strategy will ensure that suitable assistance is offered and that the job seeker has an obligation to pursue agreed plans.
Participants in the case management system
Working Nation provides that case management will be available to:

PARA.TAB: short-term unemployed people assessed by the CES as being at high risk of becoming long term unemployed;
those who have been registered as unemployed with the CES for 12 months and are eligible for newstart allowance;
those eligible for Job Compact assistance; and
those covered by the Youth Training Initiative.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation provides for the Minister for Employment, Education and Training to make a written determination of the groups of persons, such as those I have just outlined, who are to become participants in the case management system. With this provision the government and ESRA will be able to manage the case management system so that the most effective use is made of available case management resources. This arrangement will be used to tailor assistance, in the first instance, to those in most need and those who are reaching certain points in being unemployed, such as those who are reaching the 12 months point of unemployment.
As time goes by, case management can be extended by the Government to other groups of unemployed persons, or otherwise be modified to reflect changing needs and priorities.
Referral to case managers
The CES will be required to notify and interview persons as they qualify to become participants in the case management system in order to assess their needs prior to referring them to case managers.

In making a referral, the CES must have primary regard to the client's preference for a case manager and several other considerations which are set out in a disallowable instrument, including the local availability of case managers and their ability to meet the particular needs of the client.
The longer term objective is that clients are able to make an informed choice of case manager and that the CES decisions would reflect few changes to job seekers' nominations.
Case management services

One of the responsibilities of ESRA will be to fully determine what are and are not considered to be case management services, which will be set out in a disallowable instrument. The case management market will be subject to considerable innovation over time and the use of a disallowable instrument will enable ESRA to respond to such changes while ensuring job seekers' interests are being met.

As part of delivering case management services, a case management activity agreement will be developed and agreed between the case manager and the job seeker. The requirements of the case management activity agreement will give force to the Working Nation emphasis on the reciprocal obligations of job seekers, especially those who have become eligible for the Job Compact. For example, the case management activity agreement will require a Job Compact client to accept any offer of suitable paid work or any offer of a placement under New Work Opportunities or the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme. Contracted case managers will have a responsibility to monitor a job seeker's activity against his or her Agreement and to provide relevant information to the CES.

The legislation will also require the job seeker's compliance with the case management activity agreement. The legislation provides that a case management activity agreement will take the place of a Newstart Activity Agreement or a Job Search Activity Agreement for the purposes of the Social Security Act 1991. Failure to enter into a case management activity agreement or to abide by the conditions of a case management activity agreement will have the same effect for the job seeker as failure to enter into a job search or newstart activity agreement or failure to comply with the terms and conditions of those agreements. In other words, it will lead to a deferment of allowances fora period of time.
Accreditation of case managers
ESRA will have the power to accredit case managers and its regulatory functions will be exercise primarily through the use of this power.

The details of the accreditation scheme are st out in a disallowable instrument. ESRA will make decisions to accredit case managers and to vary or cancel their accreditation. It will also be able to set and vary conditions of accreditation. ESRA may also issue a formal warning if a case manager contravenes a condition of accreditation.

The accreditation scheme will stipulate conditions which must be met before an applicant can be accredited s a case manager. It will also stipulate conditions which must be met in the ongoing delivery of, and reporting on, case management services to ensure that accreditation is maintained.

The use of a disallowable instrument to set out the detail of the accreditation scheme will allow ESRA to vary conditions of accreditation as the needs of the client group or the industry itself changes.

The legislation does, however, stipulate that a case manager may not demand or receive any fees from a job seeker for the provision of case management services. All case management fees are to be paid by ESRA. In addition the legislation requires case managers to lodge case management activity agreements with the CES and to provide information to the Secretary of DEET concerning a job seeker's compliance with a case management activity agreement.

One of the more significant accreditation decisions ESRA will be empowered to make is to specify classes of case management services. ESRA will ac credit case managers to provide either general case management services and/or one or more classes of specialist case management services. The initial classes of specialist case management services are likely to include, but not be limited to, services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, people with disabilities, people from a non-English speaking background, youth and people seeking employment in particular industries. ESRA will be able to change specialist classes as expertise develops and increasing numbers of case managers make specialisation in case management services more viable.

Once a case manager has been accredited, ESRA may enter into contractual arrangements with that case manager for the provision of case management services. Contracted case managers will be paid by ESRA.
Rules of conduct
The arrangements for the accreditation scheme stipulate adherence to rules of conduct declared by ESRA.

All rules of conduct are contained in a disallowable instrument, thereby allowing the scrutiny of Parliament over the regulation of the industry. Rules of conduct will also be published by ESRA and their operation will be monitored, evaluated and reported upon.

The disallowable instruments were tabled on 20 October 1994. Public hearings were held in Melbourne on 9 November 1994 and in Sydney on 10 November 1994. The period of public consultation runs until 21 November 1994.
Codes of Practice

The ESRA Board may declare codes of practice that relate to the provision of case management services. Codes of practice will be advisory in nature and ESRA will evaluate and monitor compliance with the codes of practice and report to the Minister on the operation of the relevant section of the legislation.
DEET assistance to case managers
Under the terms of the legislation DEET will provide two types of assistance to contracted case managers.

PARA.TAB: in addition to what is required in the referral process, DEET may be required to assist case managers, for example, by ensuring that information about the case management system and local case managers, perhaps in pamphlet or poster form, is available through CES offices. Any assistance which the CES is required to give to case managers is set out in a disallowable instrument; and

the Department Information Technology Assistance Scheme, also detailed in a disallowable instrument, will cover those aspects of information technology assistance the Department is required to give case managers from time to time. It is envisaged that DEET would charge case managers for Information Technology assistance on a cost-recovery basis and that the details of the charges would be among the matters covered in the disallowable instrument.

SPEECH.PARA: Establishment of Employment Services Regulatory Authority (ESRA)

The government has made the commitment to provide case management services to all long-term unemployed and those at risk of becoming long-term unemployed. This will involve approximately 500,000 people. The services are to be opened up to outside competition to help meet this commitment. Community and providers are to be funded to operate in fair and open competition with EAA in the delivery of case management services. Wherever possible, people being case managed will be able to choose between government and non-government providers.

The government has set clear targets for the numbers of cases it expects non-government providers to manage. In 1994-95, 10 per cent of cases will be managed by external providers. This will be increased to 20 per cent in 1995-96 and 30 to 40 per cent in 1996-97. The commitment to case management and the introduction of competition in its provision will ensure better outcomes for the long-term unemployed, improved levels of services for employers and better value for the money committed to funding the services.

As with the introduction of competition into other areas of government monopoly, there is a need for a regulatory authority. The legislation establishes ESRA and sets out its functions, powers and arrangements to allow the appointment of a board and chief executive officer.

The legislation allows ESRA to regulate the case management system primarily through its powers to accredit and select contracted case managers. It is also given specific powers to promote competition and to monitor, evaluate and report to the Minister on the operations of the case management system.

The legislation allows for an ESRA Board to be established with a Chairperson and between two to five members. The Board will have the responsibility to determine policies and will direct the Chief Executive Officer. The Governor-General will appoint Board members and the CEO by written instrument. Remuneration will be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. The appointments of both the Chairperson and the CEO are expected to be on a full-time basis. To promote linkages with the activities of NETTFORCE, the Chairperson of ESRA will be a member of the NETTFORCE board.

In order to ensure probity and effective performance of Board members, the Legislation requires declarations by Board members of direct and indirect pecuniary interests in any matters being considered by the ESRA Board. The Governor-General will have the power to terminate the appointment of a Board member on grounds of conflict of interest, unauthorised absence, bankruptcy or otherwise unsatisfactory performance.
Investigations by ESRA

The legislation provides investigative powers for ESRA to ensure the highest quality case management for unemployed persons and stringent measures against fraud and malpractice. ESRA will be able to investigate the action of the CES in referring people and providing assistance to case managers. It may also investigate the adherence of contracted case managers to conditions of accreditation, contractual conditions and rules of conduct. ESRA will also be able to investigate any contraventions of the Departmental Information Technology Assistance Scheme, rules relating to the use and return of case management documents and the duty of non-disclosure of information about clients.

Some matters which come to ESRA's notice may be more appropriately dealt with by the Ombudsman, a Departmental Secretary, the Trades Practices Commission or the Privacy Commissioner. The legislation also allows ESRA to refer such matters to these Agencies. Obligations in relation to client rights and protection, such as those covered by the Privacy Act, Freedom of Information Act and the Ombudsman Act, equivalent to those that apply to the Australian Public Service, will be imposed on contracted case managers, contracted case managers' adherence to anti-discrimination legislation will exist by virtue of separate legislation in those areas.
Monitoring of Compliance

To further ensure that there are effective anti-fraud measures and safeguards against malpractice, the legislation enables ESRA to appoint inspectors with formal powers to undertake searches, gather information and seize documents.
These powers may be exercised for the purpose of monitoring compliance by case managers with the conditions of their accreditation and the agreements under which they are engaged.
Review of Decisions relating to referral to Case Managers and Decisions Relating to Case Management Activity Agreements

Clients will be referred to case managers by the CES taking into account client preferences, needs, and the circumstances of local case managers. The legislation provides for access to a review of this decision by an Authorised Review Officer. Appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is also provided for. There will also be access to these review mechanisms with respect to decisions about case management activity agreements.
Review of ESRA Decisions

A case manager, or a prospective case manager, may request a review by ESRA of a decision ESRA has made about its accreditation or disqualification. The legislation also allows for review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of a decision that has been confirmed or varied by ESRA.
Annual Report

As with standard requirements for regulatory authorities, the ESRA Board is to furnish an annual report, for tabling in Parliament. It is intended that the report will cover concerns which the CES has reported to ESRA regarding the activity testing efforts of EAA and contracted case managers and will include evaluation of how rules of conduct and codes of practice are operating and the extent to which contracted case managers meet the standards required by their accreditation conditions. The annual report will also include a copy of ESRA's audited financial statements and any directions given to it by the Minister.
Conclusion

This legislation reflects a bold and imaginative venture by the Federal Government. Together with the Job Contract and new incentive to employers through training and wage subsidies, it will better equip us to tackle unemployment and, in particular, long term unemployment. It will encourage into this field many community and business organisations which will bring with them special expertise, local knowledge and links with employers. In doing so they will provide a much wider range of choice of service for job seekers, and improve job seekers' chances of returning to employment.

This represents a radically new approach. There is currently no well developed non-government case management market and many providers will be learning as they go. Equally for the government and for ESRA it will be very much a matter of learning by doing. While the legislation seeks to be as specific as possible, it also reflects the certainty that many new problems will emerge over time and there will be a need to set down detailed aspects of the new arrangements quickly to address unanticipated needs and problems.

The legislation includes a number of safeguards against inappropriate use of powers. It provides for disallowability of instruments that define a number of key aspects of the arrangements. This will allow Parliamentary scrutiny of those arrangements. At the same time, the legislation gives ESRA and the Minister the power to act quickly and effectively to ensure proper protection of one of the most vulnerable sections of our community—long term unemployed people—from exploitation by the unscrupulous.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
EMPLOYMENT SERVICES (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994
This bill makes consequential amendments arising from the Employment Services Bill.

The bill repeals Part VI of the Employment, Education and Training Act 1988, under which the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) is currently established. The CES is being re-established by Clause 8 of the Employment Services Bill 1994.
The bill provides for the extension of the Privacy Act 1988 to the provision of case management services by contracted case managers.

The amendments to the Freedom of Information Act 1982 provide for members of the public to have rights of access to documents relating to case management services that are held by contracted case managers.

The bill provides for the Ombudsman to investigate complaints about contracted case managers. The Ombudsman would be able to refer those complaints to the Employment Services Regulatory Authority (ESRA) where it is considered the complaint could be more appropriately dealt with by ESRA. The current provisions of the Ombudsman Act would already extend to the operations of Employment Assistance Australia.

The Ombudsman would be able to provide information on matters relevant to the operation of the case management system to ESRA without the need to make a formal report to the responsible Minister in all cases.

The bill amends a number of provisions in the Social Security Act 1991 to provide for the disclosure of information to contracted case managers by the Secretary to the Department of Social Security and to insert notes cross referencing relevant provisions to the Employment Services Act 1994.

Proposed amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 also address difficulties created by recent amendments to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No 2) 1994. The amendments related to the reciprocal obligations of persons who receive Job Search Allowance or Newstart Allowance under that Act.

The amendments were intended to provide for a period of notice to an allowance recipient before a deferment period was imposed because she or he had breached her or his obligations under the Act. The intended effect was that a person would receive an additional two instalments (four weeks) of Job Search Allowance or Newstart Allowance before payment of allowance was cancelled.

In practical terms, what these amendments seek to accomplish is a return to the procedures that existed prior to 4 July 1994. It is the Government's view that these procedures ensured that a person received sufficient notice of the consequences of failing to respond to a particular requirement made by the CES, before a decision was taken that the person was in breach of that requirement.

Prior to 4 July 1994 the process for activity test breaches was that when an apparent breach of the activity test was identified, the person was contacted by the CES and given an opportunity to explain why he or she had failed to meet the particular requirement (for example, a request to attend a job interview, or participate in a training course). If the person's explanation satisfied the CES that the person had taken reasonable steps to comply with the requirement, or had sufficient reason for not complying with the requirement on this occasion, he or she was informed of this and no breach action was taken. If on the other hand, the CES was not satisfied with the person's explanation, the person was told that breach action would proceed and that a penalty (deferment period) would be applied, usually at the end of the current allowance pay period. These procedures ensured that the person received direct, personal notice of the penalty before it was applied.

The process ensured that a person was fully informed of the consequences of his or her failure to respond to a specific requirement to contact or attend the CES. If the person did not respond within 14 days of the first requirement, a second warning letter was sent to the person, reiterating the requirement and stating explicitly that if the person did not contact or attend the CES by a date 14 days hence, the person's allowance would be cancelled. This second letter not only gave the person a second chance to respond, but also gave prior notice of the penalty and when it was likely to be imposed, if the person failed to respond.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs examined these procedures as part of its consideration of the proposed amendments. On the whole, the Committee was satisfied that the procedures provided sufficient notice of deferment of income support, without the need for additional payment periods.

The amendments have also raised a number of matters of administrative and technical concern for both the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education and Training who are responsible for the administration of this legislation. For example, a deferment period cannot be expressed to commence until after the notice specifying the commencement date is actually received by the client. Therefore the decision maker is being asked to make a decision on an event about which he or she could not be certain at the time the decision is made.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to lunch, I was addressing some comments about the issue of cooperation between the state and federal governments. I was speaking in response to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Collins). He said that the effect of our amendment mandating that the federal government consult with state governments would be that, if a state government were recalcitrant and did not cooperate, the process would fall down. The minister had picked on the Court government, saying that there would be quite a lot of potential for it to be recalcitrant.

PARA.TAB: I had made the point that every state government besides Western Australia had agreed to pass complementary legislation under the native title regime, although none of those pieces of legislation have been proclaimed. The Western Australian government passed its own legislation, which both the federal and state governments regard as being not complementary. I also made the point that the Court government in practice had been extremely cooperative with the National Native Title Tribunal. Senator Chamarette has been made aware of that in hearings. I think it would be worthy of the minister if he is aware of the facts—and he may not be—to recognise that.

I know that the Aboriginal affairs people within the Premier's department have regular contact with the Native Title Tribunal people in Perth, and the Lands Titles Office in Perth is providing total access to all the tenure histories. These are all very important matters for the Native Title Tribunal to deal with.

Also, I would say in response to this matter—because it is important and I am not going to let any federal government minister get away with bashing Richard Court and his Aboriginal affairs policies; we may not agree with all of them; I am sure Senator Chamarette does not either—you cannot ignore the fact that one of the first things Richard Court did when he became Premier of Western Australia was to commission a task force on Aboriginal social justice. To this inquiry he appointed Mike Daube, who could never be considered a Liberal Party sympathiser and was formerly a very active member of the health department and a strong campaigner on smoking and health.

I would be happy to actually table the reports of this inquiry if I were given leave, but they are readily available. The Daube inquiry: the task force on Aboriginal and social justice, volumes 1 and 2, makes excellent reading. I know the minister probably has far too much to read already, like all of us. But I do thoroughly recommend reading the volumes of this report. They give I think—and I do not know whether Senator Chamarette has read them—an absolutely thorough analysis of the delivery of services to Aboriginal people in Western Australia, state and federal government assistance and programs, and a very thorough analysis of past failures and recommendations for the future. I might even just send this across the chamber when we adjourn tonight so that the minister can read the executive summary. It will only take him a couple of minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll give you leave to table the volumes if you'll stop talking.
—I seek leave to table the two volumes and the executive summary.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. I will not delay too long as that is not really what I am trying to, but I will respond when the minister criticises the Court government in relation to this issue. There is a perception amongst the community that the Labor Party seems to care more about Aborigines than does the Liberal Party. We know from past history that that is not the case, that it is just not simply true or fair. But the perception exists out there and, of course, in politics perception is reality. But I repeat: the perception is not true.

PARA.TAB: The Court government received this report, the cabinet considered it thoroughly and made what is a most unprecedented response to it: it has undertaken to implement each and every recommendation of the report. To do it may take a while, but they have made that recommendation.

Some of the recommendations—and I refer specifically to page 280 of volume 1 of the task force on Aboriginal and social justice—do refer to the issue of Commonwealth-State relations. I will quote from that, but I want to quickly quote from some of the other leading recommendations. One is, the need to establish a comprehensive state Aboriginal affairs policy. Remember, this report came out after 11 years of Labor government in Western Australia, with ministers, such as Ernie Bridge, a very dedicated Aboriginal affairs minister, and 11 years of federal Labor government. It is committed to Aboriginal affairs and has won a perception for the Labor Party that it is dedicated to Aboriginal affairs. This is a report that takes a snapshot of Aboriginal affairs after 11 years of federal and state Labor governments. This is the report which Mr Daube authored as chairman. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: .Comprehensive state Aboriginal affairs policy—
11 years on, no policy—
.More effective consultation with Aboriginal people—
something we are advocating here today—
.A strategic plan for Aboriginal affairs achieving long-term and short-term objectives;
.An influential department responsible for Aboriginal affairs—
Is that not incredible? The state does not have an influential department for Aboriginal affairs after 11 years of Labor government—
.A reliable and up to date database for planning;
.Effective monitoring and evaluation of mechanisms
.Increased accountability in relation to funding and better processes to ensure that funds are directed to those they are intended to assist—
intended to assist—
.More effective coordination between the levels of government—
and this comes to the very heart of this amendment. I repeat:
.More effective coordination between the levels of government within government and regionally—
and, again, right to the heart of this amendment—
and between government and non-government organisations.
It goes on—we have had the two volumes of the report tabled so we will not read all 296 recommendations:

It is not the role of the task force to apportion blame for problems of the past or to identify in any other than broad terms why certain problems now obtain. It is, however, important not to avoid the issue that we currently have virtually parallel systems aimed at dealing with Aboriginal affairs.
This goes back to the issue of duplication that we were discussing before lunch. The report continues:

The operation of these parallel systems results in much duplication and even more confusion and cannot be seen as working to the benefit of either Aboriginal people or the community at large. The remit of this task force is to consider the role of State government agencies. The role of Commonwealth agencies is, however, of such importance that it is relevant to discuss their role and structure also, in the context of making structured recommendations on a more fruitful and co-operative relationship.

There is no documentation clearly identifying the respective roles of Commonwealth and State governments. While there is implicit agreement and relatively satisfactory working arrangements in some areas, both in other areas and overall the situation is unsatisfactory.

I recommend this report to the minister, particularly the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner. I guess it would be against his principles to read anything that emanated from WA, just on the basis that it came from that state. But it provides very good reading. I certainly hope that the people who have responsibility for Aboriginal affairs, both within PM&C and, of course, Minister Tickner's office, would at least read some of that report. Even if one research officer were to read it, it might help relations between Western Australia and the Commonwealth in this very important area. The issue of consultation which is highlighted in that report again makes the case for the amendment that would require consultation with the states.

PARA.TAB: The issue of timing was raised by Senator Kernot and by the minister, again building up this picture that all of this consultation would ensure that it would take forever to get these strategies up and running. I will knock that argument over as quickly as I can. The minister argued this morning that the current consultation provision—that is, that you must consult with the ATSIC regional office and then you can consult with whoever else you may think is appropriate—was a catch-all that would obviously envisage consultation with other people in the area and possibly even, dare we suggest it, state governments.

The reality is that if the ILC operates efficiently, as we hope and expect it would, as a matter of course, it would negotiate with the state governments and, as a matter of course, it would, we would hope, negotiate with other land councils and other Aboriginal communities that would have a stake in the process. The reality is that by actually saying, `We think you should do this and it is important that you do it,' the time that it takes to do it should make no difference because if the job is done properly, these things should be done, anyway.

By way of example, if you wanted to go to the Kimberleys in Western Australia—and this is a very practical example—you would be mad not to speak to the Aboriginal affairs people within the state government. You would be absolutely stupid not to do so. They have shown they will cooperate. They have already cooperated with the Native Title Tribunal. When the ILC goes there and starts determining its regional strategy, we know that in effect it would probably be a matter of ringing up the Premier's office or Minister Kevin Prince's office, making an appointment and having a briefing from those officers who are responsible for that part of the government's land policy in relation to Aboriginal affairs. The briefing, I am quite sure, would take possibly half an hour or an hour. They could quickly lay on the table some maps, programs and policies and be cooperative, and that meets the requirement of this provision. I think that is all that it practically takes. It is just common sense and I think it is important that it be mandated and not left to the ILC. I think it would be inadvisable for it not to proceed along this track.

So on the point of timing, I summarise by saying that the answer to the question raised by Senator Kernot by way of interjection is that if the ILC is doing its job properly, it will not take one nano-second longer under the provision that the Greens and the coalition are supporting than it would under the existing provision in the bill. It would not take one nano-second longer to get the strategies up and running and get the funding into operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on the public record that we were discussing the change to the wording before lunch. I mentioned the words `as far as possible' in relation to qualifying the way in which state or territory government consultations should go to ensure that the strategies complement the existing state and regional acquisition management programs. It was suggested to me that, if I used the phrase `as far as is practicable', it would match the words used in clause NA. I am happy about that, so I suggest that we accept that change to the wording of section J7C. Accordingly, I seek leave to amend my amendment.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask one more question before I make up my mind on the moneys not to be distributed until a regional strategy is prepared. Does it make a difference if it is money for management? What if there is an urgent need for management, compared with acquisition? Under this plan, it is still money for nothing until the regional strategy is prepared.
—It is a good question. I would be happy for the minister to respond.
—Our interpretation is that it would apply to all moneys, management and acquisition.

—I think the principle is that moneys are to be distributed prior to an integrated strategy being developed. I realise the time constriction, but if we do not abide by that, or if the board in its application of the legislation does not abide by that, it could generate ill-feeling from the whole community. However, it would be different if the board had a good reason.

PARA.TAB: The principles that we are supporting in this amendment ensure that in the legislation there will be an obligation to have an integrated strategy that is open and able to be assessed for its validity. That is not to constrict anything. It is to help the Aboriginal community see that there is something in place to balance justice and equity across Australia. I think there is a danger of ad hoc allocations, even on urgency. I am one of the worst offenders. If something is urgent, I am more likely to address it than if it is important. I think that is the same danger here, where we have a very small amount of money.

There may be people who are well prepared to make an urgent request. It may be an obvious urgent request, and there may be a great temptation on the board to meet it because of its validity. But there may be an unseen, equally urgent case somewhere else. By allowing that whole process, even if it is in relation to management, to hold matters up is a problem. I see not putting a time limit as leaving it in the ILC's hands as to how it devises that strategy. Hopefully, it will balance the immediate and urgent needs that we have had in this country for years and years of the need to establish credibility as an equitable agency in terms of allocating the funding, whether it is for management or acquisition. My support of the amendment does not alter. Obviously, it is something that the chamber should take into account.
Amendments (Senator Chamarette's) agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (20)Clause 3, page 11, after subsection 191N(6) add the following subsections:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Copy to be tabled in each House

PARA.TAB: " `(7) The Minister must cause a copy of the national indigenous land strategy or of any changes made to the national indigenous land strategy to be presented to each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the Minister has received the document.

PARA.EMPHASIS: National indigenous land strategy etc to be disallowable by either House of Parliament

PARA.EMPHASIS: Land not to be purchased, moneys not to be distributed, etc, until after national indigenous land strategy has been tabled etc.

PARA.TAB: " `(9) The Indigenous Land Corporation must ensure that no land, or interest in land, is purchased and that no moneys are distributed for the performance of its functions under sections 191D and 191E before the time has expired during which either House may disallow, or be deemed to have disallowed:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the national indigenous land strategy; and

TAB.TAB: (b)if the national indigenous land strategy has been disallowed or deemed to have been disallowed by either House, a new national indigenous land strategy.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment relates to section 191N(6), which relates to the tabling of the national strategy. Subsection (7) says that the minister must cause a copy of the national indigenous land strategy, or any changes to it, to be presented to each house of parliament within 15 days of that house sitting after the minister has received the document. There may be a typographical error there; my copy does not have `the house sitting'. I think it should have that in there. In any event, I will return to that in a moment. Subsection (8) states:
The national indigenous land strategy, and changes made to the national indigenous land strategy, are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.
It goes on to state in subsection (9):

The Indigenous Land Corporation must ensure that no land, or interest in land, is purchased and that no moneys are distributed for the performance of its functions under sections 191D and 191E before the time has expired during which either House may disallow . . . the national indigenous land strategy;

On behalf of the opposition, I can see that there is some concern with subsection (9) because that would mean that nothing could happen until that time for disallowance had passed. I note Senator Kernot's reservations about how long the formulation of these strategies might take and how that might delay the delivery of this benefit to those for whom to it is intended.

PARA.TAB: The coalition is conscious of that one. However, the problem is that if we are to make it disallowable and say, `In the meantime, you can go ahead and purchase the land and perform your other functions as outlined therein,' and the ILC has gone ahead and purchased land and entered into all sorts of arrangements and then we disallow it, we run into trouble because it has then acted in a way which is ultra vires really because we have now disallowed the strategy. We cannot untangle the web which already would have been weaved. That is why we have inserted subsection (9).

The main interest that the coalition has in this amendment is in subsections (7) and (8); that is, for parliament to have some sort of scrutiny over the strategy. It may be argued that if we set up a board like the ILC, we should not have any scrutiny. I would point to other areas where regulations are made, are subject to scrutiny and all sorts of instruments are disallowable across a whole range of activity in the quasi-government jurisdiction.

It would take a majority to disallow it, so it would be no mean thing if, say, the Aboriginal community at large were at great odds with this national strategy and went to its elected representatives and said, `Look, we don't like the strategy as it is. We want it changed. We believe the ILC has not considered the matter carefully enough and we want parliament to debate the matter and to disallow it.' Of course, if the matter were of sufficient importance and attracted a majority of parliament, I would submit that it would need to be ventilated in this place. It would have to be the coalition plus the Greens, an Independent, the Democrats or even the government agreeing. Nonetheless, for it to be disallowed it would have to be a matter of grave concern.

The opposition is perhaps more ambivalent about subsection (9), to the extent that there are conflicting interests. We do not want to unnecessarily delay the delivery of the benefit. But, at the same time, we want to have some parliamentary scrutiny so that there is some other access for the strategy to be reviewed by parliament. It could be successfully reviewed only if there were a majority. I submit that, if we were able to get a majority to disallow, we would have to have pretty strong arguments to begin with. That is basically the sum of this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats do not have a problem with the first part of this amendment requiring a copy of the national indigenous land strategy or any changes to be presented to each House of parliament within 15 sitting days. But I do have a major problem with subsection (8) and subsection (9). Despite Senator Ellison's eloquent exposition, there is a fundamental problem and conflict here.

PARA.TAB: All the way through the debate those opposite have been saying, `Let Aboriginal people decide. They know best.' Even under this mixture of freedoms and prescriptions that the opposition has given the ILC it is still ultimately saying that all non-indigenous Australians in this place ultimately still know best. We have this incredible multilayered consultation process that we have just imposed on the ILC. But we are still saying that we have to have final scrutiny because, ultimately, we still know best about what makes up the best national strategy. That is what we are saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only a majority of the parliament.

—It does not matter if it is a majority. We are still saying that the majority of us know better. I do not accept that. I think disallowable instruments are reasonable in some cases but not after having imposed the structures that we have just imposed on the ILC. I do not think the two hang together anymore.

PARA.TAB: We will look at the annual report in the way we look at the annual reports of so many other statutory authorities. We will have other avenues for parliamentary scrutiny the way we always do. I do worry about the effect of delaying. I am worried in that the cumulative effect of all the changes we have imposed has the capacity to delay. At the very end of all that, we still add this final trump card: to continue to delay. I will not be supporting the second and third part of this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of Senator Kernot's remarks, it might be easier if we take these separately. Subsection (7) could be taken on its own and subsections (8) and (9) could be taken together.

—I want to make what would be regarded as a last ditch attempt, even though I do recognise some of the difficulties. We do not want to unnecessarily delay—we have already said that quite honestly—seeing the strategies devised. It is possible that, under the disallowance provisions, in an election year, for example, the regional strategies might be prepared in December and 15 sitting days may be a hell of a long time coming. I think in 1993 it took something like about four months to get 15 sitting days. The coalition does recognise that problem.
—During which time the corporation could not function.

—That is right. We do recognise that. That is why the coalition would be very happy for subsection (7) to be supported. However, the principle behind subsections (8) and (9) is worthy of note. The point that Senator Kernot made about—
—If you don't like it, withdraw it.

—No, it is okay. We do need, as I indicated privately, to divide on these things. I am just saying that I do recognise the problem. It should not be a problem unless there is an early election, because if the strategies are prepared on time, it would not take long for 15 sitting days to occur. I wanted to address the one argument and that is the `we know better' argument. It is not actually `we know better' because all of us represent Aboriginal constituents. We represent lots of constituents.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that the original concept of this was to ensure that the documents were tabled so that they would be available for the eyes of all the world to see. I want to go through the logic of it for the record so that when someone comes back and reads this debate in 30 years time, they will understand—God help them—why this amendment was put up. Under the government's bill, the strategies could be prepared and given to the minister, and no-one else would ever see them.

This was the thinking behind the coalition's amendment, to ensure that it is tabled and to ensure that any Australian, and particularly Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians, will have access to the strategy. In the meantime, we have come up with some other consultation provisions which have just been passed. That ensures that the consultation is broader, but it is still important that anyone who is going to be affected by the strategy—any Australian at all—does have access to it. Subsection (7) will cover that. The thing about disallowance is that it does create an imperative upon the strategy reflecting the views of those people.

So if the strategy was to be tabled here under subsection (7) of the amendment and it was made available to Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders around the place, and they all of a sudden said, `Look, this is a disaster. They have really made a mess of this strategy. We don't like it'—

TALK.START.PARA: —You gave them the right to do that, remember. You said, `Self-determination is the right to make mistakes.' That is what you said.
—That is right. This is the ILC board we are talking about. This is the ILC board that is all appointed by the—
—Well!

—Sorry, Senator Kernot. I will go back over the whole philosophy of our approach, and that is to give more self-determination and more responsibility to the individual Aboriginals and their communities, and to make sure that the ILC board is not just a puppet of the government. What we are saying here is that we are actually forcing accountability onto the ILC board. If they stuff up their strategy and the Aboriginal people are not happy with the strategy, there is a provision here to ensure that they can come to Senator Kernot as their representative.

PARA.TAB: The Cape York Land Council could come down here and say, `Senator Kernot, we are very upset with this national land strategy. I am so glad that those coalition senators stuck to their guns and got this disallowance put in. We want you to disallow it because it is a disaster for us.' If Senator Kernot received overwhelming representations from Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, she would come down here and say, `Minister, this is a disgrace. This national land strategy is nothing like we envisaged on 10 November 1994. It is a disgrace. It does not do anything that the minister said it would do. Mr Keating has misled the Australian people here again and we, the Democrats, are going to disallow this instrument.'

TALK.START.PARA: —But I am not making up the strategy. Aboriginal people are presenting it to—

—Yes, the ILC is making up the strategy. This is the national land strategy. This is to be tabled. I am just saying that I think it was a sensible way to go. I started by saying that I do perceive that there is a potential problem if we have 15 sitting days. As we have said—and I said quite honestly and openly—if Mr Keating does want to have an election early next year, it could be a long time between now and when 15 sitting days have occurred. We recognise that reality and we recognise the reason why the Greens and the Democrats have said they are going amend the motion to take out subsections (8) and (9). But I did think it was important to put on the record the thinking behind the coalition's amendment.
—It will be good to read that in 30 years.
—I bet I will never do it. That is the philosophy, that is what I wanted to put on the record, and I will sit down.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the only thing Senator Campbell has said that made any sense. First of all, I thank the opposition for agreeing to split the amendments. We have no difficulty in supporting part (7). I have to say that, in terms of Senator Campbell's statement that he thought it was useful to place the opposition thinking on this issue on the public record, I am delighted he has done so. What Senator Campbell has just told us is that he recognises—I know he does—the complete unworkability of parts (8) and (9) but in fact will divide on them. If you can work out the logic of that, you're a better man than I am, Gunga Din.

PARA.TAB: I do understand Senator Campbell's position. What I accept is that Senator Campbell, I guess, is expressing a personal view that he does recognise the potential unworkability of parts (8) and (9) but that he has an obligation in this chamber—as we all do, I might add—to represent his party room and divide. Senator Ellison is nodding, so I guess he is confirming this view. He obviously got rolled in the party room on this one. But I have to say that the Hansard record will make interesting reading afterwards. It will show the spokesperson for the opposition acknowledging that these are unworkable amendments but insisting on taking the chamber to a division in supporting them.

The bottom line—this is what I find profoundly objectionable about these amendments—is that the measures proposed in these amendments do not apply to any other indigenous body that the Commonwealth has established. They will be an unprecedented shackle on this body not suffered by any other commercial body. And people have the hide to come in here and talk about paternalism, as Senator Kernot has rightly just said, and supporting Aboriginal self-determination. I have no doubt the Greens cannot support (8) and (9).

TALK.START.PARA: —They have already said they haven't.

—Fine. I did not know that, but I am delighted to hear that they have said that. We are unnecessarily being taken to a division for the opposition to support amendments which Senator Campbell himself does not agree with, on his own statement in the parliament. We are going to waste a bit of time determining this great point of principle. I will not say anything else. I am sorry I was not aware that the Greens indicated that they would not support this. It will be done, and I guess I should be done as well.

PARA.TAB: I make the point that Senator Campbell is correct. This does have the potential, when parliament is prorogued, depending on the time it is prorogued, to completely stop the operations of this organisation for months—not weeks or days, but months—and that is totally unsupportable.

TALK.START.PARA: —We get back to the point that I made to Senator Gareth Evans quietly last night. We could have had the vote just then, but Senator Collins has to distort what I said on the record and then distort what I said to him privately. I went across and privately said to Senator Collins, `I would suit the coalition that we split this up. We might just have to have a division on parts (8) and (9) just to put our vote on the record.'
—You said that on the public record.

—I did not say that this is unworkable. I said that it has the potential to unreasonably delay the workings of the ILC if the Prime Minister calls an early election. If he does not call an early election, it will not unreasonably delay the workings of the ILC at all. We have 15 sitting days coming out of our ears between now and next March. We are back here in January. If what the minister is saying is that they are going to get the regional land strategy prepared—
—It will not be ready by next January.

—Of course it will not be. Officials of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet said to someone at the Australian Financial Review—it is at the bottom of an article in today's paper—that they expect that the whole legislation will be rewritten. So basically we are wasting our time here anyway. The whole thing is a charade. Who were the officials who told the Financial Review that the legislation is going to be rewritten? Did anyone from the PM&C say that? Did the Financial Review make it up? Did Michael Dwyer make it up?
—It is not even relevant. Let's just get on with it.

—It is relevant. I am now going to correct the record. What I said was that this was the initial scheme. It is not because we know better. It is not paternalistic. It is because, if the ILC comes up with a strategy that the Aboriginal people do not like, those people have the option to see it on the table and if they do not like it they can go to any senator or member of the House of Representatives and say, `We do not like this. We want you to disallow it.' So it is empowering the Aboriginals. It is empowering the people of Australia. That is what it is doing.
—It disempowers them.

—It does not disempower the Aboriginal people; it empowers them. Minister Tickner or Mr Keating—whoever the genius was who dreamt up this bill—created a system whereby we can have a national strategy but no-one can see it except for the minister and the members of the board. Not one single other Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander is allowed to see the national strategy. It is secret. This amendment ensures that every Australian can see it. That is what we are saying.

PARA.TAB: The reason that (8) and (9) are now not so crucial to the opposition is that we have put in, with the support of the Senate—we did not have this support a few days ago—all of these other consultation provisions. We have provided that Aboriginals in the regional areas have to be consulted. The government's bill did not provide that they had to be consulted. We have now asked that these people be consulted. So the consultation is wider. The principle remains that there is no reason why any other Aboriginal Australian cannot see the strategy. I am glad that (7) will receive support.

I have not consulted with Senator Harradine so I do not know whether he wants his vote recorded on this amendment. But he can indicate his view if he wishes to do so. As it is quite obvious that (8) and (9) will go down and since we have now put clearly on the record our thinking, the progression of where this amendment came from and why it is there—if the minister wants to get up and have another go, I will get up and respond again—as a magnanimous gesture I will not call for a division and draw out proceedings for another four or five minutes. Clearly, it is not necessary. Senator Harradine might have a different idea and I respect his right, as a senator representing Tasmania, to require a division if he wants to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just clarify one point that Senator Campbell just asserted. It is wrong and I want to put it on the record now that I have found it. Senator Campbell asserted that the government's intention was `to have these plans secret documents'. I refer Senator Campbell to page 12 of the bill, which states:

PARA.TAB: The Indigenous Land Corporation must make a copy of the national indigenous land strategy or a regional indigenous land strategy available to any person who asks for a copy.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not quite sure how much more public it can be. It was never a secret document. In conclusion, I thank Senator Campbell for his courtesy in indicating that if it is clear the support is not there for (8) and (9), he will not be moving to a division.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to subsections (7) and (8)—
—There is an amendment before the chair to delete (8) and (9).
—So we are sticking with (7)?
—We are supporting it.

—What do we do with this when it is tabled in parliament? We should uphold the very important principle that the parliament have a final say on matters about which the citizens of this country have specific concerns and on which the government of the day has a major input. The key point is whether the government of the day has a major input. Part of our responsibility as auditors of executive government actions is just that—to ensure that measures which result from a decision of a board appointed by the executive government of the day in some way come back to us.

PARA.TAB: It has been said by Senator Ian Campbell that there may well be a number of Aboriginal people who are very concerned about a particular aspect of the strategy and that, if that is the case, they should have some final right of appeal. It is not that the government is going to determine what the strategy will be. Even if it were able to get the majority view of the particular chamber, all it would be doing is disallowing the matter and the strategy would go back to the ILC.As I see it, that is as important for the Aboriginal peoples as it is for the parliamentary system itself. It is important for them because they are electors; they are the people who help to chose whether we sit in this place or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will just keep sending it back until they get it right. We can't amend it.

—Is Senator Collins seriously suggesting that a minister of the day could not have undue influence over a particular decision of the board in respect of the development of a national indigenous land strategy? Is that what he is saying?

—No. I don't make the connection at all, Senator Harradine, with what I just said and what you just asserted. I wonder why that great principle was not applied to other acts that have been passed in respect of indigenous organisations?

—I will just check that, but I think we did have a disallowable instrument. My memory is quite vague but I have a feeling that, in one of the pieces of legislation that came through, we did have a matter that was disallowable. Correct me if I am wrong, but the record will show that one way or the other.
—I am sure all the regulations subject to the ATSIC bill are disallowable.
—Regulations, of course, are disallowable.

—That is right. I believe it is in the interests of the Aboriginal persons as electors, as persons who put us here. I am not happy with part (9) because it would unduly interfere with the way in which this is run, so I am not able to vote for that. It is important always to uphold the duties of this parliament in respect of the executive government actions, whether they be direct actions or indirect actions. Here the minister appoints the members of the board and the members of the board make the decisions. I cannot readily accept that any minister at some stage might not try to influence a member of the board he has appointed. Therefore, in my view, this is the way to safeguard undue exercise of ministerial pressure.

—I would just like to put the Greens' position on the record even though people have referred to it. We certainly support part (7) but we do not support parts (8) and (9), and we are glad that those parts will be debated separately. I agree with what Senator Harradine has said. I do not think we should lightly dismiss the option that the national strategy be tabled in parliament and be a disallowable instrument because there is a large element of government control, as Senator Harradine has pointed out.

PARA.TAB: The Greens feel that at all points our amendments have been directed to trying to make the ILC as separate from government as possible. We feel that, if we make it something that is answerable to parliament, while it may recognise that government component this may cause it to have more power than it should. We feel that the responsibility of the ILC is to be accountable primarily to the people. That is why we have moved the regional strategies approach.

Our feeling is that, if the national strategy becomes a disallowable instrument, because our parliament has failed Aboriginal people I think almost totally in really meeting their aspirations, their dreams and their values, it would be inappropriate that we should have the final say, even if our democratic system were operating in such an effective way that we could represent all the Aboriginal people who are within the areas that we come from.

I think this should not be dismissed out of hand because—and I think this is where there is a slight difference between the government and the Australian Democrats in terms of what the opposition, Senator Harradine and the Greens have been saying all along about some of these amendments—we see the ILC as a government body. All our amendments have been derived around controlling that in order that it be more responsive to the people and more separate from government control. The only measures that we have included are the ones that we feel support the ILC's accountability to Aboriginal people and communities. The measures that we resist are the ones that tie it into government. Unlike the opposition and perhaps Senator Harradine, I feel that parts (8) and (9) tie it in far too much to government and parliaments. We are not at that useful stage where we have enough Aboriginal representation in this parliament to be an effective voice in those concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to respond to a couple of points. I appreciate the points that Senator Chamarette has made. I think Senator Harradine further reinforced the fact that just having the national strategy tabled is not entirely satisfactory. If we can convince the Greens to contemplate taking out part (9), which is clearly going to go down as no-one will support it—
—They definitely will not support it.

—Senator Ellison says that they definitely will not support it, but I will give it a go. I will firstly respond to what Senator Collins said about the strategy being available to any person. I was using political rhetoric by saying it is secret. The reality is that the requirement is that the minister and clearly the members of the board get the document. The advantage of having it tabled here is that, if there is any controversy about it, it will become a national political issue.

PARA.TAB: We all know that virtually any Commonwealth document is available to anyone who asks. People can go to an Australian Government Publishing Service bookshop and get virtually any document that this Commonwealth government prints. It prints a hell of a lot each year. So I admit that saying it was a secret document was of course political rhetoric and not intended to deceive my colleagues in this chamber or anybody else. But the reality is that the importance of tabling it, which I have stated twice already and I am very glad it was supported by Senator Harradine, is that it places a constraint on the minister and the board because it ensures that the whole world is aware of the strategy.

The fine point about, and the importance of, part (8)—which I get to in a last-ditch effort to ask Senator Chamarette to support part (8)—is that the mere tabling of the document is, as Thomas Hobbs would have said, a covenant without a sword. It is of little effect. It does have the effect of ensuring that at least the document becomes public and, if people are unhappy with it, they can raise concerns about it. But the fact is that there is no penalty on the government if the strategy of the ILC does not reflect the hopes, aspirations and wishes of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people whom we seek to serve.

In relation to the point that Senator Chamarette makes about trying to keep it away from this parliament, I understand her philosophy. I am learning more and more about her self-determination philosophy—particularly over the last few weeks—and am beginning to understand it. As Senator Chamarette and I have said privately, and even on the Howard Sattler program on 6PR the other morning, there is a meeting of the ultra libertarian, anti-institutional philosophy of the Greens—I am again putting words into Senator Chamarette's mouth—and the libertarian aspects of liberalism. Even though we respect some institutions, we are very worried about too much government control over people's lives.

This is a crucial issue. Part (8) is very important to me and that is why I said I would like to divide on it. The point I am getting to is that there is a difference. Many people in Australia think of parliament as government. They think we have too much government because we have local, state and federal parliaments. They conceive that government is actually all of the members of parliament, in their white cars and with their flashy allowances and overseas travel. Highly intelligent business colleagues of mine in Perth say, `Look, surely we could cut government by getting rid of state parliaments.' A bit of expenditure would be cut but parliaments are not a particularly expensive part of government. Senator Chamarette understands this because, on all of these principles of making government accountable to the parliament, she is always on our side. Just about every time since she has been here, she has voted with us when we have tried to have Auditor-General's inquiries, more responsiveness—

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that her make the third faction of the Liberal Party?

—That is probably drawing a long bow. My point is that this is making the ILC accountable to all of the people and specifically to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, who have an enormous stake in this. As I said, the ILC's land strategy can be tabled if one has a covenant without a sword—to steal Thomas Hobbes's idea—but, if it does not satisfy the people and they are not happy with it, there is no covenant and no disallowability.

PARA.TAB: Taking away the thing that I know worries Senator Chamarette most—which is that people cannot go and buy something until the national strategy is finalised—gets over the major hurdle. It is just saying that the strategy has to reflect the hopes and aspirations of Aboriginal people. If it does not they will ring up Senator Chamarette, me, Senator Ellison and the minster and say, `This is just a disgrace. We want you to disallow it.' Without that disallowance provision, part (7) loses a bit of its clout. I ask that Senator Chamarette give consideration to this. Time will ensure that a vote will not be able to be taken on this amendment tonight but I hope that, over the weekend or on the plane back to Perth, Senator Chamarette gives this amendment some serious consideration.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That, for the reasons set out in paragraph (4) and subject to paragraph (2), orders of the day for the consideration, or further consideration, of bills introduced into the Senate before 1 July 1994 (category A bills) are to take precedence over orders of the day for the consideration, or further consideration, of bills introduced into the Senate after 30 June 1994 (category B bills).

(2)That an order of the day for a category B bill may not be called on in precedence to an order of the day for a category A bill unless, immediately before the order of the day for the category B bill is to be called on, the Senate agrees to a motion on notice that consideration, or further consideration, of that bill not be postponed until the first day of sitting of 1995.
(3)That this order cease to have effect after the last day of sitting in 1994.
(4)The reasons referred to in paragraph (1) are as follows:

TAB.TAB: (a)there should be an orderly debate of bills in accordance with some general chronological priority based on the principle that bills introduced in one sittings should preferably be debated in the next sittings;
(b)such a priority reflects and ensures effective use of the time available:
(i)to Senators to research the implications of the bills, consult the community, prepare speech notes and draft any necessary amendments, and
(ii)to the media and the public to become aware of the possible effects of proposed laws; and

(c)where the Government wishes the Senate to depart from that general chronological priority, the Government should justify each such departure in debate which concludes with a resolution of agreement by the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being past 7.20 p.m., under sessional order I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Chinese Australians in First World War

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —With Friday being Remembrance Day, and millions of Australians pausing at 11 a.m. to remember the fallen of all wars, I feel it appropriate to draw to the attention of the parliament, and the Australian people, the contribution of our secret army in the First World War. The secret army to which I refer is that group of Anzacs who were in fact ethnic Chinese and who, by virtue of the regulations of the day, were never meant to have been allowed to enlist in the first place.

PARA.TAB: It must be remembered that, prior to the outbreak of the war, Australia's first years of Federation were absorbed in part by the efforts of the unions and the Labor Party to impose the White Australia policy. This was because of the fear that Australia would be taken over by Chinese.

While many think that the Chinese population of Australia in the 19th century was composed entirely of itinerants on the goldfields, the truth is different. In fact, Chinese Australians were market gardeners, cabinet-makers, labourers, merchants and shopkeepers, but it was their role as shepherds and shearers in New South Wales that was most contentious, for it was part of the basis for the formation of the Australian Workers Union. In his poem, A Bushman's Song, Banjo Paterson wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: I asked a cove for shearin' once, along the Marthaguy:
`We shear non-union here,' says he. `I call it scab,' says I.
I looked along the shearin' floor before I turned to go—
There were eight or ten dashed Chinamen a-shearin' in a row.
It was shift boys, shift, for there wasn't the slightest doubt
It was time to make a shift with the leprosy about.
So I saddled up my horses, and I whistled to my dog,
And I left his scabby station at the old jig-jog."

One of the motivations for the formation of the union movement was the influx of Chinese workers into the pastoral industry, and the fear of their arrival in Queensland may have been one of a few factors behind the shearers' strike. Certainly the term `scab' was applied to the non-union Chinese who were thought to carry leprosy. Even after the turn of the century, Chinese and other Asians, especially Pacific islanders, were excluded from membership in the Australian Workers Union.

PARA.TAB: Against this background, therefore, the army, at the outbreak of the First World War, was obliged to reject, for anything other than non-combatant duties, any recruit who was not substantially of European origin or descent. The stupidity of these regulations can be seen in a letter written to the Argus by Mr George Kong-Meng on 20 January, 1916. I seek leave of the Senate for a copy of the letter to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RECRUITING STUPIDITY
TO THE EDITOR OF THE ARGUS.

PARA.TAB: Sir,—Having answered the Prime Minister's appeal for recruits, I journeyed to Melbourne to offer my services to my country. I attended the recruiting depot at the Melbourne Town Hall on Friday, the 14th inst., and after giving my name, age, and religion to the recruiting sergeant I was sent in with some others to the examining room, and told to undress, preparatory to the medical officer examining me as to my physical fitness. After my height, weight, and chest measurement had been taken by one of the officials there I was sent to the medical officer. Upon going before him I was told to get dressed again, and when I asked if I had failed to pass the medical officer said he would not swear me in. When leaving the depot, I received a certificate with "not substantially of European origin" written on it, and signed by the medical officer, Captain N. J. Gerrard. With the exception of being asked where I came from, I was not asked one question whilst before the medical officer. Now, sir, for your own guidance, I might state that my father was a British subject, born at Penang, S.S., and arrived in Australia in 1854. My mother was born in Tasmania in 1842, and I myself was born in this State in 1877. I have had six years' military training in the old Victorian Mounted Rifles, and 8th Australian Light Horse Regiment. My brother is at the front serving his King and country, having gone with the 1st Australian Division, and holds the rank of sergeant, but evidently the authorities at the Melbourne Town Hall depot seem to think I am not worthy of helping to defend the Empire. The Prime Minister has appealed to every man of military age to join the colours; but, if this is the treatment the native-born are to receive, I am afraid the appeal will fall on deaf ears. England and France deem it fit to use coloured troops to defend their shores, but the great Australian democracy denies its own subjects the same opportunities. I might state that I have gone to Melbourne on two occasions to offer my services to my King and country, and, after paying all travelling expenses, to be treated like this does not give one any encouragement to go again.—Yours, &c.,

SPEECH.PARA: GEORGE KONG-MENG.
Longwood, Jan. 20.

TALK.START.PARA: —The regulation was not only discriminatory but also ludicrous in light of the nationality of Australia's allies who were at that time fighting beside Australian troops in Gallipoli, in France and in the Palestine campaign, for they included Italians, Indians, Maoris and Japanese. In spite of these regulations, many ethnic-Chinese did enlist in the AIF, and their heroism, bravery, and in some cases sacrifices, showed them to be truly the stuff of which the Anzac legend was made.

PARA.TAB: While it will never be known exactly how many ethnic Chinese enlisted, in part because Eurasians with European fathers are now impossible to identify, I wish to tell the tale of a number of these brave men to preserve forever the contribution they made to the forging of our nation.
