One of those who enlisted at the outbreak of the war was William Edward `Billy' Sing, who was born in Clermont in Queensland on 2 March 1886. His father, John Sing, was a Chinese born in Shanghai. His mother, Mary Ann Pugh, was born in England.

This small, dark man with the jet black moustache may have been Eurasian, but he was certainly not slow to enlist. His service number 355 shows that he was part of the original contingent of the 5th Light Horse. Arriving on the rocky shores of Gallipoli, he was assigned to the dreaded Quinn's Post, which was manned mainly by Queenslanders.

Lest anyone think that all Chinese are short-sighted with thick glasses, I should point out that Sing was a crack shot in an army of crack shots. As a young boy growing up around Clermont, it is said that he was able to shoot the tails off piglets at 25 yards. So it is not surprising that he quickly gained a reputation as an extraordinary sniper who, during his time at Gallipoli, was officially credited with felling over 150 Turks and is believed to have accounted for a further 50 unofficial victims. It was Sing, too, who won a deadly duel with the Turkish sniper known as Abdul the Terrible. In recognition of his achievements and bravery, he was awarded the Distinguished Conduct Medal and the Belgian Croix de Guerre.

Unfortunately, after returning to Australia, Billy Sing never did find a great fortune, although he did eke out a living on a gold lease before retiring to Brisbane, where he died of a heart attack at 304 Montague Street, South Brisbane, on 19 May 1943. Although he may not have been rich in monetary terms, there is no doubt that Billy Sing was rich in courage, spirit and loyalty to his country. A few years ago, a plaque was placed on the wall of the warehouse which now stands where Billy Sing passed away. I seek leave of the Senate to have a copy of that incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: AT REST
WILLIAM EDWARD (BILLY) SING (DCM)
Born Clermont Qld. 2.3.1886—19.5.1943

SPEECH.PARA: Reg. No. 355 Australian Fifth Light Horse Regiment and later the 31st Infantry Battalion

PARA.TAB: Son of JOHN SING (bn. SHANGHAI) and MARY ANN (nee PUGH bn. ENGLAND) AND MARRIED FOR A TIME TO ELIZABETH (STEWART) IN EDINBURGH 29.6.1917.

SPEECH.PARA: A man of all trades, Pte. Sing was awarded the Distinguished Conduct Medal for conspicuous gallantry, the Belgian Croix de Guerre and mentioned often in despatches. Serving at Gallipoli and in France from 1915-1918, he became known as Australia's most effective marksman/sniper accounting for more than 150 of the opposing forces.
His incredible accuracy contributed greatly to the preservation of the lives of those with whom he served during a war always remembered for countless acts of valour and tragic carnage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another Chinese Australian Anzac was Private Caleb Shang who lived most of his life in North Queensland. Shang enlisted in the 45th Battalion and went on to become the most decorated Chinese Australian soldier of the war, winning a DCM and bar as well as a Military Medal. The citation to Shang's DCM during the battles around Messines Ridge in 1917 is inspiring. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: "For conspicuous gallantry and devotion to duty on numerous occasions. He acted as a runner for four days through barrages of fire swept areas, carrying water, food, and ammunition to the front line. He attacked enemy snipers in broad daylight and accounted for them. In addition to this, he constantly volunteered for dangerous patrols into enemy country, where he gained valuable information as a scout, and also showed remarkable skill in improvising lamp signals in a very dangerous position where he would send information to Battalion headquarters. His conduct showed a never-failing example of fearlessness, resource and initiative."
Not far away, another Chinese Australian, Lesley Henry Kew Ming, was in action with the 23th Battalion and won the Military Medal at Polygon Wood. The citation reads:

"Whilst digging the communication trench to newly captured front line at Broodseinde Ridge on 9.10.1917 he set a fine example to his men and encouraged them to satisfactorily complete the work though under heavy shell fire. He remained on duty though wounded until ordered to R.A.P."

After returning home from the war, Les Kew Ming settled again in his home town of Minyip, Victoria, before moving on to Echuca. While living in Echuca he set what was then an Australian record punt kick of 74 yards in Aussie rules, as well as the record drop kick of 73 yards, which stood until broken by H. Hughson of Fitzroy in 1943.

PARA.TAB: Les Kew Ming is also interesting in that both his father, Hi Kew Ming, and his mother, Louisa—the daughter of local bootmaker, Cum Moon—were Chinese Australians. In spite of this, he was given the opportunity to enlist and to serve his country, in large no doubt because of the attitude of a sympathetic local recruitment officer. No doubt a similar explanation is behind the enlistment of Walter Quan, who was born in Koondrook in Victoria to James and Ada Quan, and enlisted at Meekatharra on 23 September 1915 where he stated his occupation to be a miner.

Quan's medical certificate upon enlistment stated him to be five foot nine and a quarter with a 37-inch chest, dark complexion, dark hair and blue eyes. I have seen a lot of Chinese and a lot of Eurasians, but I have never met one with blue eyes. Of course, if Quan's medical certificate said he had blue eyes, it was prima facie evidence that he was not substantially of European descent. It was no doubt on that fiction that he was allowed to join up. Having completed his training, Quan was assigned to the 13th Reinforcement 16th Battalion on 17 December 1915 and embarked for Egypt on the Runic, arriving in Alexandria on 26 February 1916.

By this stage, the urgent need for men on the Western Front saw him transfer to the 48 Battalion and shipped to Marseilles on the Caledonia in June. In the murderous carnage around Pozieres, he was reported missing less than two months later on 8 August 1916 and now lies beside hundreds of his fellow Australians in Serre Road Cemetery in France. He was awarded the 1914-15 Star, the British War Medal and the Victory Medal.

When the war was over, surviving Chinese-Australian Anzacs returned home to start a new life. Some, like Sam Tongway, found new opportunities open to them as result of the training and education they received while in the forces.

In 1939, war broke out again. Chinese Australians again enlisted for the war in large numbers and served in all the forces. They were fighter pilots like Roy Goon, sailors like `Bo' Liu, as well as soldiers. They even included amongst their number members of the elite Z Force, such as Jack Sue. Some, like Wellington Lee, later went on to prominence in public life after leaving the services.

Others, while not enlisting in the army, navy or air force, enlisted in the merchant marine. According to Arthur Gar-Lock Chang, who was the assistant secretary to the Chinese Seamen's Union and who came from the same village as my grandfather, as many as 2,000 Chinese served in the Australian merchant marine during the Second World War.

The speech I have been able to put together is not exhaustive, but it is a start. I hope the work can be continued. I am grateful for the assistance I have received from Mr Gilbert Jan and Mr Lionel Nomchong, both Chinese Australian World War Two veterans, as well as Margaret Thompson and Marie Woods of the Australian War Memorial, who have patiently dealt with my every request. Their unstinting efforts show a true love and devotion for the memory of our war heroes. I have here a roll of honour completed by Mr Gilbert Jan of those veterans known to be Chinese Australians, and I seek leave for it to be tabled.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The tales of the men I have mentioned are tales of courage, loyalty to Australia and honour to their families. The reason I have told their stories is not to raise them above other Anzacs but to do them the service which has been due to them for far too long—to honour their memory and their love of this country. All Chinese Australians should be proud of the contribution their community has made to the building of our nation. On Remembrance Day, let us commemorate their sacrifice and be proud of the freedoms they won for us. Lest we forget.

—The federal government has a policy that it is not implementing. It is called the national forest policy but, like many of this government's promises, it exists on paper only. The government has taken the jargon, used the rhetoric and hoodwinked us into believing that it might do something to protect our forests. Thanks to Senator Collins's recent information, we now know that there are still no adequate comprehensive and representative areas protected by the policy.

PARA.TAB: The government has had about two years in which to implement it and it has only year to go before it is all supposed to be finished. But nothing is being done. I understand that, as part of the permit process, the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) has to consider the advice of the Minister for Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner). But the way the woodchip export licence for north-eastern New South Wales was granted to Sawmillers Exports Pty Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary of Boral, illustrates just how poorly this government implements its own policies and just how useless that process is.

Senator Faulkner offered quite reasonable advice to Mr Beddall in that process, advice which sought to protect the best areas of old-growth and wilderness forest from logging, which sought to protect endangered species, and which attempted to set in place the comprehensive adequate and representative reserve system that the government's own policy requires. According to a detailed analysis by North East Forest Alliance, whose series of successful land and environment court actions in New South Wales has forced New South Wales State Forests to improve its EIS processes and endangered fauna measures, Mr Beddall's licence process is a joke.

Of the 26 recommendations made by Senator John Faulkner, 17 were not accepted, four were heavily modified and only five were accepted without change. I suggest that it is the five that were the least onerous in terms of Mr Beddall's interpretation. Some examples of those rejected recommendations were: that areas nominated for wilderness should be excluded; that habitat trees should be identified and protected; and that harvesting should preserve adequate vegetation to protect water quality and habitat.

Clearly, Mr Beddall has thrown out most of the environment minister's advice and put a little window-dressing in its place. But he has not stopped there. He has indicated to Boral that he will `consider issuing an additional licence to cover the increased volume if that proves necessary.' Where does that leave the government's commitment to phase out export woodchipping by the year 2000? Perhaps that was another joke like the licence and its other policies. If we return to the Boral licence we see that Mr Beddall in flagrant disregard for of government's commitment wrote, `I will consider issuing an additional licence to cover the increased volume if that proves necessary.'

The notes I have here describe Mr Beddall's `incompetence', but I would suggest that as the resources minister he has been particularly overzealous and he is leading to deliver us an impotent environment minister. Whatever way we describe it, what we are left with is a failure to actually implement government policy. I really do not know what it is that is being implemented. We have a thing called government policy but that is not what is being implemented. It is perhaps an ideology or a direction, but it is not what is publicly paraded as government policy.

It extends to the heart of Mr Beddall's responsibilities under the Environment Planning (Impact of Proposals) Act. Under that act, he is required to ensure that there is proper environmental assessment where there may be significant impact on the environment. That is the clue that delivers us exactly what it is he is guilty of. Under that act, he is guilty of incompetence.

However, in his wisdom Mr Beddall has decided that the current environmental impact statement for the Sawmillers' export licence should suffice not just until 1996 but perhaps for 10 or 15 years more. Not only does this prevent the federal government from phasing out woodchipping by the year 2000, but it is also questionable implementation of the legislation. Mr Beddall's suggestion that Boral's use of woodchips from sawmill residues and logging residues does not have a significant environmental impact is plainly wrong.

The timber industry has developed the euphemism `integrated logging' to describe what is little more than forest mining. About half of the logs that are taken from the forest under clear-felling are woodchipped. The country does not get the sort of economic benefit from woodchipping that is touted by the government. The ordinary people of Australia lose out in two ways with export woodchipping. They lose the forests, our unique wild and diverse areas, and they lose out economically.

Woodchipping mills account for only one per cent of jobs in the forest industries and since the arrival of woodchipping in Tasmania more than 4,000 jobs have been lost from the forest industry. According to the Resource Assessment Commission's timber industry inquiry, native forest logging, including woodchipping, has run up a $5 billion debt over time with the state forestry commissions.

Mr Beddall's woodchip troubles did not start with the Boral licence, they started during his early days in the portfolio. In June this year Mr Beddall announced that he had granted an export licence to Gunns Ltd in Tasmania to ship 200,000 tonnes of woodchips from Bell Bay or Burnie. At the time the company had no buyer for this product and it did not know where it was going to send it from.

In documents obtained by the Australian Democrats under freedom of information, we discovered that Mr Beddall failed to require an EIS for this approval, arguing that the additional volume did not require an additional EIS. The minister seems very keen to exercise his ministerial discretion where the woodchip industry is concerned but not when the environment is at risk. The result of Minister Beddall's work on these two licences is that he is now facing two Federal Court actions which question his competence as a minister.

What we have here is a government policy designed to provide resource security to the timber industry—a frightening prospect for the community's interest in our public forests. Sadly, the national forest policy is another example of this government's broken promises. It is a policy which would be mediocre at best anyway, with a handful of useful commitments the government has been unwilling to meet.

Of course the federal government will blame it on the states, which also signed the statement, but the states must also share some of the blame. Their performance has been appalling. While all this finger pointing is going on, the forests are falling day by day; ecosystems are being destroyed day by day; and our environment is ravaged day by day.

In issuing the export licences, the federal government has the opportunity and the responsibility to slow down that deadly destruction. The federal government can protect the forests of high conservation value, but it must actually want to do it. At the very least, the government should surely uphold its own policy, minimally satisfactory as it might be.

It could at least protect forests of high conservation and wilderness value. What we do not need is more silence from the Prime Minister on the issue, more irresponsible decisions by an incompetent resources minister, and more of our best areas disappearing into the chipper.

That is an act of such shame. It is an act for which our children and our grandchildren will hold us responsible. The governments are not robbing just a few jobs; they are robbing our entire future in this area. It is now that we have the opportunity to protect these forests and I implore the government to implement its own policies and act to save the forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to draw to the Senate's attention the most unfortunate circumstances in which a fellow Australian finds himself in the United Arab Emirates. The gentleman is Mr Eric Robert Bowra, a respected boat builder from Fremantle, Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Mr Bowra earlier this year travelled to the Middle East, as he had often done in the past, to secure a boat contract. He took with him an aluminium chaser boat which was to be looked at by the United Arab Emirates government. During a sales exercise on 5 August Mr Bowra took on board an air force colonel from that country, who was a guest for the day and who participated in the exercise.

Later that day, the colonel drove another speedboat in the vicinity of the demonstration boat that Mr Bowra was driving. The colonel was accompanied by his son, and Mr Bowra had a passenger in his own boat. Whilst in the same vicinity, the two boats converged and it seems that the colonel turned incorrectly, contrary to nautical rules. Mr Bowra, being a skipper of some 16 years experience, anticipated that the colonel would turn the other way. As I understand it, Mr Bowra correctly steered to starboard, as was required by nautical rules in the circumstances. As a result of the collision, the colonel was killed and his son was severely injured. Mr Bowra survived the accident; however, his passenger too was injured.

Unfortunately, the Australian government is under the misapprehension that Mr Bowra fled the scene. I am advised by Mr Bowra's lawyers that he in fact stayed on the scene. Help was rendered to the other stricken speedboat while Mr Bowra rendered assistance to his own passenger, who had a severe leg injury. The passenger was taken to a nearby vessel where first-aid facilities were on board.

It was at that stage, as I understand it, that a friend advised Mr Bowra that he had best leave the country as soon as he could. He decided on the spur of the moment that he would go to the airport and try to board the earliest plane possible out of the country. Airline officials became suspicious. They held him at the airport and he was arrested by police. Mr Bowra was charged with causing the death of the colonel and the injury to the colonel's son. The Australian government mistakenly thought that he had been charged with murder. He was not; it was simply an equivalent of a manslaughter charge.

On 27 September this year a judge, finding that Mr Bowra had been in custody since 5 August, ruled that he had spent enough time in gaol and ordered his interim release. However, this was not complied with by the police and there was an appeal to the United Arab Emirates appeals court, which upheld the interim release order. Unfortunately, the police deemed that this too was irrelevant to the circumstances. Mr Bowra finds himself still in custody in that country.

Mr Bowra last attended court on 25 October. It was expected that, in settlement of the charge, he could pay $55,000 to the colonel's family in satisfaction for the accident and that this would secure his release. However, the prosecution maintained a claim for the wrecked speed boat. The position is that the matter was not resolved and Mr Bowra was returned to prison.

Mr Bowra's next court appearance is this Sunday. It is feared by his friends and relatives that he could well face indefinite incarceration in that country. Although the Australian authorities have had low level contact with the United Arab Emirates government, unfortunately, to date, nothing has eventuated which can shed any light on the matter or provide any hope for Mr Bowra.

It is to this end that I implore the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, to use his good offices to intervene in this matter. This matter is viewed quite seriously by those who have been involved in the matter. Mr Bowra's lawyer is most concerned about his client's possible fate. Indeed, the case was reported on the front page of the West Australian today.

Having realised the efforts that Senator Evans went to recently in the kidnapping matter in Cambodia, and the effect which I understand it had on him, I ask Senator Evans to take this on board and put a personal input into it, as I fear this Australian citizen could well have been wrongly maligned and could well be facing an indefinite period of incarceration after not having had his case properly ventilated.

It is always of concern that Australian nationals who go overseas find themselves the subject of the laws of other countries. We have to acknowledge that. We have to observe the international sensitivities that follow that. Nonetheless, in this country we still believe in a fair trial and in the fact that a person is innocent until proven guilty. I believe this case is most serious indeed and needs the full attention of the Australian government. Therefore, I implore the Minister for Foreign Affairs to use every effort to assist Mr Bowra in this matter. I believe the merits of this case require such attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ensure that the concerns of Senator Bell in relation to the forestry issues he raised are drawn to the attention of the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall. I will also ensure that the concerns raised by Senator Ellison just now are drawn to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans).

PARA.TAB: I conclude by associating myself with the remarks made by Senator O'Chee in respect of the very significant contribution that Australians of Chinese origin have made to the development of this country and, indeed, to the defence of it in our armed services. I commend Senator O'Chee for the work that he is doing. I am looking forward to seeing the results with great interest.
Towards the end of last century, thousands of Chinese people were brought to the Northern Territory not only to work on the gold fields but also to build the railway that went

SPEECH.PARA: from Darwin to Larrimah. Some of them subsequently became successful business people in the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: Of their descendants, there were a number of distinguished Australians of Chinese origin. For example, Harry Chan became President of the Legislative Council of the Northern Territory, the forerunner of the current Northern Territory parliament, and subsequently Lord Mayor of the city of Darwin. He was followed by Alec Fong Lim, who became the second Chinese-Australian Lord Mayor of the city of Darwin. Unfortunately, his tenure in that office ceased with his untimely illness and death. I think I would be speaking for most of the citizens of Darwin when I say that, without question, Alec Fong Lim would be considered one of the most popular and successful mayors the city ever had. Had it not been for his untimely death, I have no doubt that he would still be Lord Mayor of the city of Darwin.

Finally, I would like a mention another very distinguished Chinese-Australian in the Northern Territory, Mr Ray Chin, who not only served this country with great distinction during the Second World War in the Australian Air Force but, after the war, spent many years as a clerk at the table of the Northern Territory parliament and subsequently, before his retirement, became clerk of the Northern Territory parliament. The day before Remembrance Day, I wish to join with Senator O'Chee in acknowledging the very significant contribution that Chinese-Australians have made and continue to make to this country's development.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Senate adjourned at 7.52 p.m.

PARA.TAB: The following document was tabled:

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to question on notice no. 330 (Senate Hansard, 30 August 1993, page 596) which stated that `All matters which come to the Reserve Bank's attention relating to prudential supervision of banks are treated very seriously. The Bank's response to matters raised by Mr Johnson was no exception', and if that is the case:
(1) Why didn't the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) agree to a meeting with Mr Johnson, as specifically requested by Mr Johnson in his letter dated 1 July 1994.
(2) Why didn't the Governor of the RBA reply in writing to Mr Johnson's letter dated 1 July 1994.

(3) Why didn't the Governor of the RBA request Mr Johnson to officially document all his concerns about Tasmania Bank/State Bank of Tasmania so that those concerns could be fully evaluated by the RBA to enable appropriate action to be taken.

(4) Why did the Governor of the RBA have a meeting with Mr Johnson's superior, Mr Paul Kemp, on 18 July 1991, and a subsequent meeting several weeks later in Hobart, although he refused Mr Johnson's written request for a meeting.
(5) Why didn't the Governor of the RBA take Mr Johnson seriously when he was aware that Mr Johnson had been credited with saving Tasmania Bank from collapse by alerting the Premier, Mr Field.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: I have raised the honourable senator's question with the Reserve Bank which provided the following answer.

(1) We presume that the letter referred to by Senator Bell is that dated 1 July 1991. Given the seriousness of the allegations raised by Mr Johnson in this letter, the Governor made immediate enquiries of both Mr Johnson and the General Manager of the newly merged Tasmania Bank/Savings Bank of Tasmania, Mr Paul Kemp. In light of the responses received, it was decided that a meeting with Mr Johnson was not warranted.
(2) The Governor considered that, in the circumstances, it would be more appropriate and responsible to telephone Mr Johnson direct to discuss immediately the matters raised in his letter.

(3) See answers to (1) and (2) above. Mr Johnson was given the opportunity to elaborate on his concerns when the Governor spoke to him following the receipt of his letter. After discussion within the Reserve Bank and with Mr Kemp, it was felt that Mr Johnson's allegations had been fully aired. Mr Johnson was, of course, free to contact the Bank again if he had further information to offer. (We assume the reference to the "State Bank of Tasmania" should be to the "Savings Bank of Tasmania".)

(4) The Governor did not meet with Mr Kemp on 18 July 1991. While he was in Hobart on 3 October 1991 to speak at a conference, the Governor called upon Mr Kemp to discuss various issues relating to the Trust Bank Tasmania.

(5) As stated in the reply to Question 330 to which the Senator refers, all matters which come to the Reserve Bank's attention relating to the prudential standing of a bank are treated very seriously; Mr Johnson's allegations were no exception. The allegations contained in his letter of 1 July 1991 were investigated thoroughly.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to question on notice no. 330 (Senate Hansard, 30 August 1993, page 596) which stated that `The bank would be very concerned, and would object strongly if it believed that a bank employee had suffered in any way as a result of providing information in good faith to it', why did the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) not show concern by objecting strongly to Mr Alban Johnson's sacking.
(2) Why hasn't the Governor of the RBA publicly supported Mr Johnson's action of writing to the Tasmanian Premier about the problems of Tasmania Bank.

(3) If the RBA `would be very concerned and would object strongly if it believed that a bank employee had suffered in any way as a result of providing information in good faith to it', why did the Governor of the RBA write to Mrs Johnson on 20 August 1991 and say `the issue of the circumstances of your husband's separation from the bank and the question of possible compensation are matters to be pursued through channels other than the Reserve Bank.'

(4) Why was it left to Mr Johnson to save Tasmania Bank from collapse when, by his own admission, the Governor of the RBA has stated that the soundness of Tasmania Bank was a matter which came within the responsibilities of the RBA.

(5) With reference to the Statement in the Governor's letter of 20 August 1991 to Mrs Johnson that the RBA had made a number of inquiries: (a) what inquiries were made, and to whom; (b) were inquiries made to executives of the bank about whom Mr Johnson had expressed concerns; and (c) did the Governor of the RBA request Mr Johnson to properly document all his concerns so as to enable the RBA to properly evaluate them and take appropriate remedial action; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: I have raised the honourable senator's question with the Reserve Bank which provided the following answer.

(1) It is the Reserve Bank's understanding that Mr Johnson was made redundant following a restructure of the merged Tasmania Bank/Savings Bank of Tasmania; the decision to terminate his services was based on an independent assessment of his suitability for a management position in the merged bank. This was not a matter for the Reserve Bank.

(2) Mr Johnson claims to have written anonymously to the Premier of Tasmania in June and August 1990; Mr Johnson's identity was not known to the Governor until it was revealed in his letter of 1 July 1991. The Reserve Bank has no independent knowledge of the contents of Mr Johnson's correspondence with the Premier.

(3) The Governor wrote to Mrs Johnson in reply to a letter received from her. The statements quoted reflect the Reserve Bank's belief that the decision to terminate Mr Johnson's services arose out of a review of the Bank's staffing requirements, and not from any communication between the Governor and Mr Kemp. See answer to Question 1.

(4) Mr Johnson claims to have been responsible for drawing to the attention of the Premier the existence of problems in Tasmania Bank. The Premier ordered an audit investigation of Tasmania Bank, which revealed the full magnitude of the bank's problems. During the relevant period the bank was being supervised under a voluntary arrangement by the Reserve Bank. The Reserve Bank raised a number of issues of potential concern with the bank during this time but was assured by management that they were cognisant of the risks and were comfortable with the bank's position; the accounts of the bank had been subject to external audit and the Reserve Bank relied on the audit to detect any problems that were not evident in the data available to it.

(5) (a) Given the serious nature of the allegations contained in Mr Johnson's letter of 1 July 1991, the Governor, in the first instance, sought advice from the senior officers within the Reserve Bank responsible for the prudential supervision of banks. The Governor also had a conversation with Mr Cullen of the Australian Bankers' Association, who had been approached by Mr Johnson. He then telephoned Mr Johnson, and also Mr Kemp to obtain the bank's response to the allegations.

(b) Mr Johnson's letter of 1 July 1991 did not identify any particular executives of the merged bank about which he harboured any concerns; it merely made a broad assertion about the competency of the management of the merged bank compared with the previous management of Tasmania Bank.
(c) No. See answer to Question 1473(3).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 July 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Can farmers acquiring grape vines claim a 4-year write-off under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936?
(2) Do sugar cane growers obtaining clean disease-free plants to plant cane get a tax deduction?
(3) Can banana growers who grow their own root stock from existing trees claim the cost of wages and materials as a deduction on income tax?

(4) Is it a fact that banana growers acquiring clean disease-free banana plants stock from proper authorities cannot claim either an income-tax deduction during the year of purchase, or a write-off over a number of years; if so, what is the justification for preventing banana growers who acquire clean treated plant stock to support the multi-million dollar banana industry from obtaining a tax deduction for the cost input, whereas other growers in similar positions are able to claim such a tax deduction?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) A concessional write-off for grape vines was provided with effect from 1993-94 in recognition of the disadvantages grape growers might suffer following the wine tax increase in the 1993-94 Budget.

Expenditure incurred on or after 1 July 1993 on establishing grape vines in Australia for use in a business of primary production is deductible over four years. Deductions are available from the time the vines are planted in the land.

A person engaged in a business of primary production who acquires vines within four years of planting will be entitled to a deduction for the remainder of the four year deduction period. The deduction will be pro-rated between the purchaser and vendor in the year of change.

(2) Expenditure incurred in planting annual crops such as sugar cane is deductible. The cost of disease free plants for planting is therefore fully deductible for income tax purposes in the year in which the costs are incurred.

(3) Expenditure incurred in the initial planting of banana trees and other fruit trees is expenditure of a capital nature and is not tax deductible. Accordingly, expenditure incurred by banana growers on wages and materials used in growing their own root stock is not deductible.

(4) Generally, expenditure of a capital nature is not deductible under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The cost of planting fruit trees is expenditure of a capital nature and is therefore not tax deductible. The cost of planting fruit trees is capital expenditure regardless of the kind of fruit tree planted. There are exceptions to the general principle that capital expenditure is not deductible. Such exceptions include measures implemented for particular purposes such as expenditure on combating or controlling land degradation and environment protection expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 July 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why didn't the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr Fraser, request the boards of the Tasmania Bank and the State Bank of Tasmania to call in external independent auditors after he received Mr Johnson's letter of 1 July 1991, rather than accepting assurances from the same executives about whom Mr Johnson had expressed concerns.

(2) In the light of Mr Johnson's summary dismissal from the Tasmania Bank less than 24 hours after talking to the Governor of the Reserve Bank about his concerns about the Tasmania Bank, what should other bank officers do when they have serious concerns about senior executives in their bank and want to discuss it with officers of the Reserve Bank.
(3) Did the Governor of the Reserve Bank act unethically in breaching the confidence of Mr Johnson when he disclosed to Mr Paul Kemp the contents of the letter from Mr Johnson; if so, why.

(4) Has the Governor of the Reserve Bank signed a declaration of secrecy in which he solemnly declares he will at all times maintain secrecy in relation to the affairs of the Reserve Bank, and in particular that he will not directly or indirectly communicate or divulge any information that comes to his knowledge in the performance of his functions as a member of the Reserve Bank board, except by authority of the Reserve Bank board or under compulsion or obligations of law.

(5) Did Mr Fraser telephone Mr Kemp on 2 July 1991 and disclose to him that Mr Johnson had written him a private and confidential letter, and did Mr Fraser act unethically by breaching Mr Johnson's confidence by disclosing to Mr Kemp the contents of the letter; if so, does such an action contravene section 16 of the Reserve Bank Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: I have raised the honourable senator's question with the Reserve Bank which provided the following answer.

(1) The claims made in Mr Johnson's letter of 1 July 1991 were thoroughly investigated by the Reserve Bank, drawing on the extensive prudential data available to the Reserve Bank and after consultation with Mr Johnson and the merged bank's General Manager, Mr Kemp. The Bank's decision not to refer the matter further was based on the results of its own analysis and knowledge of the merged bank, and information already available from auditors.

(2) See response to Question 1480 (1). Where any bank officer has concerns which have the potential to threaten the stability of a bank it would be appropriate to raise these with the Reserve Bank, in the knowledge that such concerns will be treated seriously and investigated thoroughly and impartially.

(3) No; the contents of the letter were disclosed in a general way in order to elicit management's views on the allegations about the stability of the bank. It was important that the issues be addressed immediately.
(4) The Governor made a Declaration of Secrecy in the form prescribed in the Reserve Bank Regulations.

(5) The Governor did not act unethically or unlawfully in communicating with Mr Kemp on 2 July 1991. The Governor has acted entirely consistently with his duties under the Reserve Bank Act and the Banking Act, which among other things, require that the Bank monitor the prudential soundness of banks and act to ensure the protection of their depositors. Section 69D of the Banking Act clearly acknowledges that disclosure of information will sometimes be appropriate where necessary for performance of functions or duties under this Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 9 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to changes to Australian foreign policy in East Timor since the Indonesian invasion of 1975:
(1) Please detail any Australian foreign policy changes that led to the recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor and the timing of those changes since 1975.
(2) Please explain the rationale for any changes.
(3) Please advise whether there are any other countries, besides Australia, that recognise Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Government recognises Indonesia's sovereign authority over East Timor. In 1979 the then Coalition Government extended de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor. This has been maintained by successive Labor Governments. The Government explicitly confirmed its recognition policy in a statement to Parliament by the then Prime Minister Mr Hawke on 22 August 1985 (Hansard, 22 August 1985 page 222).

(2) The decision taken by the then Coalition Government to recognise Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor in 1979 is not for this Government to explain, but in the context of reaffirming Australia's recognition of Indonesia's sovereignty over East Timor in 1985, the then Prime Minister Mr Hawke said that the fact of Indonesian control over East Timor had been demonstrated. The Government believes the best way to serve and advance the interests of the people of East Timor is by working constructively with the Indonesian Government within the framework of recognition of Indonesia's claims over the territory, rather than in a spirit of confrontation.

(3) The Australian Government cannot speak for other Governments concerning their policy on recognising Indonesia's sovereignty over East Timor. However, according to information available to the Government, at least thirty one countries can be assessed as having indicated that they have recognised the sovereignty of Indonesia over East Timor at some time since 1976 by public statement, by explanation of vote in the United Nations or through the signing of a treaty with Indonesia which contains a territorial clause that covers East Timor.

The following countries, apart from Australia, have made public statements recognising Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor: India, Papua New Guinea and the United States of America (which has stated that it recognises incorporation of East Timor into Indonesia without recognising that a valid act of self-determination has taken place).

States that have indicated that they have recognised the incorporation of East Timor, at some stage since 1976, through an explanation of their vote at the United Nations General Assembly include: Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Bangladesh, Canada, Sweden, Papua New Guinea, India, Oman and Jordan.

It is common practice for Indonesia, when it negotiates a bilateral treaty, to insert a clause which defines Indonesia as that territory which is deemed by the laws of Indonesia to be subject to Indonesian sovereignty. A treaty which contains such a provision (if concluded after 1976) can be regarded as evidence that the relevant state party recognises East Timor as being part of Indonesia. The following twenty four states have signed such treaties: Austria, Brunei Darussalam, Bulgaria, Canada, China, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, India, Italy, Japan, the Republic of Korea, New Zealand, Norway, Pakistan, the Philippines, Saudi Arabia, Singapore, Sweden, Switzerland, Thailand and the United Arab Emirates.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 8 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware of a situation involving the paper recycling company Austissue and another manufacturer, Packmore Merchandising, whereby a bounty in order to compensate the first company, supposed to offset sales tax re-imposed by the Government in 1992, is being paid to the first company, which is not in fact subject to sales tax.

(2) Has this unintended windfall to Austissue resulted in a legal challenge by the second manufacturer, Packmore Merchandising, which purchases the product from Austissue in order to produce an end product that is subject to sales tax but without the relief of the bounty.
(3) Is the Minister aware that this inequity has resulted in a legal challenge.
(4) Has this decision seriously disadvantaged some Australian companies that invested millions of dollars in order to utilise recycled paper.
(5) Has the Minister received Senator Coulter's letters of 25 November 1993, 24 January 1994 and 14 April 1994 highlighting this unintended inequity.

(6) Is the Minister aware that the misrepresentation of the bounty scheme involves many millions of dollars; if so, why has the Minister failed to respond to or otherwise acknowledge any of these letters.
(7) What action will the Minister take to rectify this inequity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The Treasury received a letter of 29 March 1993 on this matter from solicitors representing one of the companies involved, replied to it on 13 April 1994 and has provided evidence subsequently in the court case between Packmore Merchandising and Austissue.

The Government does not accept that the transitional assistance for recycled paper manufacturers should be directed to the company that pays sales tax on certain 100 per cent recycled paper products. The transitional assistance is deliberately targeted to specialist manufacturers of 100 per cent recycled paper for the production of toilet or facial tissues, paper bags or exercise books, ie to companies that use waste paper as the sole source of fibre input to the paper they manufacture. The transitional assistance enables specialist recycled paper manufacturers who invested in equipment used to make waste paper into 100 per cent recycled paper to adjust to the removal of the sales tax exemption. The transitional assistance is not available to downstream companies, such as those that convert recycled paper manufactured by other domestic or overseas companies into final paper products.

Transitional assistance would be misdirected if, as suggested by Senator Coulter, it went to the company paying the sales tax on the affected 100 per cent recycled paper products. This is because sales tax is collected at the point of final wholesale sale, and the wholesaler, paper converter, or importer may have made no investment based upon the introduction of the sales tax exemption. Further, such arrangements would risk the duplication of compensation where the same stream of paper was involved in various transactions before the final wholesale sale. It would also lead to imported recycled paper products attracting the compensation, which would further disadvantage domestic products.

(2) There is no `unintended windfall' for the reasons provided at (1). The scheme is operating as intended. As indicated in the response to (1), the Government is aware of the dispute between the two companies.
(3) See above.

(4) No. See my response to (1) on the transitional assistance payment arrangements. Companies that convert paper are more easily able to change between using different types of virgin, part-recycled or wholly recycled papers than specialist paper manufacturers that have invested to produce 100 per cent recycled papers.
(5) Yes.
(6) The Assistant Treasurer responded to the correspondence to which Senator Coulter refers on 23 June 1994.
(7) No action is warranted.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: Given the decision in the week beginning 12 September 1994 of the Federal Court in the case of ICI Australia Limited v Commissioner of Taxation and also given the fact that the taxpayer was held to have made a profit or gain as a result of the debt defeasance scheme and the amount treated as assessable income, and given that this decision appears totally inconsistent with another Federal Court decision, made 3 months ago on almost identical facts, where the taxpayer was found not to have made a profit or gain:
(1) Which decision correctly represents the law.
(2) Will the new code of taxing arrangements for financial instruments cover debt defeasance arrangements.
(3) What is the progress of the new code.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The earlier case referred to is Unilever Australia Securities Ltd v FCT which was decided on 22 June 1994. In each case the principal question was whether a profit or gain from a debt defeasance arrangement was income, within the ordinary connotation of that word. Drawing the distinction between income and capital receipts can sometimes be a difficult matter, and factual differences between cases can be very significant. The Unilever decision has been appealed to the Full Federal Court and an appeal to the Full Court is expected in the ICI Australia case. It is expected that any inconsistencies between the two decisions will in due course be reconciled by the decisions of the Full Court.

(2) The taxation consequences of debt defeasance arrangements are specifically addressed in Chapter 10 of the Government's Consultative Document, "Taxation of Financial Arrangements", which was released in December 1993.

(3) A small team of Treasury and Australian Tax Office officials has been analysing a wide range of policy issues that have arisen out of responses to the Consultative Document, "Taxation of Financial Arrangements". Some 40 submissions were lodged by the extended deadline for comment of 30 May 1994.

In conformity with undertakings to consult widely on this matter, officials have been in regular discussion with a small group of private sector experts on the major issues raised in submissions. It is expected that, in the near future, meetings will be held with the various representative taxpayer industry and professional organisations to inform them of developments that have taken place since the release of the Consultative Document.
After that initial round of consultations, the Government intends to prepare an Exposure Draft Bill of the proposed financial arrangements accruals tax system for further comment and debate.

PARA.TAB: Neither the Department nor the National Health and Medical Research Council have initiated research into iridology and breast cancer. The Department is not aware of any compelling evidence that would warrant commissioning of research in this area, and the NHMRC has not been approached by any researchers wishing to investigate it. The NHMRC is prepared to assess any proposals for research relating to breast cancer, including research into iridology and breast cancer.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: What customs and immigration regulations apply to ensure that: (a) minors coming into or leaving Australia have the approval in writing of both parents and/or guardians to leave their country of origin; (b) both parents/guardians have given approval in writing for the minor to be in the company of the person with whom they are travelling; (c) any child custody laws or any other laws are not circumvented or breached by the minor entering or leaving Australia; and (d) in the case of minors entering Australia, their place of residence is known and access available to authorities during all stages of their stay in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) Australia is a signatory to The Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Applications for minors to come to Australia are carefully considered to ensure that as far as possible, visas are not granted to children where the grant would infringe upon the rights of custody or access that another person may have in respect of the child.

There is a regulatory criterion in permanent visa classes and visitor classes in Schedule 2 of the Migration Regulations requiring that grant of a visa will not prejudice the rights of persons with custody, guardianship or access to a child applicant.

It is a policy requirement that if a child is to accompany one parent to Australia documentation should normally be sought to show that either the accompanying parent has sole custody of the child, or that the other parent has given written consent to the visit or the other parent is in Australia.
The laws relating to children leaving Australia are not a matter for the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
(b) Public Interest criterion 4012 of the Migration Regulations sets out additional requirements for unaccompanied minors visiting non-relatives in Australia.

It is a policy requirement that the written consent of the person(s) having custody of the child would normally be required for any child under 18 years of age who is to travel unaccompanied by a parent or guardian. In most cases this means that both parents should give written consent.

(c) Children can only enter Australia legally using an Australian passport or a visaed passport of their country of citizenship. The issue of an Australian passport to a minor child is authorised by the Department of Foreign Affairs.
(d) There are no immigration regulations to ensure that in the case of minors, their place of residence is known and access available to authorities during all stages of their stay in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the technology at Nurrungar and Pine Gap out of date; if so, please explain what purposes are not being met by the existing technology.
(2) What comments has the United States (US) made with regard to the future of the Nurrungar and Pine Gap bases in Australia.
(3) Has there been any dialogue between the US and Australian Government on the future of the bases in Australia; if so, what was the nature of this dialogue.
(4) Has the US Government provided a possible date for the bases to close; if so, when.
(5) Is it the US Government's intention to eventually close the bases; if so, when (please specify for each base).
(6) If it is the Australian Government's intention to eventually close the bases; if so, when (please specify for each base).
(7) Which country has the power to decide to close the US bases in Australia, and please explain the conditions upon any closure of the bases.

(8) Does the Minister still maintain his view about the future of the bases expressed in the Senate in February 1994 that the bases "wouldn't be there forever . . . indeed I doubt it will be there by the end of this century".
(9) What is meant by the Minister's assertion that the bases would not be around by the year 2000.
(10) Do the Minister's comments refer to any intention by Australia to give the US 3 years notice to quit the bases in 1995, in light of the fact that the 10 year leases come up for renewal in 1998.

(11) (a) Is it the Government's intention to renew the leases to Nurrungar and Pine Gap in 1998; if so, what is the reason for the renewal of the lease, and what role and functions will be carried out; (b) will the bases take on any new functions or roles; if not, will a notice to quit be presented to the US in 1995; and (c) can the US Government refuse an Australian request to close the bases; if so, why.
(12) Are there any future plans for further upgrading of the Nurrungar and Pine Gap bases; if so, please explain what equipment and technology will be upgraded and its purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Nurrungar and Pine Gap both continue to perform the functions for which they were built. They both conduct ongoing maintenance programs and occasionally upgrade their existing capabilities to incorporate new technologies.

(2) to (11) The Australian and United States Governments maintain regular and detailed dialogue on the future of the Joint Facilities. I do not propose to provide details of that dialogue. However, as the honourable senator may be aware, I expanded upon my statement of 7 February 1994 in the Senate Estimates Committee B hearing of 22 February 1994. I have nothing to add to my statement of 22 February. Further, I would emphasise that those statements related solely to the Joint Defence Facility Nurrungar and should not be interpreted as including the Joint Defence Facility Pine Gap.

Australia does not lease the land at Pine Gap or Nurrungar to the United States. Rather, the Joint Defence Facilities operate pursuant to Government-to-Government Agreements signed in the 1960s and extended for 10 year non-terminable periods by Exchanges of Notes on 16 November 1988.

Under the 1988 arrangements, each Government can give three years notice to terminate either Agreement after seven years. Notice can, therefore, be given at any time after 16 November 1995. If neither party gives such notice, the Joint Defence Facilities will operate beyond 1998 under existing Agreements until such time as either Government has given the required three years notice or alternative arrangements are agreed.

Neither Australia nor the United States have advised the other of a date on which it intends to give formal notice to terminate either Agreement. The Australian Government does not intend to give the United States notice to terminate either Agreement in 1995.
(12) With regard to Pine Gap, I refer the honourable senator to my response to part 3 of her Question on Notice No. 1625 of 23 August 1994. There are no comparable projects planned for Nurrungar.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, in a question without notice, on 29 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: Why has the Government rejected the introduction of a superannuation savings account which, as well as increasing competition, would mean low administrative costs, not another layer of government bureaucracy, and would give workers greater control over their savings? Why must Australian women be required to subsidise the ACTU's monopoly on the use of their savings?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: A number of banking groups presently offer "over the counter" superannuation savings accounts through their branch networks. Like all superannuation products these accounts must be provided through an interposed trust structure, usually the banks' life office subsidiaries.

In essence, what the banks and others were seeking was the removal of this interposed trustee requirement and the introduction of a separate regulatory regime involving its own tax collection arrangements and lower obligations for supervision and disclosure in respect of the superannuation accounts they provide. In other words what the banks and others were seeking would not have amounted to equal access to superannuation.

The Government believes that such an arrangement would have conferred unfair competitive advantages on a select group of institutions to the longer term detriment of its superannuation policy objectives.

The requirement that superannuation products must be offered through a trust structure ensures that all industry participants are subject to the same rules. It also ensures that all superannuation savings enjoy similar regulatory protection.

SSA's, moreover, are not needed to address the so called small amounts problem, nor would they have effectively done so. The measures I announced on 28 June 1994 provide a universal and comprehensive remedy to that problem. Also, they do so in a way that does not impose further major structural changes on an industry that has already endured substantial and costly adjustment over recent years. Casual and part time employees, a majority of whom are women, will be the major beneficiaries of these latest Government initiatives.
